headlines: Politician beats man, runs auto on him after he refuses to give ₹100 for alcohol
text: A 28-year-old CPM leader Pradeep was arrested in Kerala after he and his friends allegedly assaulted a jackfruit trader after he refused to pay ₹100 they wanted for alcohol to celebrate New Year, police said. The accused pinned the victim down on road and asked his colleague to run an auto-rickshaw on him. The trader was hospitalised with multiple fractures.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: NASA loses contact with satellite seeking planets outside Solar System
text: NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory has lost contact with ASTERIA, a briefcase-sized satellite designed to find planets outside Solar System. The space agency said the last successful communication with it occurred on December 5 and attempts to contact it could continue into March. The satellite observes stars for a dip in their brightness to indicate the presence of an orbiting planet.
author: Dharna

headlines: Gurdwara Nankana Sahib 'untouched and undamaged': Pak after mob attack
text: After a mob attacked Gurdwara Nankana Sahib in Pakistan, the country said, "The Gurdwara remains untouched and undamaged." "Attempts to paint this incident as a communal issue are patently motivated," Pakistan added. The altercation happened over a minor incident at a tea-stall and authorities immediately intervened and arrested the accused, it further said.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Greta changes Twitter name to Sharon after Celebrity Mastermind video goes viral
text: Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg has changed her Twitter name to Sharon after a clip from a game show 'Celebrity Mastermind' went viral. In the video actress Amanda Henderson is asked which Swedish climate change activist wrote 'No One is Too Small To Make A Difference'. The question stumped Henderson, who shook her head before answering: "Sharon".
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Porn site to pay ₹91 crore to 22 women who didn't know videos would be posted
text: A US judge has awarded $12.7 million (over ₹91 crore) to 22 unnamed women, ruling that they were tricked into appearing in widely distributed online porn videos. The women were told the videos were for a private collector or overseas DVDs and would never appear online. However, the videos were uploaded to a subscription-based amateur porn website.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Japan café hosts playdates for robotic dogs and their owners
text: A café in Japan's Tokyo has started hosting playdates for robotic dogs and their owners. Specifically catering to Aibo, an AI-powered robot built by Sony with cloud-based memory and facial recognition capability, the event sees Aibos performing and learning tricks. "It would break my heart to have another dog die," an owner told BuzzFeed on why she bought the robot.
author: Dharna

headlines: In our times, we had heroines as props, were only used in songs: Gulzar
text: Lyricist Gulzar, while talking about the journey of women in the film industry, said, "In our times, we'd have heroines as props. They'd be taken on outings...were only used in songs." He added that the things have changed now and women are present everywhere in the film industry. "[They've] empowered themselves and come forward in every way possible," Gulzar said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: I don't expect support from B'wood when it comes to controversy: Sooraj
text: Actor Sooraj Pancholi, while talking about the controversies he's been involved in, said that he hasn't done anything wrong and no one has been able to prove anything against him. "But kisi ko toh bakra banana hai, mujhe bana diya," he added. Talking about the support he got from Bollywood, the 30-year-old actor said, "I don't expect much from them."
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Have only seen clips of Joaquin Phoenix's Joker: Martin Scorsese
text: On being asked if he had the chance to watch the Joaquin Phoenix-starrer 'Joker', filmmaker Martin Scorsese said he's only seen clips of it. "I know it...why do I need to," he added. Scorsese, who was earlier attached to the film as a co-producer, had said in an interview that he opted out of the project due to "personal reasons".
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Politicians serving biryani at protests: BJP leader to Delhi Police
text: BJP's Braham Singh from Delhi's Okhla wrote to the police alleging that Congress and AAP leaders are politicising the Shaheen Bagh protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act by serving biryani. He also added that BJP (Okhla unit) would stage a dharna if Noida-Kalindi Kunj road isn't opened in 48 hours. "Businessmen, students...facing trouble due to anti-social elements," Singh further wrote.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Declare those opposing CAA as anti-Dalit, anti-poor: BJP's Nityanand
text: BJP leader and Minister of State for Home Affairs Nityanand Rai has said that those who are opposing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) should be declared "anti-Dalit" and "anti-poor". "Most of the persecuted refugees are OBCs (Other Backward Classes) and Dalits," he added. Rai further said that the anti-CAA people are against OBCs and their leader Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Snapchat acquires deepfake startup AI Factory for $166 million
text: Snapchat-maker Snap has acquired AI Factory, a startup developing image and video recognition technology. Snap reportedly made the purchase for $166 million to power its new 'Cameos' feature that lets users insert their selfies into an existing scene, similar to deepfakes. AI Factory was founded by Victor Shaburov, who also founded facial-recognition startup Looksery, acquired by Snap in 2015.
author: Dharna

headlines: Hard work, no special treatment: Musk's mom on raising successful kids
text: Maye Musk, mother of billionaire entrepreneur Elon Musk, on the topic of raising three 'successful' children said she taught them about hard work. In her book 'A Woman Makes a Plan', she wrote, "I didn't treat them like babies...didn't check their homework...that was their responsibility." Musk added she let them live in "poor" conditions during college including mattresses on floor.
author: Dharna

headlines: Man tries to burn pump employee after denied petrol in bottle, arrested
text: A man was arrested for allegedly attempting to burn a petrol pump employee in Uttar Pradesh's Moradabad after the latter denied giving him fuel in a bottle. "The man got angry...bought the fuel from [another] petrol pump and tried to burn down the employee using that," police added. The man has been arrested on the charges of attempt to murder.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: 10 infants die within month in hospital in Rajasthan's Bundi
text: At least 10 infants died in the month of December last year in a hospital in Rajasthan's Bundi. The administration said that the deaths didn't occur due to their irresponsibility and added, "Some...were underweight...others had breathing issues...some had consumed contaminated water," hospital's Duty in-Charge said. The Additional District Collector (ADC) made a round of the hospital on Friday.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: J&K Police arrests LeT militant from a Srinagar hospital
text: A Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT) militant was arrested from Srinagar's Shri Maharaja Hari Singh Hospital on Saturday by the Special Operations Group of the Jammu and Kashmir Police. The militant was identified as Nisar Ahmad Dar and is a resident of the Hajin area of north Kashmir's Bandipore. Further details are awaited, a police official said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: There should be no more corporate tax cuts: Nobel laureate Banerjee
text: Nobel laureate Abhijit Banerjee has advised against any further cuts in corporate taxes in the upcoming Union Budget. He added, "It needs to be understood that the corporate sector isn't short of cash. Just that it is not investing." "What you need to do is get the demand side going. Get money in hands of people...they will spend," Banerjee said.
author: Dharna

headlines: Killed Iranian General was responsible for terrorist plots in Delhi: Trump
text: Stating that Iranian General Qassem Soleimani, who was killed in a US strike in Baghdad, "made the death of innocent people his sick passion", US President Donald Trump said, "He contributed to terrorist plots as far away as New Delhi and London." "We took action...to stop a war. We did not take action to start a war," Trump further said.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: 7-year-old swallows AirPods he got as Christmas gift, gets hospitalised
text: A 7-year-old boy from the US was hospitalised after accidentally swallowing one of the Apple AirPods that he received as a Christmas gift from his mother. The doctors took an X-Ray which showed the wireless headset sitting below the child's ribs and released him after assuring the device would pass naturally. "No more AirPods for this kid," his mother said.
author: Dharna

headlines: SP promises pension for anti-CAA protestors in UP; BJP says 'SP honours rioters'
text: Samajwadi Party on Friday promised pension for anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) protestors in Uttar Pradesh if voted to power. SP leader Ram Govind Chaudhary said their party would also give compensation to the kin of those jailed or killed during anti-CAA protests in the state. Criticising the move, BJP said it was in the "DNA of [SP] to honour rioters".
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: CAA won't benefit Rohingyas in J&K; they'll be deported: Union Minister
text: Union Minister Jitendra Singh on Friday said that Rohingyas living in Jammu and Kashmir will be deported since they are not eligible for citizenship under the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). Singh added that details of the deportation of Rohingyas are yet to be figured out. "Their lists will be prepared and biometrics wherever required will be taken," he said.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Captain once dropped himself, replacement broke his ribs
text: England captain Mike Denness left himself out of the team for an Ashes Test that started on January 4, 1975, after scoring 65 runs in previous six innings. John Edrich replaced Denness as captain and broke his ribs after getting hit by the first ball he faced in the second innings. Australia went on to win by 171 runs.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Won't lodge complaint against Shubman, no question of stretching matter: Delhi
text: DDCA secretary Vinod Tihara has said that Delhi team will not lodge any complaint with the match referee against Punjab opener Shubman Gill for not walking after being given out in their Ranji Trophy match. "We believe that the matter ended then and there...No question of stretching the matter and honestly, there was no walk-off either," he added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Don Bradman once reversed batting order, scored 270 at no. 7
text: Cricket legend Don Bradman reversed the Australian batting order to protect batsmen from 'wet' wicket in the second innings of the third Ashes Test in 1937. The innings was opened by Australia's tail-enders while Bradman came to bat at number seven on January 4, and scored 270(375). Bradman's knock was later named by Wisden as the greatest in Test cricket.n
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: We have the most toxic air in the world at the moment: Kyrgios breaks down
text: Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios broke down during post-match interview after raising ₹2 lakh for the bushfire victims following his victory in ATP Cup. "My home town's Canberra, and we've the most toxic air in the world at the moment...so it's pretty sad," Kyrgios said rubbing his eyes. "It's tough to go out here and concentrate on tennis," he added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Tesla crosses $80 billion in market value, adds $48 billion in just 7 months
text: Billionaire Elon Musk-led Tesla crossed $80 billion in market value on Friday after the electric carmaker beat analyst estimates for annual vehicle deliveries. The Silicon Valley company added $48 billion to its market cap in just 7 months as its shares surged 150%. It is now worth $28 billion more than General Motors and more than twice of Ford.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Tesla shares rise to record high as carmaker meets 2019 delivery goal
text: Tesla shares rose to a record high of $454 apiece, following the announcement that its annual vehicle deliveries for 2019 met the target laid out by it. Tesla delivered around 3,67,500 cars during the year, meeting its 3,60,000-4,00,000 vehicle target. In the fourth quarter alone, the Elon Musk-led automaker produced a record 1,05,000 vehicles and delivered 1,12,000, beating analyst estimates.
author: Dharna

headlines: To cover up CAA stir: Raj Minister on 'politics' over infant deaths
text: Rajasthan Health Minister Dr Raghu Sharma on Friday said that the opposition BJP's "politics over death of children in Kota" was being done to cover up anti-CAA protests. He also blamed the previous BJP-led state government for not releasing funds sought by the hospital. "When...BJP was in power, hospital authority had sought funds. Why wasn't money released then?" he said.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Pak PM tweets old video from B'desh as 'Indian police's pogrom against Muslims'
text: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan on Friday shared an old video showing the Rapid Action Battalion of Bangladesh police attacking unarmed men and tried to pass it off as "Indian police's pogrom against Muslims in UP." He shared another video showing clashes between farmers and police in Unnao as "ethnic cleansing" of Muslims in India. Khan later deleted the tweets.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: UP Police accused of stripping cleric, raping minors in orphanage
text: Uttar Pradesh Police has been accused of stripping and torturing a 66-year-old Muslim cleric Asad Raza Hussaini in custody. The police has also been accused of detaining and assaulting around 100 students of the Maulana from the Saadat hostel-cum-orphanage in Muzaffarnagar town. Some students also suffered rectal bleeding from the torture, a local Congress politician alleged.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Policeman came to my house to solve case & raped me: 30-yr-old Odisha woman
text: A 30-year-old woman from Odisha's Puri has alleged that she was raped by a police officer three months ago after he had visited her residence for solving a case filed against her family. She said the accused had threatened to put her in jail if she ever told anyone about the incident. An investigation has been launched in the case.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Trump called me to his office to kiss, told me I was the hottest one: News anchor
text: A news anchor has revealed that Donald Trump called her before becoming the US President and said, "You should come up to my office sometime, so we can kiss." Trump also told Courtney Friel that he considered her "the hottest one at Fox News". Friel said she ended the call after telling Trump that "we're both married".
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Indonesia injects chemicals into clouds to halt rain after floods kill 43
text: Indonesia conducted cloud seeding on Friday to prevent further rainfall over Jakarta and surrounding areas amid flash floods and landslides. The Air Force shot salt flares into clouds in an attempt to trigger rainfall. The move is aimed at breaking up clouds before they reach Jakarta. The disaster mitigation agency said at least 43 people have died as of Friday.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Adani to buy India's second-largest private sector port for ₹13,572 crore
text: India's largest private port operator Adani Ports has agreed to buy a 75% stake in Krishnapatnam Port for an enterprise value of ₹13,572 crore. The port, located in Andhra Pradesh, is India's second-largest private port and handled 54 million metric tonnes of cargo in 2019. Adani operates 10 ports and terminals and handles over 350 MMT of cargo a year.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Tamasha around Faiz's poem is so ridiculous: Vishal Bhardwaj
text: After IIT-Kanpur set up a panel to decide if Faiz Ahmed Faiz's poem 'Hum Dekhenge' hurts Hindu sentiments, filmmaker Vishal Bhardwaj said the 'tamasha' around his poem is ridiculous. "To understand the poetry, you need to feel it," he added. "You need...certain standard of emotional intelligence which seems to be...lacking in those who are interpreting it as...anti-Hindu," Vishal further said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Labuschagne seems like right guy to lead Australia in future: Ponting
text: Former Australia skipper Ricky Ponting has said that Marnus Labuschagne could lead Australia in Tests in the future. "He seems like the right sort of guy to be a captain down the track," he said. In the ongoing third Test against New Zealand, Labuschagne scored his fourth ton in five Tests as Australia ended the first day at 283/3.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Nanoleaf smart light system learns from users and responds to needs
text: Smart-lighting startup Nanoleaf announced displaying its new Nanoleaf Learning Series at the CES 2020 which learns from its users and reacts to their needs. The startup said the light system minimizes need for adjustments or voice controls and provides light where needed. A Nanoleaf spokesperson told Engadget the system will work with light bulbs as well as the light panels.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Fortnite remains top-earning game in 2019 even as revenue drops
text: Fortnite remained the highest-earning online video game of the year 2019, with research firm SuperData putting the revenue figure at $1.8 billion. This is, however, a decline of 25% compared to the $2.4 billion revenue earned by Fortnite in 2018. The video game was developed by US-based Epic Games and was launched in 2017.
author: Dharna

headlines: Segway-Ninebot unveils a self-balancing transportation pod
text: China's Segway-Ninebot Group unveiled a self-balancing transportation pod, called the S-Pod, which allows one to sit while navigating around enclosed campuses. The pod can run at a maximum speed of 38.6 kmph and lets passengers adjust the speed by changing the centre of gravity in the pod. It also unveiled a kick scooter with a maximum speed of 20 kmph.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Woman who had breasts removed due to misdiagnosis calls for AI in hospitals
text: The UK's Sarah Boyle, who underwent double mastectomy and chemotherapy due to a misdiagnosis by doctors in 2016, has now called for use of artificial intelligence in hospitals to save others from being misdiagnosed. She was told she had triple-negative breast cancer before doctors admitted their mistake. Doctors later told her a reconstructive surgery could increase cancer risks in future.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: New mathematical model predicts stability of knots
text: MIT researchers have developed a mathematical model to predict the stability of knots, based on properties like the number of crossings involved and the direction in which the rope segments twist. Researchers also found that a knot can be made stronger if it has more "circulations," defined as regions where two parallel strands loop against each other in opposite directions.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: We want nationwide NRC in future but no draft yet: BJP's Trivedi
text: BJP spokesperson Sudhanshu Trivedi has said that his party wants a nationwide National Register of Citizens (NRC) in future but there is no draft of the same as of now. "When NRC will happen, then raise objections; they will be heard," he added. Commenting on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, Trivedi said that it's for foreigners, not Indians.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Rupee closes at six-week low as crude prices hit $69.16 a barrel
text: The Indian rupee closed at a six-week low against the US dollar on Friday as global oil prices rose nearly $3/barrel due to heightened US-Iran tensions. The Indian currency fell 0.6% from Thursday's close to end at ₹71.81 a dollar. Crude prices hit $69.16/barrel, the highest since September 17, after a US air strike killed Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani.
author: Kiran Khatri

headlines: Iranian General, killed in US strike, should've been eliminated years ago: Trump
text: US President Donald Trump in a tweet said that Iranian General Qassem Soleimani, who was killed in a US air strike in Baghdad, should've been eliminated many years ago. "While Iran will never be able to properly admit it, Soleimani was both hated and feared within the country," he added. Meanwhile, Iran said it'll take revenge for this heinous crime.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Unite to protect secularism: Kerala CM writes to 11 CMs on CAA
text: Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan on Friday wrote to his counterparts from 11 states, urging them to unite against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). The letter appealed to the CMs to push for revocation of CAA passed by the Parliament last month. "The need of the hour is unity among all Indians wishing to protect democracy and secularism," said the letter.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: I have learned all my cricket from TV: Jasprit Bumrah
text: Team India fast bowler Jasprit Bumrah has said that he has learned all his cricket from TV. "Even now, I look at videos and I listen to feedback, and then I like to prepare on my own, the way I want to. I try to do the analysis myself because on the cricket ground, I will be alone," he added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: India asks Pakistan to take action after mob attacks Nankana Sahib Gurdwara
text: India on Friday asked Pakistan to take immediate action against the miscreants who attacked Nankana Sahib Gurdwara in Pakistan. "India strongly condemns these wanton acts of destruction and desecration of the holy place. We call upon the Government of Pakistan to take immediate steps to ensure...safety, security, and welfare of the members of the Sikh community," an MEA statement read.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Army ready for operations in Pakistan-occupied Kashmir if required: Army chief
text: Indian Army is ready to conduct larger-scale operations in Pakistan-occupied Kashmir "should that be the mandate," Indian Army chief General Manoj Mukund Naravane said in a recent interview. "We have our forces deployed all across the border, including J&K, and we have various plans, and if required, those plans can be put into action," he added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Peace most important: India after Iran warns of revenge on US for Soleimani death
text: After a US airstrike in Baghdad killed Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani, India advocated for restraint and said it's vital that the situation doesn't escalate further. "Peace, stability and security in this region (are) of utmost importance to India," the External Affairs Ministry said. Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei warned that a "harsh retaliation is waiting" for the US.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Punjab CM asks Pak PM to rescue those stranded at Gurdwara Nankana Sahib
text: Punjab CM Captain Amarinder Singh on Friday appealed to Pakistan PM Imran Khan to rescue devotees who are reportedly stranded at Gurdwara Nankana Sahib. "Appeal to Imran Khan to immediately intervene to ensure that the devotees stranded in Gurdwara Nankana Sahib are rescued," Singh tweeted. This came after reports emerged of stone pelting at the Sikh shrine.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Will make Yamuna so clean that people can take dip in it: Arvind Kejriwal
text: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal today said if re-elected, his government will make Yamuna river so clean that people of the national capital can take a dip in it. Addressing his fourth town hall meeting in East Delhi, Kejriwal said it'll be AAP government’s priority in next five years. "I'll take a dip along with you then," he told the audience.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: What helped Indian shrimp stocks rally up to 91% in three months?
text: Indian shrimp stocks Avanti Feeds, Apex Frozen Foods and The Waterbase have gained between 52% and 91% in the past three months. The demand for Indian shrimp in the US, its key market, has been steadily increasing after a decline in the beginning of 2019. Feed manufacturers also raised prices because of moderation in supply globally, according to ICICI Securities.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Ex-Nissan boss used our jets illegally in escape from Japan: Turkish firm
text: Turkish private jet operator MNG Jet on Friday said that ex-Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn used two of its planes illegally in his escape from Japan.  An employee admitted to falsifying lease records, it added. Turkish police have detained seven people, including four pilots, as part of an investigation into Ghosn's transit through Istanbul on his way to Lebanon.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: CAA unnecessary, will affect Hindus, Muslims both: Delhi CM Kejriwal
text: Speaking at an event in Delhi, Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal called the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) "unnecessary" legislation that will affect Hindus as well as Muslims. "Where will we accommodate two crore Hindus from Pakistan?" he asked. "The government must take care of its citizens first, and then care about people from other countries," he added.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: 445 Bangladeshis returned from India in 2 months: BGB chief
text: About 1,000 people were arrested in 2019 for illegal border crossings from India to Bangladesh, with 445 of them returning home in November and December, Border Guard Bangladesh (BGB) Director General said. The returnees are all Bangladeshi nationals who went to India illegally at different times and have nothing to do with India's Citizenship (Amendment) Act, he added.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Shami-Bumrah one of world's most exciting combinations: Gillespie
text: Comparing the pace attacks of India and Australia, Jason Gillespie said, "[What] I can say is that [Jasprit] Bumrah and [Mohammad] Shami is one of the most exciting bowling combinations in the world." "I particularly enjoy watching Australia and India's pace attacks. It's tough to go past [Mitchell] Starc, [Josh] Hazlewood and [Pat] Cummins in my opinion," Gillespie said.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Manav Thakkar jumps 9 places to become World No.1 in ITTF U-21
text: Manav Thakkar has jumped nine places to become the world number one paddler in the Under-21 men's category in the latest International Table Tennis Federation (ITTF) rankings. In December, 19-year-old Thakkar had claimed the ITTF Challenge Plus Benemax-Virgo North American Open men's singles title. Notably, he had also achieved world number one rank in the Under-18 category in 2018.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Tennis Australia to hold exhibition match for bushfire relief
text: Tennis Australia is set to organise a tennis exhibition match on January 15 in Melbourne in a bid to raise funds for bushfire relief and recovery efforts prior to the Australian Open 2020. Tennis Australia has already committed to making an AU$100 donation for every ace served at the ATP Cup in Brisbane, Perth and Sydney.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Dale Steyn to make international comeback after 10 months
text: South Africa pacer Dale Steyn has confirmed that he'll be part of the limited-overs series against England in February. "I'll be around for the ODIs...I don't know how much I'll play (the ODIs)…I'll be there for...the T20s," he said. Steyn, who played his last limited-overs game in March 2019, has played eight Tests, nine ODIs and two T20Is since 2016.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: TikTok parent secretly built a deepfakes maker: Report
text: TikTok's parent ByteDance has secretly worked on a technology that allows one to place their face in a video featuring someone else, TechCrunch reported. The unreleased feature was built using life-like deepfakes technology that the app's code refers to as Face Swap. Last year, Amazon, Facebook and Microsoft had teamed up to fight against deepfakes.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Govt approved 2,636 new charging stations in 62 cities: Javadekar
text: Union Minister Prakash Javadekar said the government has given its nod for setting up of 2,636 electric vehicle charging stations in 62 cities across 24 states and union territories under the FAME India scheme. He added the move would encourage original equipment manufacturers to launch new electric vehicle models. Out of 2,636 charging stations, 1,633 will be fast charging stations.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Bengaluru startups get most funding in 2019: Report
text: Startups in Bengaluru received the highest amount of funding in 2019 followed by ones in Delhi-NCR, YourStory reported. Bengaluru saw a total of $4.3 billion in funding with 273 deals while Delhi-NCR raised $1.3 billion with 73 deals. Paytm, Udaan and Delhivery were the top funded startups, beating Swiggy, Oyo and Byju’s, which were the top funded startups in 2018.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: FabHotels to raise ₹40 crore from Goldman Sachs, others
text: Budget hotel brand FabHotels is set to raise around ₹40 crore at a valuation of ₹856 crore from its existing investors. Goldman Sachs and Accel will invest about ₹14.2 crore each, while RB Investments will pump in around ₹10.6 crore, filings revealed. Post the investment, Goldman Sachs will be the biggest shareholder with a 25.64% stake.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Scientists find first evidence of tool use by seabirds
text: Three researchers have found evidence of tool use by puffins, the first-ever evidence of tool use by any seabird. The researchers were able to video-record a puffin grabbing a small stick and using it to scratch its underside. This also the first-ever observation of a bird of any kind using a tool to scratch itself.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Transgender DMK candidate elected from local body seat in Tamil Nadu
text: Ria, a 30-year-old transwoman, was on Thursday elected as union councillor in Namakkal district's Tiruchengode Panchayat Union. She contested on Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) ticket from the Karuveppampatti ward. She won the election by over 950 votes. "I was confident I will win and work for the welfare of people," she said.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Dirt in their mind: Shiv Sena's Sanjay Raut on Congress booklet row
text: Reacting to the Congress Seva Dal's booklet claim that Veer Savarkar had physical relationship with Nathuram Godse, Shiv Sena's Sanjay Raut said it shows the "dirt in their mind." "Savarkar was a great man and will remain a great man," he added. Earlier in the day, Swami Chakrapani of the Hindu Mahasabha said that he's heard "Rahul Gandhi is homosexual".
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: India's 2019 gold imports fall 12%, hit 3-year low: Reports
text: India's gold imports in 2019 fell by 12%, hitting the lowest level in three years as demand slowed down in the second half amid record-high prices, Reuters reported citing a government source. India reportedly imported 564 tonnes of gold in the first half and 267 tonnes in the second. Imports fell 2% to $31.22 billion in value terms, Reuters added.
author: Kiran Khatri

headlines: Australian PM cancels India visit due to bushfire crisis
text: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison has cancelled his four-day visit to India due to bushfires in several parts of his country. Morrison was scheduled to hold bilateral talks with PM Narendra Modi, who had invited him to visit India from January 13-16. At least 19 people have died in bushfires on the east coast of Australia since October.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: US strike against Soleimani reaction to Iran provocations: Germany
text: The US airstrike in Iraq that killed Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani was a reaction to series of military "provocations" by Iran, German government spokeswoman Ulrike Demmer said. "We are at a dangerous escalation point and what matters now is contributing with prudence and restraint to de-escalation," Demmer added. Iran said they "will take revenge on the US" for killing Soleimani.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Iraqis seen dancing in street after Soleimani's death: Pompeo
text: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Friday said that Iraqis celebrated the death of Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani by "dancing in the street". "Iraqis - Iraqis - dancing in the street for freedom; thankful that General Soleimani is no more," he said while sharing a video on Twitter. Soleimani was killed in US airstrike in Iraq's Baghdad on Friday.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: I don't clarify as*****s' statements: Paudwal on woman claiming to be her daughter
text: After a 45-year-old Kerala woman named Karmala claimed that Anuradha Paudwal is her mother, the veteran singer said, "I don’t clarify idiotic statements made by a******s! It is below my dignity." The 67-year-old singer's spokesperson said, "Karmala is a psycho. Karmala is mentioning Anuradha’s husband, but she doesn’t even know that he is no more."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Fan says he'll murder Siddhant for romancing Deepika; actor responds
text: During an interview, Siddhant Chaturvedi read out a comment of a fan who threatened to kill him for romancing Deepika Padukone in an upcoming film. "Ek baar kar lenge romance, fir khoon kar dena mera tu hi (Let me romance her once, then you can kill me)," Siddhant reacted. He'll be seen alongside Deepika and Ananya Panday in the film.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: BJP will not move back even an inch on the issue of CAA: Amit Shah
text: Talking about Citizenship (Amendment) Act during a rally, Home Minister Amit Shah said, "Even if all Opposition parties come together, BJP won't move back even an inch on issue of Citizenship (Amendment) Act." "You can spread as much misinformation as you want," Shah added. He further said if Rahul Gandhi has read law, he can come to discuss CAA.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Govt sets up dedicated desk for matters related to Ayodhya verdict
text: Central government has constituted a desk to take care of all matters related to the Supreme Court verdict on the Ram Janmabhoomi-Babri Masjid title case. Union Home Ministry said in an order that all the matters and court judgements related to the Ayodhya verdict will be handled by three officers. The desk is headed by Additional Secretary Gyanesh Kumar.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Many people believe Malinga taught me the yorker, but that's not true: Bumrah
text: Fast bowler Jasprit Bumrah has said that many people believe that Lasith Malinga taught him the yorker, but that is not true. "He didn't teach me anything on the field. The things I learnt from him are about the mind. How to handle different situations. How to not get angry. How to make a plan for a batsman," added Bumrah.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Why runs for leg-byes? You missed the ball: Mark Waugh calls for rule change
text: Former Australia batsman Mark Waugh has said that leg-byes should be done away with in cricket. "Why do [batsmen] get runs for leg-byes? You missed the ball," he added. "The idea of batting is to hit the ball. Whoever made this rule up was a pretty ordinary batsman I'd say back in heyday, back in the early 1900s," Waugh said.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: There are drawbacks in country's every hospital: Raj CM on Kota hospital deaths
text: When inquired about the lack of basic hygiene at Kota's JK Lon Hospital, where over 100 children died in December, Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot said, "You'll definitely find some drawbacks when you'll visit any hospital across the country." He added that whenever the government will be informed about any lack of facility inside a hospital, it'll work towards it.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Green carpet laid out for minister at Kota hospital where 100 kids died in Dec
text: A green carpet was laid out at Kota's JK Lon Hospital, where at least 100 children died in December 2019, ahead of Rajasthan Health Minister Raghu Sharma's visit on Friday. However, it was removed later reportedly after seeing the presence of media at the hospital. Meanwhile, state CM Ashok Gehlot said the matter of infants' death should not be politicised.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Andhra govt appoints 2 women officers for implementation of Disha Act
text: Andhra Pradesh government has appointed IAS officer Dr Kritika Shukla and IPS officer M Deepika to implement the Disha Act. The new designations will be in addition to their existing posts. The Act enables speedy investigation in cases of sexual crimes against women and trial of the accused with stringent punishment within 21 working days.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Protest at Kota's JK Lon Hospital over infant deaths, many detained
text: A protest broke out on Friday outside JK Lon Hospital in Kota, Rajasthan, where at least 100 infants have died. Several demonstrators were detained as a precautionary measure to maintain law and order in the area, said the police. At least 91 infants had died at the government hospital in the month of December 2019 alone.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Bangladesh-bound 1,68,500 yaba tablets worth over ₹8.92 crore seized in Tripura
text: A joint operation of Border Security Force (BSF) and Directorate of Revenue Intelligence (DRI) officials recovered a cache of 1,68,500 yaba tablets worth over ₹8.92 crore from Matinagar in Tripura. The drug haul is the largest-ever contraband seizure in Tripura. "It is likely these items were about to be smuggled into Bangladesh," a BSF official said.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: What are the features of Delhi's first-ever smog tower?
text: Delhi's first-ever smog tower, installed at Lajpat Nagar central market, is 20-foot tall and will purify the air within a circumference of almost 500 metres to 750 metres. It'll aim at treating 2,50,000 to 6,00,000 cubic metre air per day and release fresh air in return. A machine fixed inside the tower will remove nearly 80% of the particulate matter.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: 480 million animals may have been killed in Australia wildfires
text: An estimated 480 million animals in Australia's New South Wales state may have been killed in wildfires since September, according to research by the University of Sydney. Many of the affected mammals, birds and reptiles would've been directly killed by the fires or indirectly through loss of habitat, it added. Around 12 million acres have been burned by the fires.n
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: India's electricity supply declines for fifth straight month in December
text: India's electricity supply fell for the fifth straight month in December, potentially reflecting a weakening industrial activity amid an overall economic slowdown. Power supply fell 1.1% from last year to 101.92 billion units in December, provisional government data showed. Electricity supply fell 4.2% in November and 12.8% in October, according to the Central Electricity Authority (CEA).
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Liverpool beat Sheffield United 2-0 to extend unbeaten run
text: Liverpool's Mohamed Salah scored a goal and set up the other as Liverpool extended their unbeaten Premier League run to a full year with a 2-0 victory over Sheffield United to restore its 13-point lead. Liverpool hasn't lost a league game in 364 days since a defeat to Manchester City last year. Leicester City are in second place.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Hopeful of best-ever Olympics in Tokyo: Pullela Gopichand
text: National badminton coach Pullela Gopichand has said that he's hoping for the best-ever Olympic outing in Tokyo. "We've had some good performances in last couple of Olympics. This time…with some good preparations, we can come back with better performances," he added. World number six PV Sindhu, who won silver in 2016 Rio Olympics, is currently the women's singles world champion.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Balotelli involved in car crash into bakery after New Year's party
text: Italian footballer Mario Balotelli was involved in a car crash at 5 am while returning home from New Year's celebrations at a nightclub in the Italian city of Brescia. Balotelli's new Fiat 500 Abarth crashed into a gate of a bakery near his home after his friend, who was driving, made a mistake and clipped the kerb.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Djokovic, Nadal call for merger of ATP Cup, Davis Cup Finals
text: Speaking about tennis' team events, ATP Cup and Davis Cup, Novak Djokovic said, "We need to have one Super World Cup event, whatever you want to call it." Rafael Nadal said, "For me personally that's not the ideal situation for our sport, but that's how it works today and I'm very excited that we can change that in the future."
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Wrestler Jitender wins 74kg trials, may advance to Olympic Qualifiers
text: Wrestler Jitender Kumar on Friday outclassed Amit Dhankar in the 74kg trials to qualify for the upcoming Ranking Series, Asian Championship and Olympic Qualifiers. However, fresh trials for the Olympic Qualifiers could be held "if the performances of the wrestlers are not satisfactory", wrestling body president had said. Notably, Olympic medallist Sushil Kumar missed the trials due to an injury.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: I'm meaner than before: Zlatan on return to AC Milan
text: Speaking about rejoining AC Milan after seven years for a six-month stint, Swede striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic said, "I'm meaner than before." "The last time I left AC Milan, it was without my approval but the situation was what it was... [The] important thing is that I am here now," Zlatan said about his return.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: I don't have too many games left to play for India: Chhetri
text: Speaking about long-term goals, Indian football team's captain Sunil Chhetri said, "I understand that I don't have many games left to play for my country... Hence, personally I want to take one game at a time." The 35-year-old, who is the second-highest goal-scorer in international football after Cristiano Ronaldo, said he has to work hard to maintain his fitness levels.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: One of world's largest freshwater fish species declared extinct
text: The Chinese paddlefish, one of the world's biggest freshwater fish species, growing up to 7 metres long, has been declared extinct by scientists. The Chinese paddlefish is believed to have vanished between 2005 and 2010, with its last confirmed sighting coming in 2003. The paddlefish was part of over 4,000 aquatic species found in China's Yangtze river system.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Measles may have emerged when large cities rose: Study
text: After the analysis of measles' phylogenetic tree generated from studying the preserved lungs of a girl who died in 1912, researchers have stated the disease may have emerged when large cities rose around 345 BC. Only three genomes from measles viruses occurring before 1990 are known, with the oldest one from 1954 being the origin of the first measles vaccine.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Proposal to create Air Defence Command by June 30: CDS Rawat
text: Chief of Defence Staff (CDS) General Bipin Rawat on Wednesday held a meeting with the three service chiefs and directed that a proposal to create Air Defence Command be prepared by June 30 in order to enhance security of India's skies. An Air Defence Command will reportedly include air defence resources of all the three services.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: 5 lakh UP primary teachers to go on mass leave on Jan 21
text: Teachers of the Uttar Pradesh government-run primary and upper primary schools will go on a mass leave on January 21 demanding better infrastructure, manpower and pension. A common leave application addressed to the Basic Shiksha Adhikari has been forwarded by the teacher's union for around five lakh teachers of the state. Earlier, they had conducted a demonstration on November 21.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Weinstein's trial in sexual harassment cases to begin on Jan 6
text: A jury trial in New York state court will begin on Monday against Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein who has been accused of sexual harassment. The 67-year-old is accused of raping an unidentified woman in a New York hotel room in 2013 and of sexually assaulting another woman named Mimi Haleyi in his apartment in 2006. Weinstein has pleaded not guilty.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Pakistan govt introduces bill to extend Army chief's tenure
text: Pakistan's government on Friday introduced legislation in the Parliament to extend the tenure of its Army chief. The legislation will validate the three-year extension given to Army Chief General Qamar Javed Bajwa approved in August last year. Pakistan's Supreme Court had later struck down the extension, ordering the Imran Khan government and Army to produce legal provisions for the extension.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Killed Iranian commander had told Trump 'You'll start war but we'll end it'
text: Iranian General Qassem Soleimani had told US President Donald Trump during a rally in 2018, "You'll start the war but we'll end it." "I'm telling you Mr Trump the gambler, I'm telling you, know that we're close to you in that place you don't think we are," he had said. Soleimani was killed in a US air strike on Friday.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Iran names Esmail Qaani as new chief of Quds Force after Soleimani's killing
text: Iran has appointed Esmail Qaani to lead Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps' Quds Force after its previous commander, Major General Qassem Soleimani, was killed in a US air strike on Friday. Qaani served as Soleimani's second-in-command. The Quds Force's program of action "will stay exactly the same" as it was under Soleimani, Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei said.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: It's my own money: Deepika as journo says Ranveer invested his money in Chhapaak
text: When a journalist said Ranveer Singh's money is also invested in Chhapaak as Deepika Padukone is the film's producer, the actress replied, "Excuse me! Who told you this? This is my own money." A video of the incident shows everyone on the stage applauding Deepika for her response, while the audience whistled and clapped.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Steve Smith takes 39 deliveries to get off the mark, bowler pats his back
text: Australia batsman Steve Smith took 39 deliveries and 45 minutes to get off the mark during the first innings of third Test against New Zealand on Friday. As soon as the 30-year-old scored the first run, the crowd gave him an applause after which Smith raised his glove and got a pat on the back from fast bowler Neil Wagner.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Grandson seeks ban on booklet that claims Veer Savarkar was homosexual
text: Veer Savarkar's grandson Ranjit Savarkar on Friday urged MP government to ban Congress' booklet that says that the freedom fighter was homosexual. The booklet claimed that Savarkar had physical relations with Mahatma Gandhi's assassin Nathuram Godse. "Government must take action against...Congress Seva Dal (who distributed the booklet) and should register a criminal case against them," he said.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Can give Italian translation of CAA to Rahul Gandhi: Amit Shah
text: Speaking at Abhinandan Samaroh in Rajasthan's Jodhpur, Home Minister Amit Shah threw a challenge to Rahul Gandhi that if he has read the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, "he can come anywhere for a debate". "If not...I'll translate it to Italian...send it you...you can read it," Shah added. "Even if all parties come together, BJP will not move back," he further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Woman tries to touch PM Modi's feet, he also bends to touch her feet
text: While PM Narendra Modi distributed awards at a ceremony in Karnataka, a woman tried to touch his feet after receiving her award. A video shows PM Modi also bending to touch the woman's feet and then folding his hands together in a respectful greeting towards her. Reacting to this, Union Minister Harsh Vardhan said, "Respect for every mother and daughter!"
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Staff asked us to check oxygen levels: Father of baby who died at Kota hospital
text: Father of a five-month-old boy, who died at JK Lon Hospital in Kota in December, said, "Hospital staff would tell us to check whether the oxygen pipes were running. How are we supposed to know that?" "I got a child after so many prayers, I've lost him now," the child's mother said. They also complained that the hospital wasn't clean.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Oil prices jump 4.4% after US kills top Iranian commander, petrol rates may rise
text: Brent crude oil, the global benchmark, rose 4.4% on Friday to $69.16 a barrel after an airstrike ordered by US President Donald Trump killed Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani, head of the elite Quds Force. Petrol and diesel rates in India may rise following the jump in crude oil price. Notably, India imports about 85% of its crude oil requirements.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Missed ₹2.35 crore payment to SBI because govt delayed rent: Peninsula Land
text: Mumbai-based Peninsula Land said it couldn't pay ₹2.35 crore to SBI on time because the Income Tax Department and GST Department, which had leased office space from Peninsula, were delaying rent payments. The loan used rent receipts as collateral, a facility where rent goes straight to the bank. The developer said it used its own resources to pay the loan.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Ratan Tata moves SC against order holding him guilty of oppressive acts
text: Tata Sons Chairman Emeritus Ratan Tata moved the Supreme Court on Friday challenging the NCLAT order which found him guilty of taking steps that were oppressive and prejudicial to the interests of minority shareholder Cyrus Mistry. The appellate tribunal has "held me guilty without any factual or legal foundation", Tata's plea said, adding its findings "are wrong and erroneous".
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Molestation case filed against Tanushree Dutta's lawyer
text: Tanushree Dutta's lawyer Nitin Satpute has been accused of molestation by a fellow advocate. A case has been registered against him in Mumbai's Kherwadi police station. Nitin is the same man who has been representing Tanushree in her case against Nana Patekar. She had accused Nana of sexually harassing her on the sets of their 2009 film, 'Horn 'OK' Pleassss'.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Jennifer, Charlize attend Palm Springs International Film Festival
text: Jennifer Lopez and Charlize Theron were among the celebrities who attended the 2020 Palm Springs International Film Festival Awards Gala on Thursday night in California. Jennifer opted for a floral strapless gown and accessorised her look with some jewellery and a pink handbag. Meanwhile, Charlize wore a tweed belted pencil dress from Christian Dior and paired it with black heels.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: It's not fair to involve Faiz in matters of 'mazhab': Gulzar
text: Veteran lyricist Gulzar said in an interview that it's not fair to involve Urdu poet Faiz Ahmed Faiz in matters of "mazhab" (religion). "It's not right to show his work in wrong context," he added. This comes after IIT Kanpur set up a panel to inquire into complaint against the recitation of Faiz's poem 'Hum Dekhenge' at an anti-CAA protest.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Varun, Janhvi and Bhumi to star in comic thriller 'Mr Lele': Reports
text: Varun Dhawan, Janhvi Kapoor and Bhumi Pednekar will reportedly feature in an upcoming comedy-thriller film 'Mr Lele'. "Janhvi and Varun haven't worked together, so the makers...were keen to get her on board," reports added. The film, which will be directed by Shashank Khaitan, will revolve around the three protagonists, who are involved in a mysterious incident, reports further said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: IIT-Bombay's Science and Technology festival Techfest commences today
text: Techfest, IIT-Bombay's Science & Technology festival, is hosting a lineup of prominent speakers, including Former PM of Bhutan, Vidya Balan, B.S. Dhanoa, Zaheer Khan and two Nobel Laureates. The fest will also showcase advanced technologies like Air Taxi, VR Time Machine, Einstein Robot and World's first actor-performer robot. Entry is free and open to all from 8am–5pm from 3rd–5th January. n
author: Esha Kohli

headlines: Are you Pakistan's ambassador: Mamata asks PM Modi
text: Addressing a rally against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in Siliguri, West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee asked PM Modi whether he's an "ambassador of Pakistan". "Why do you regularly compare our nation with Pakistan?" she further asked. "If someone says give me a job and I have no work, the Prime Minister says go to Pakistan," alleged Mamata.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: States passing resolution against CAA misleading people: Nadda
text: BJP National Working President JP Nadda said that the states passing resolutions against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) are misleading people and Citizenship is a subject under the Central government. Speaking at 'CAA Janjagaran Sammelan' organized by the BJP, he said, "You can tell facts to the Congress, but it is not in a position to understand the truth."
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Will reach out to 3 crore families for CAA awareness: Piyush Goyal
text: Union Minister Piyush Goyal on Friday attended a pro-CAA event in Mumbai, where he said, "In the next 10 days, we will reach (out) to three crore families to spread awareness about CAA." He also criticised opposition parties saying, "The opposition is confused or maybe they are doing all this with proper planning."
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Wayne Rooney makes Derby County debut with 2-1 win over Barnsley
text: Former England captain Wayne Rooney on Thursday made his debut for Derby County in England's second-tier League Championship match against Barnsley. England's all-time leading goal-scorer played the full match and helped in both goals in the 2-1 victory over Barnsley. Rooney returned to English football last summer after playing for the Major League Soccer side DC United.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Mozilla Firefox to let all users delete their collected data
text: Mozilla has announced it will let all Firefox users delete their data collected by the company in the browser's next version, releasing on January 7. Mozilla expanded the change worldwide after complying with the new US California Consumer Privacy Act which lets residents know what personal data tech companies collect, request its deletion and stop them from selling the data.
author: Dharna

headlines: Indians sent 20 billion WhatsApp messages on New Year's Eve
text: Over 20 billion WhatsApp messages were sent by Indians out of the record-breaking 100 billion private messages exchanged worldwide on the platform on New Year's Eve. WhatsApp said December 31, 2019, saw the highest number of messages exchanged worldwide than any other day in its 10-year history. Out of the 100 billion messages sent, over 12 billion were picture messages.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: We have heard Rahul Gandhi is homosexual: Swami Chakrapani
text: Reacting to the All India Congress Seva Dal's booklet claim that Vinayak Damodar Savarkar had "physical relations" with Mahatma Gandhi's assassin Nathuram Godse, Swami Chakrapani of Akhil Bharatiya Hindu Mahasabha called the allegations as "ridiculous". "Similarly we have also heard that Rahul Gandhi is homosexual," he added. Congress Seva Dal chief had said that the claim was evidence-based.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Anti-CAA protests mostly political, some people misguided: Shah
text: Union Home Minister Amit Shah on Thursday said that the protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) are "mostly political". "Some people are also misguided but we are trying to convince them," he added. Shah also said the Census 2021 and the National Population Register (NPR) have nothing to do with the National Register of Citizens (NRC).
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: UAE extends $200 million aid to Pakistan
text: The UAE has extended a $200 million aid to Pakistan for the development of small and medium-sized enterprises in the country. This comes after the Abu Dhabi Crown Prince Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan concluded his visit to Pakistan on Thursday. In 2018, the UAE had announced a $3 billion bailout package for Pakistan to ease its balance-of-payment crisis.
author: Dharna

headlines: Will avenge death of commander killed in US air strike: Iran President
text: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani has said Iran and free nations of the region "will take revenge on the US" for killing Major-General Qassem Soleimani. Iran is now more determined to "resist America's bullying and defend its Islamic values", Rouhani added. His statement came after Soleimani and a top Iraqi militia commander were killed in a US air strike in Baghdad.
author: Kiran Khatri

headlines: Iranian commander's killing will increase Middle East tensions: Russia
text: The Russian Foreign Ministry has said the killing of Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani by the US will increase tensions in the Middle East. The head of Iran's Quds force was killed at the Baghdad International Airport in an air strike on Friday. The US strike also killed Iraqi militia commander Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis.
author: Kiran Khatri

headlines: A harsh retaliation is waiting for US: Iran Supreme Leader on commander's death
text: Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has warned that a "harsh retaliation is waiting" for the US following the death of Major-General Qassem Soleimani in a US air strike in Baghdad. Khamenei called Soleimani "the international face of resistance". He also declared three days of public mourning over Soleimani's death.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: US tells its citizens in Iraq to leave immediately over air strike
text: Following the air strike that killed top Iranian and Iraqi commanders, the US embassy in Baghdad has urged American citizens in Iraq to "depart immediately". "US citizens should depart via airline while possible, and failing that, to other countries via land," it said. "All public consular operations are suspended until further notice," it added.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: US now effectively at war with Iran: US' former envoy for anti-ISIS coalition
text: Former US Special Presidential Envoy for the Global Coalition to Counter ISIS, Brett McGurk, has said that the US is now effectively at war with Iran. "The news out of Iraq is a measure of justice done but with unknowable consequences," he added. His remarks follow the death of Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani in a US air strike in Baghdad.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: World War III trends on Twitter after US air strike that killed top Iran commander
text: World War III has been trending on Twitter following the US air strike that killed Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani at Baghdad International Airport. "North Korea seeing Iran starting World War III with the US before they do," a Twitter user wrote. "I think I'm laughing uncontrollably at these World War III jokes because I'm genuinely a lil scared," another wrote.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Who was Qassem Soleimani, the Iranian General killed in US air strike?
text: General Qassem Soleimani, who was killed in a US air strike in Baghdad on Friday, was head of Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps' Quds Force. Soleimani, who was born to a poor farming family in 1957, was sometimes discussed as future president. He helped armed groups defeat ISIS, and was instrumental in the spread of Iranian influence in Middle East.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Pics of US air strike that killed top Iranian, Iraqi commanders surface online
text: Pictures of the US air strike that killed Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani and Iraqi militia commander Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis at the Baghdad International Airport have surfaced online. The pictures were released by Reuters in a video. The US Defence Department said, "The US military has taken decisive defensive action to protect US personnel abroad by killing Soleimani."
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: I really like her with Hardik: Nataša's ex Aly who was her partner in Nach Baliye
text: After cricketer Hardik Pandya got engaged to Mumbai-based Serbian actress Nataša Stanković, her ex-boyfriend and Nach Baliye 9 partner Aly Goni said, "I am really really happy for her." "I really liked them both together. I have seen them together and they are adorable. I am so ecstatic that they are getting married," the actor added.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Varun compared to Ranveer for wearing skirt on magazine cover, shares meme
text: Actor Varun Dhawan was trolled and compared with Ranveer Singh for wearing a skirt on the cover of GQ magazine's January issue. Varun shared one of the memes on his Instagram stories and wrote, "They made my dad so thin love it." The meme showed photoshopped picture of Varun's father David Dhawan pleading Ranveer to stay away from his son.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: When did I say NRC has been put in cold storage: Amit Shah
text: Home Minister Amit Shah said in an interview that "right now Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) has been brought, so discussions should be on the same". On being asked if National Register of Citizens (NRC) has been put in cold storage, Shah added, "When did I say that?" This comes after he claimed that there is no talk of NRC now.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Stanford builds particle accelerator smaller than human hair's width
text: Scientists at Stanford and SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory created a silicon chip that can accelerate electrons. The electrons are accelerated using an infrared laser to deliver, in less than a human hair's width, the sort of energy boost that takes microwaves many feet, said Stanford. Notably, the world's most powerful accelerator, The Large Hadron Collider, is about 27 kilometres long.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Footage shows Ghosn leaving house alone before fleeing Japan: Report
text: Surveillance footage from a security camera at former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn's house in Tokyo showed him leaving the house alone before he fled to Lebanon, state-owned agency NHK said. Police suspect that Ghosn left his home to meet someone before reaching the airport. Ghosn reportedly held two French passports, of which only one was surrendered under his bail conditions.
author: Dharna

headlines: Swiggy hikes commissions, delivery fee to cut losses: Report
text: Swiggy is hiking the commissions it earns from restaurants and the delivery fee levied on customers in high-demand regions in order to cut down losses, the Economic Times reported. Swiggy reportedly hiked commissions to 18-23% of the total order value from 12-18% earlier, under contract renewals. Denying any 'unusual' hikes, Swiggy said commissions were worked upon at individual restaurant level.
author: Dharna

headlines: NASA astronaut's blood clot in space gets treated by doctor on Earth
text: University of North Carolina doctor Stephan Moll helped treat a blood clot in zero gravity, which an unnamed NASA astronaut developed aboard the International Space Station two months into a six-month mission. "Knowing there are no emergency rooms in space, we had to weigh our options very carefully," Moll said. The clot was ultimately treated with blood thinners.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Pune astronomers find hydrogen ring around galaxy 260mn light-yrs away
text: Pune's NCRA astronomers discovered a galaxy with a 'mysterious', starless and neutral ring of hydrogen gas around it, about 260 million light-years away from Earth. The ring was found to be much bigger than the galaxy, with a diameter four times bigger than that of Milky Way. NCRA's Omkar Bait, Yogesh Wadadekar and five others were part of the discovery.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: 16-yr-old girl out on New Year's Eve gangraped in Gurugram's Aravalli hills
text: A 16-year-old girl, who had gone to the Aravalli mountain range in Gurugram with her male friend on New Year's Eve, was allegedly abducted by two men and gangraped. The girl and her friend were reportedly taking selfies at a picnic spot, when the two accused approached them. They were rescued by locals who heard their cries for help.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Literally asking for work, people think I'm arrogant: Actress Sumona
text: Actress Sumona Chakravarti, known for appearing on 'The Kapil Sharma Show', has revealed that she's "literally asking for work" from people. "My PR (Public Relations) skills definitely aren't up to the mark. I realised that quite late...now, I'm...meeting people, even calling and messaging them," she added. "People think I'm arrogant, will ask for heavy remuneration...that's not true," she said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Deepika to spend 34th b'day at cafe run by acid attack survivors: Reports
text: Deepika Padukone, who'll be seen portraying an acid attack survivor in her upcoming film 'Chhapaak', will reportedly celebrate her 34th birthday on January 5 at a Lucknow cafe run by acid attack survivors. Besides the eatery's staff, survivors from neighbouring cities will also be a part of the celebrations, reports added. 'Chhapaak', directed by Meghna Gulzar, also features Vikrant Massey.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Bhumi to have special appearance in 'Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan'
text: Bhumi Pednekar will have a special appearance in the sequel of her 2017 film 'Shubh Mangal Saavdhan'. The sequel, 'Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan', will be the fourth collaboration between Bhumi and Ayushmann Khurrana after 'Dum Laga Ke Haisha', 'Shubh Mangal Saavdhan' and 'Bala'. Directed by Hitesh Kewalya, it's a story of a conservative family struggling to accept their son's homosexuality.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Barcelona bans gasoline-powered cars registered before 2000
text: The Spanish city of Barcelona has restricted the use of gasoline-powered cars registered in Spain before 2000 and diesel-powered cars registered before 2006. The cars falling under the rule are banned from most city streets on weekdays between 7:00 am and 8:00 pm and face a fine of at least 100 euros ($112) on violation of the rule.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Shubman Gill refuses to walk after being given out, Delhi bowlers refuse to bowl
text: Punjab opener Shubman Gill refused to walk after being declared caught behind out by the on-field umpire. After Shubman didn't move from his place, the on-field umpires overturned the decision. Delhi bowlers then refused to bowl and started to leave the field. Delhi Ranji captain Nitish Rana alleged Shubman abused the umpire. The match was restarted after match referee intervened.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Family orders cake for 11-year-old from delivery app, finds shop doesn't exist
text: A family, which ordered a cake for an 11-year-old from a shop through a food delivery platform, found out the shop doesn't exist. After 30 minutes of ordering, the Noida family was informed by an executive that he couldn't locate the shop despite map directions. Another senior executive allegedly said at least four-five riders tried and failed to find it.
author: Dharna

headlines: ₹12,000 crore disbursed to 6 crore farmers under PM-Kisan scheme
text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday released ₹12,000 crore to six crore farmers across the country under the flagship PM-Kisan scheme. This was the third instalment in the scheme, for which ₹75,000 crore had been set aside. Under PM-Kisan, income support of ₹6,000 per year is provided to farmer families in instalments of ₹2,000 every four months.
author: Dharna

headlines: Cancer patient jumps in front of metro, saved after driver applies brakes
text: A 52-year-old Delhi man, suffering from throat cancer, attempted suicide by jumping in front of an approaching train at East Delhi's Jhilmil Metro Station on Friday. However, the driver applied the brakes on time and the train stopped before hitting him. "He is suffering from throat cancer for the past six years," the Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP) (Metro) said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Centre rejects Maha, Kerala's proposed tableau for Republic Day parade
text: After Uttarakhand, West Bengal and Bihar, Centre has rejected Maharashtra and Kerala's proposed tableau for the Republic Day parade on January 26. NCP founder Sharad Pawar's daughter Supriya Sule said, "BJP government is...treating non-BJP ruled states with discriminatory behaviour." A total of 56 tableaux proposals were received out of which 22 were shortlisted.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Way we celebrated science will always be in memory: PM on Chandrayaan-2
text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, while addressing the Indian Science Congress in Bengaluru, said he had visited the city in September 2019 when everyone's "eyes were on Chandrayaan-2". "The way in which we celebrated science...always be [in] my memory," he added. "When we start 2020 with positivity...of...technology-driven development, we take one more step in fulfilling our dream," PM further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Punjab's SDG index rank low due to health freaks' restricted diet: Minister
text: After Punjab slipped by two points in Niti Aayog's Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) India Index 2019, state Health Minister Balbir Singh Sidhu blamed the same on "health freaks' restricted diet". "I don't think there is anyone in Punjab who sleeps without having food," he said. "Anyone who does is probably doing it to reduce weight," he added.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Sensex falls 160 points as oil prices surge after US air strike
text: Indian equity benchmark Sensex was down by nearly 160 points on early Friday at 41,468 as crude oil prices surged globally. The surge follows an air strike carried out by the US and authorised by President Donald Trump killing top Iranian and Iraqi commanders at Baghdad International Airport. The broader Nifty 50 index was trading 40 points lower at 12,240.
author: Dharna

headlines: Killed top Iranian commander was planning to attack American diplomats: US
text: Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani, who was killed in a US air strike at Baghdad International Airport, was actively developing plans to attack American diplomats and service members in Iraq and throughout the region, the US has said. "We will continue to take all necessary action to protect our people and interests wherever they are around the world," the US added.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Trump tweets US flag after death of top Iranian and Iraqi commanders
text: US President Donald Trump tweeted the US flag following the death of Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani and Iraqi militia commander Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis in an air strike at the Baghdad International Airport. Meanwhile, the Pentagon said, "Soleimani had orchestrated attacks on coalition bases in Iraq, culminating in the death and wounding of additional American and Iraqi personnel."
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: US responsible for consequences of its rogue adventurism: Iran
text: Following the death of Major-General Qassem Soleimani in a US air strike, Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif said, "The US' act of international terrorism, targeting & assassinating Soleimani is extremely dangerous & a foolish escalation." "The US bears responsibility for all consequences of its rogue adventurism," he added. Zarif described Soleimani as "most effective force fighting ISIS".
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: I love whom Athiya is dating, he fits into family like a glove: Suniel Shetty
text: Actor Suniel Shetty has said that he and his wife Mana love whom their daughter Athiya and son Ahan are dating. "We're blessed that they are from brilliant families and so humble and fit into the family like gloves," he added. Ahan is said to be dating Tania Shroff, while there are rumours Athiya is dating cricketer KL Rahul.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: UP Police send notice to man dead for 6 years over anti-CAA stir
text: Following violent anti-CAA protests in Uttar Pradesh's Firozabad, police have sent out notices to 200 people as a precautionary measure. The list of people who were sent the notices includes a 94-year-old man, who is said to have died six years ago. It also includes the name of a 93-year-old man, who is bedridden.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Apple shares rise to new record, cross $300 for the first time ever
text: Shares of technology giant Apple reached a new record high, rising 2.3% to close at a record $300.35 apiece. The Nasdaq-listed iPhone maker crossed the $300-mark for the first time on a split-adjusted basis, Bloomberg noted. Notably, Apple had cut its sales forecast during this same period last year for the first time in almost two decades.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Salesforce CEO reveals why he gifted 'AppStore.com' URL to Steve Jobs
text: Salesforce's billionaire Co-founder and CEO Marc Benioff, in his book Trailblazer, revealed that he'd registered 'AppStore.com' domain on Apple Co-founder Steve Jobs' advice in 2003 to develop an 'application ecosystem'. However, Benioff switched to the name AppExchange and AppStore.com sat dormant until 2008. When Jobs revealed Apple's 'App Store' in 2008, Benioff gifted the URL to his mentor.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Google's senior leaders bullied young women, made them cry: Ex-exec
text: Senior colleagues at Google bullied and screamed at young women working at the firm, causing them to cry at their desks, said its former International Relations Head. Ross LaJeunesse, who handled policy-related roles, further flagged racist stereotyping at Google, claiming his boss at a meeting, said, "You Asians come to the microphone too. I know you don't like asking questions."
author: Dharna

headlines: After heavy criticism, SpaceX to test dimming Starlink satellites
text: Elon Musk-led aerospace startup SpaceX will test a new a non-reflective coating on the bottom of one among the 60 Starlink constellation satellites it aims to launch on Friday. This came after the startup's internet-beaming constellation was heavily criticised by astronomers for being "too bright" and hindering scientific research. The satellites have also been mistaken for 'alien spacecraft'.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Physicist designs engine to 'move' entire Solar System to save Earth
text: Illinois State University physicist designed a 'stellar engine' that could theoretically 'move' Sun, which would then move the entire Solar System as it's bound by gravitational force. The design was created to 'save' Earth from potential space disasters like stellar explosions or asteroid catastrophes. The physicist said his design could move the sun 50 light-years in just one million years.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Astronaut shares pic of 'decade's first Moonrise' as seen from space
text: NASA's record-breaking astronaut Christina Koch tweeted an image of Moon and said, "First moonrise seen from the [International Space Station] in the decade we go back." Notably, astronauts aboard the space lab had celebrated New Year at 5:30 AM as per Indian Standard Time (IST). Koch recently broke the record for the longest spaceflight by a woman.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: My motto for young scientists is 'innovate, patent, produce, prosper': PM
text: Addressing the 107th session of Indian Science Congress in Bengaluru, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said that his motto for young scientists has been "innovate, patent, produce and prosper". "Our growth story depends on its success in the science and tech sector," he added. "Our schemes...created more technology business incubators in...last 5 years than in...previous 50 years," PM further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Watchman throws metal flute at judge in Mumbai court, shouts 'Jai Shri Krishna'
text: A 60-year-old watchman has been arrested in Mumbai after he threw a metal flute at a judge inside a courtroom. The court was scheduled to hear his brother's murder case later in the day, when he entered the room wearing an advocate's attire. He said in the courtroom that it was Janmashtami, shouted 'Jai Shri Krishna' before throwing the flute.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Delhi gets its first ₹7 lakh 20-foot-tall 'smog tower' to purify air
text: The first 20-foot-tall 'smog tower' in Delhi has been installed in Lajpat Nagar market to purify the air in the area amid high pollution levels in the city. The equipment, which is for ₹7 lakh, has been installed by the market's traders association with MP Gautam Gambhir's help. The purifier aims at treating 2,50,000-6,00,000 cubic metre air per day.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Each time a man was rescued, I thought it was my son: Deceased firefighter's dad
text: Father of 28-year-old firefighter Amit Balyan, who died after a burning factory collapsed during the rescue operation in Delhi, said, "Each time they pulled out a man from the building, I thought it was my son." The man stayed outside the factory for hours. "When they finally found him...he was unconscious, with blood on his head and nose," he said.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Bushfire victims call Australian PM 'idiot', tell him to 'piss off' in viral video
text: A video showing bushfire victims calling Australian PM Scott Morrison an "idiot" and telling him to "piss off" has gone viral. "You're never getting any votes down here buddy...You are out son. You are out," a man can be heard telling Morrison. He was on a visit to Bega Valley township of Cobargo, which was engulfed by flames on Tuesday.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Title of Rajkummar, Janhvi's 'Roohi Afza' changed to 'Roohi Afzana'
text: The title of Rajkummar Rao and Janhvi Kapoor's horror-comedy film 'Roohi Afza' has been changed to 'Roohi Afzana'. This is the second time that the title of the film has been changed, which was first titled 'Rooh Afza'. Talking about her character in the film, Janhvi had said, "It's one of...most exciting, challenging, complicated...and emotionally taxing roles...I've had...privilege of doing."
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: It does happen to men as well: Sunny Leone on #MeToo
text: Sunny Leone, while talking about the #MeToo movement, said men also face sexual harassment, adding, "It's just not recognised because 'he's guy what's...big deal'." She further said things will change if both men and women speak up about facing sexual harassment at their workplace. "Especially when...things have come out through social media...I've to assume...people are thinking twice," she said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: 'War' would be my film of the year 2019: Filmmaker Sujoy Ghosh
text: Filmmaker Sujoy Ghosh took to Twitter to reveal a list of films he liked in 2019 and wrote, "Damn difficult - so many good films - Uri, Bala...Dream Girl, Sonchiriya...list is never-ending." "But...the film I enjoyed the most in...cinemas and had...rocking good time is WAR. That'd be my film of the year and of course....all hail Hrithik Roshan," he added.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Dostana became classic, hope we match that standard: Janhvi on Dostana 2
text: Talking about the second instalment of the 'Dostana' franchise, Janhvi Kapoor said that the story, characters and the sets of the film are completely different from its first part.
