Bengaluru-based Swiggy was founded in 2014.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Astronaut shares pics of the decade's last solar eclipse from space
text: NASA astronaut Jessica Meir tweeted pictures of the decade's last solar eclipse from the International Space Station (ISS). "We saw the shadow of Moon on Earth below, just above the horizon (central grey area above horizon)," wrote Meir. An annular solar eclipse occurs when Moon covers Sun's centre, leaving Sun's outer edges to form a 'ring of fire' around Moon.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Norwegian tourist who attended anti-CAA protest in Kerala told to leave India
text: A 74-year-old Norwegian tourist who attended a protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act in Kerala has said she's been told to "leave India at once or face legal actions". "The officer from Bureau of Immigration is not leaving me before he can see that I've a flight ticket," she added. "A friend fixing a flight ticket to Dubai," she further said.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Man kills ex-girlfriend, leaves fake suicide note near her body accusing husband
text: A man has been arrested for allegedly killing his former girlfriend and making it look like a suicide in Maharashtra. The 20-year-old victim's body was found near railway tracks and the accused was nabbed with the help of CCTV footage. Police said he left a note and messaged victim's father using her phone, falsely accusing her husband of abetting suicide.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Ex-ISRO scientist, falsely accused of selling secrets to Pak, to get ₹1.3 crore
text: The Kerala government has approved a recommendation that former ISRO scientist Nambi Narayanan be paid ₹1.3 crore as compensation for his unlawful arrest and torture while in police custody. In 1994, Narayanan was accused of selling vital secrets associated with Indian space technology to Pakistan. He was acquitted by the Supreme Court in 1998 and awarded ₹50-lakh compensation in 2018.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Arundhati Roy clarifies her remarks on NPR, asks 'is it ok for the PM to lie'
text: Defending her remarks on National Population Register (NPR), author Arundhati Roy asked, "Is it ok for PM...to lie to us but a criminal offence...for us people to have a laugh?" "What I was proposing was civil disobedience with a smile," she said. "Give your name as Ranga-Billa, Kung Fu kutta, and address as 7 RCR in NPR," she had said.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: 'Bahadur' MiG-27 jets used by IAF in Kargil war retire after 35 yrs of service
text: The MiG-27 fighter jets of the Indian Air Force, which were part of the Kargil war with Pakistan 20 years ago, flew for the last time on Friday. The fleet has been decommissioned after around 35 years of service and it received 'water salute' at a ceremony in Jodhpur. The MiG-27 had earned the tag of 'Bahadur' from IAF pilots.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Rahul Gandhi dances while playing dhol in Chhattisgarh; video surfaces online
text: Congress leader Rahul Gandhi was seen taking part in a traditional dance at the inauguration of Rashtriya Adivasi Nritya Mahotsav in Chhattisgarh's Raipur. A video showing Rahul dancing while playing dhol has surfaced online. The three-day festival is being held at the Science College ground and over 1,350 artistes from India and six other countries are taking part.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Japan's public broadcaster mistakenly reports N Korea missile launch
text: Japan's public broadcaster, NHK, on Friday mistakenly reported that North Korea had fired a missile that landed in the sea off the country's northernmost island of Hokkaido. The broadcaster apologised for the mistake, saying it'd been intended for "training purposes". North Korea fired missiles over the island in 2017 to demonstrate its ability to strike US military targets in Guam.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Adnan Sami tweets 'Muslims are happy in India', then deletes it
text: Reacting to Pakistani people who criticised Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Adnan Sami wrote on Twitter, "If you're advocating for Muslims...accept that them wanting to leave you, defeats...purpose of your existence!" He added if they're "so worried" about Muslims, they should open their borders for them. "And...Muslims are...proud and happy here," Adnan added. However, he later deleted his tweets.n
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: There are no complaints: Zoya on Gully Boy not making it to Oscars
text: Zoya Akhtar has said there are no complaints regarding her film, 'Gully Boy', not making it to the final nomination list for Oscars 2020, adding, "There was a huge learning." "This has encouraged me to do what I do," she added. "I'm here to make movies. My job is to take every experience and get better with it," Zoya said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Kevin Spacey accuser Ari Behn commits suicide at 47
text: Norwegian princess' ex-husband Ari Behn, who had accused actor Kevin Spacey of sexual misconduct, committed suicide at the age of 47 on December 25, Behn's family's spokesman Geir Håkonsund announced. Behn accused Spacey in December 2017 of groping him under a table at 2007 Nobel Peace Prize concert. His death comes three months after another Spacey's accuser was found dead. n
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: My kids hated 'We Are Family' because I died in the end: Kajol
text: Actress Kajol has revealed that her kids hated her 2010 film, 'We Are Family', in which she played a mother who was diagnosed with cancer. "They hated it because...I die in...end," she added. Kajol further said that her daughter, Nysa, was "traumatised" after watching the film, adding, "She's like, 'I can't believe that you made me go through this film'."
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: I just bought house, need to pay for it: Shahid on Kabir Singh success
text: Shahid Kapoor, while talking about the success of 'Kabir Singh', jokingly said, "I've just bought a house in Worli, and I need to pay for it, so I'm very happy...I got a successful film." "People see actors differently but we also have...same issues...ke, ghar chalana hai aur family ko accha ghar dena hai and acchi life deni hai," he added.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Apple shares hit a record high of $290, surge by 83% in 2019
text: Shares of iPhone maker Apple rose nearly 2% to hit a record high of $289.9 apiece on Thursday, driven by strong early estimates on sales during the Christmas holiday shopping season. So far in 2019, its shares have risen over 83%, putting it on the track for its best annual performance in a decade, since rising about 150% in 2009.
author: Dharna

headlines: Turkey's Wikipedia ban violates human rights, says its top court
text: The highest court in Turkey has ruled against the country's ban on Wikipedia, saying it was unconstitutional and violated human rights concerning the freedom of expression. Turkey had blocked Wikipedia in April 2017, because of content suggesting that Turkey had co-operated with jihadist militants in Syria. Following the ruling, Wikipedia's Co-Founder Jimmy Wales tweeted, "Welcome back, Turkey!"
author: Dharna

headlines: RBI asks banks to cap stake in insurance companies at 30%: Report
text: The RBI has asked lenders to cut their stakes in insurance companies to a maximum of 30%, Livemint reported. The rules, to be introduced soon, are aimed at shielding banks from the risks arising out of their non-core businesses and realigning focus on boosting credit growth. For non-banking financial companies (NBFCs), the shareholding limit will reportedly be capped at 50%.
author: Dharna

headlines: Plane carrying 100 crashes into 2-storey building after take-off from Kazakh airport
text: A plane belonging to Bek Air crashed in Kazakhstan immediately after take-off from Almaty International Airport on Friday. The aircraft, which was carrying 95 passengers and 5 crew members, crashed into a two-storey building. "The aircraft lost its altitude during take-off. Rescue work began immediately. The death toll at the moment is 7," the airport said.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Pay ₹215 cr for using father's image: Bruce Lee's daughter to fast-food chain
text: Bruce Lee's daughter Shannon Lee has sued Chinese fast-food chain Real Kungfu for misappropriating the late martial arts star's image and sought ₹215 crore in damages. Real Kungfu said it has been using the logo since 2004 and is preparing to respond. The image is that of a dark-haired man in a kung fu pose who looks like Bruce Lee.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Didn't say a word to hurt religious sentiments: Raveena after FIR against her
text: After Raveena Tandon, Farah Khan and Bharti Singh were booked for allegedly hurting Christian community's sentiments by making fun of the word 'Hallelujah', Raveena asked people to watch the show's clip. "I haven't said a word that can be interpreted as an insult...The three of us...never intended to offend anyone, but [if] we did, my most sincere apologies," she tweeted.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: CAA ignores Muslims, won't implement it come what may: Puducherry CM
text: Puducherry Chief Minister V Narayanasamy on Thursday said that the Citizenship (Amendment) Act "ignores" Muslims and that he will not implement the law, as well as the National Register of Citizens in the Union Territory "come what may". Narayanasamy added that CAA and NRC were "ill-conceived" and aimed at achieving the goal of "Hindutva, as championed by the BJP".
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Norwegian tourist questioned by Kochi foreign office for attending CAA protest
text: A 74-year-old Norwegian tourist was summoned to Foreigners Regional Registration Office in Kochi and asked about her attendance at an anti-CAA protest march on Monday. An official said, "We're enquiring for more details to understand if there was a visa violation. Did she intentionally attend the protest? Or was it out of curiosity?" Her visa is valid until March 2020.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Internet services suspended in Kanpur district till 9 pm tomorrow
text: UP government has suspended internet services in Kanpur district ahead of Friday prayers amid concerns of further protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The services will remain suspended till 9 pm tomorrow. At least 20 people have died in violence during the anti-CAA protests. Internet will also be affected in Agra, Mathura, Firozabad, Saharanpur and Bijnor among other places.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: UP DGP orders SITs for probe into violence during anti-CAA protests
text: Uttar Pradesh Director General of Police (DGP) OP Singh has directed the state police headquarters to constitute Special Investigation Teams (SIT) for proper investigation in all 327 FIRs registered in connection with the violence during anti-citizenship law protests. The officers are asked to conduct investigations on merit basis and arrest people after collecting proper evidence against them.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Selector Gandhi ejected from Bengal dressing room after Tiwary's complaint
text: BCCI's national selector from East Zone, Devang Gandhi, was ejected from Bengal's dressing room for unauthorised entry by a BCCI anti-corruption official after Bengal batsman Manoj Tiwary raised a complaint. "A national selector cannot get in dressing room without authorization. Only players and officials who have their mug-shots at the entrance can get access in the dressing room," Manoj said.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Umpire David Shepherd jumped up, down every time score struck 111
text: Late English umpire David Shepherd would hop and skip on the cricket field every time the scoreboard read 111, 222, 333 and so on. Such a score, called a Nelson in cricket, is considered unlucky and it is believed that having no part of the body in contact with ground brings better luck. Shepherd was born on December 27, 1940.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: India's data rules could limit everyone's access to info: Wikimedia
text: Wikipedia's operator Wikimedia Foundation urged the government to rethink the proposed changes to the intermediary liability rules. Wikimedia wrote over the proposed rules around content filtering, setting up of a local entity and traceability of content. "We remain concerned that requirements in the bill will hinder our mission to provide free access to knowledge in India," Wikimedia said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Banaras Hindu University to offer 'Bhoot Vidya' course
text: Banaras Hindu University (BHU) in Varanasi will offer a six-month certificate course named 'Bhoot Vidya' to teach doctors how to treat people who claim to see or be possessed by ghosts. The course will be conducted by the faculty of Ayurveda. A separate unit of Bhoot Vidya has been set up in the university to focus on psychosomatic disorders.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Centre sends 11 teams to Gujarat as locusts from Pak destroy crops
text: The Centre has sent 11 teams to Gujarat to tackle the locust infestation from Pakistan that has damaged several crops like potato, wheat, cumin, cotton and mustard over the last few days in the state. The locusts destroyed crops in Mehsana, Kutch, Banaskantha, Sabarkantha and Patan. The Gujarat government is considering using drones to spray insecticides on the fields.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: No maintenance for women if divorce is due to adultery: Bombay HC
text: Bombay High Court recently upheld an order of a lower court cancelling maintenance paid to a divorced woman. The maintenance was cancelled on the grounds that the divorce was granted after an allegation of adultery against the woman was proven. The husband sought a divorce in 2000 and was granted one under Section 13 of The Hindu Marriage Act, 1955.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: US city plans to legalise snowball fights after 57-year-long ban
text: City council of Wausau in the US state of Wisconsin is looking to amend a nearly 57-year-old law prohibiting throwing snowballs within city limits. The law enacted in 1962 states that no person shall shoot any object, arrow, stone, snowball at another person or at any other public place within the city. The amendment is to strike the word "snowball".
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Firefighter stands with koala during bushfires in Australia; pic goes viral
text: A picture of a firefighter standing with a koala in Australia's Lobethal during the bushfires has gone viral on social media. Officials said that two koalas came out of the bush to escape the fire and they were given water and were moved to a safer location. Around 2,700 animals are estimated to have been killed in the bushfires.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Student who died tackling gunman in US shooting honoured as Jedi by Star Wars
text: Riley Howell, a US student who died tackling a gunman in a shooting has been honoured as a Jedi. Howell, a Star Wars fan, has been mentioned in the book 'Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker – The Visual Dictionary'. He's been credited in the book with collecting "many of the earliest accounts of exploration and codifications of The Force".
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: RBI announces second round of 'Operation Twist'
text: The RBI will conduct a second round of simultaneous bond buying and selling on Monday in an effort to lower long-term borrowing costs. It will purchase ₹10,000 crore worth of government bonds maturing in 2029 and sell ₹10,000 crore worth of short-term government bonds maturing in 2020. The move is similar to the US Federal Reserve's 'Operation Twist' in 2011-12.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Don't be misled by Opposition's propaganda on CAA: Shivraj Chouhan
text: BJP leader Shivraj Singh Chouhan said people shouldn't be "misled" by the Congress-led Opposition's "propaganda" on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). "While Sonia Gandhi, along with her family, is leading the protests against CAA...why was she and Rahul Gandhi silent about the Bill when it was being discussed in Parliament," he asked. His statement comes amid nationwide protests against CAA.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: BJP's 'no discussion on NRC' claim tactical retreat: JD(U)'s Kishor
text: JD(U) Vice President Prashant Kishor tweeted, "The claim of 'abhi toh NRC ki koi charcha hi nahin hui hai' is nothing but a tactical retreat in the face of nationwide protest against CAA-NRC." He added, "Government could wait till Supreme Court judgment on CAA. A favourable court order and the whole process will be back."
author: Shailesh

headlines: Playing aerial shots not a crime: Rohit Sharma
text: Team India's ODI vice-captain Rohit Sharma has said that playing aerial shots is not a crime if it translates into results. "What we need to be careful of is, if the player is doing mistakes again and again," he said. "I would encourage [young players] to play shots...but...they need to understand that they need to produce results," he added.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Spurs remain unbeaten in Boxing Day matches since 2003
text: Tottenham Hotspur on Thursday defeated Brighton 2-1 in the Premier League to remain unbeaten in Boxing Day fixtures since 2003. Brighton's Adam Webster provided lead to the Seagulls in the 37th minute, however,  Spurs' Harry Kane scored the equaliser in the 53rd minute. In the 72nd minute, midfielder Dele Alli provided the winner to the Spurs.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Smith argues with umpire over dead ball call during Boxing Day Test
text: Steve Smith on Thursday entered into an argument with umpire Nigel Llong over a dead ball call during the 26th over of the Boxing Day Test against New Zealand. Umpire Nigel had called a short-pitched ball that hit Smith on his ribs a dead ball and not a leg-bye. Ex-Australia spinner Shane Warne supported Smith, calling Llong's decision "wrong".
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Russian YouTubers create a copy of Tesla's Cybertruck priced at ₹7.6 lakh
text: A team of Russian YouTubers called 'Pushka Garazh' has created a copy of Elon Musk-led Tesla's Cybertruck and have put it on sale for 6,66,666 Russian rubles (over ₹7.6 lakh). They used a LADA 2109 hatchback and plastered with sheet metal to make the Cybertruck knockoff. Their car was spotted on roads outside Moscow and its videos were shared online.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Alibaba invests ₹70 crore in Pune-based logistics startup Xpressbees
text: Pune-based logistics startup Xpressbees is raising more than ₹70 crore ($10 million) from Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba. Regulatory filings showed that Xpressbees is issuing 9,317 Series D preference shares at a price of $1073.30 per share. The startup was founded as the logistics arm of baby products retailer FirstCry and was later spun out as a separate entity in 2015.
author: Dharna

headlines: SoftBank valued Grofers at $644 mn in Series F round: Report
text: Online grocery firm Grofers was valued by SoftBank at around $644 million across all four tranches of its Series F round of funding this year, Entrackr reported. In May, Bloomberg said Grofers raised over $200 million led by SoftBank Vision Fund (SVF) in Series F. During the time, Bloomberg pegged the startup's valuation at $1 billion.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Don't kill innocents in Idlib: Trump to Syria, Iran, Russia
text: US President Donald Trump on Thursday warned Syria, Iran and Russia against killing "innocent civilians" in the Syrian province of Idlib. Syrian and Russian forces have intensified bombardment in the province, which is one of the few pockets of territory under rebel control in the country. Reportedly, thousands of migrants began fleeing towards Turkey after the bombardment began.
author: Shailesh

headlines: 5 OYOs were booked every second in 2019: OYO's Annual Travelopedia
text: The second edition of OYO Travelopedia revealed insights about travel trends in India wherein Uttar Pradesh emerged as the most welcoming state followed by Maharashtra & Karnataka. Delhi topped the popularity chart along with being the most-searched destination. Notably, 5 OYO properties were booked every second this year, as per OYO's travelopedia.
author: Roshan Gupta

headlines: Internet suspended in Ghaziabad from 10 pm tonight, Section 144 to be imposed
text: Internet services will be suspended in Uttar Pradesh's Ghaziabad for 24 hours, starting from 10 pm tonight. Section 144 will also be imposed in the city. Amid the protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Internet services have also been suspended in several areas across Uttar Pradesh, including Agra, Firozabad, Sitapur and Bijnor.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: 51 BHU faculty members sign statement condemning CAA, NRC
text: Fifty-one faculty members of Banaras Hindu University have signed a statement condemning the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and NRC. "This is completely against...the idea of a pluralist democracy...This is clearly an attempt to divide society on communal lines so that real issues of day-to-day living of common man are relegated to the background," the statement read.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Pakistan players refused to eat food with Kaneria as he was a Hindu: Akhtar
text: Ex-Pakistan pacer Shoaib Akhtar has alleged that Pakistan national team cricketers treated former spinner Danish Kaneria unfairly. He added that players refused to eat food with Kaneria because he was a Hindu. "I used to reply to those players, 'How would you feel if I took your food from your house and forced to make you eat outside?'" Akhtar added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Photographer's injury delays start of SA-England Test; carried away on stretcher
text: The start of the Boxing Day Test match between South Africa and England was delayed after photographer Christiaan Kotze got injured in front of the sightscreen. Kotze collapsed in severe pain after tripping on the boundary rope and losing his footing on a slippery pitch cover. He was carried away on a stretcher after receiving medical treatment.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Cummins won't change even if you pay him $100 million or $1 billion: Langer
text: Referring to Australian fast bowler Pat Cummins' ₹15.5-crore IPL deal with KKR, Australia head coach Justin Langer said, "You could pay him a $100 million, you could pay him a $1 billion, it's not going to change him." He added, "They're the sort of people you want in your team. He just loves playing cricket, he's an outstanding young bloke."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Will reveal names of players who didn't talk to me as I am a Hindu: Kaneria
text: After ex-Pakistan pacer Shoaib Akhtar claimed that Pakistani players had problems eating with Danish Kaneria as he is a Hindu, the ex-spinner said, "Akhtar has told the truth." He added, "I will reveal names of players who didn't like to talk to me as I was a Hindu. I didn't have courage to speak on it, but now I will."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Alibaba Cloud is growing, but only in China: Amazon Web Services CEO
text: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is not threatened by the growth of Alibaba Cloud, AWS CEO Andy Jassy has said. He added that Alibaba Cloud is only growing in China and does not have much of a presence in the US, Europe or other countries. According to Gartner, AWS has the most (47.8%) share in the worldwide Infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) market segment.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: 39-year-old Australian man diagnosed with syphilis in his eyes
text: A 39-year-old Australian man was diagnosed with syphilis in his eyes after going to hospital with a headache. He said his pain had been getting worse when he moved his eyes but his vision was still normal. The man told doctors he was 'in a same-sex open relationship and engaged in casual unprotected sexual encounters with several male partners'.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Villagers loot 2,500 kgs of onions worth ₹2.5L after van overturns in Jharkhand
text: Villagers of a Jharkhand village in the Bokaro district looted 2,500 kilograms of onions worth ₹2.5 lakh after a van carrying the staple overturned on Wednesday morning. The carriage van's driver lost control while trying to avoid a speeding vehicle approaching from the opposite side. The villagers even forgot to rescue the injured driver stuck inside the vehicle, locals said.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: SC rejects DU's plea against construction of high-rise in north campus
text: The Supreme Court has dismissed a plea of Delhi University (DU) due to inordinate delay in challenging a decision of the Delhi Development Authority (DDA) which allowed a private real estate firm to construct a high-rise in the north campus without any height restriction. The DDA had allowed the firm to construct a high-rise group housing society in 2011.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: 2 Indian students killed in car crash in Dubai on Christmas eve
text: Two Indian students from Kerala were killed in a road accident in Dubai in the early hours of Christmas Day on Wednesday. Rohit Krishnakumar and Sharat Kumar were on their way back home when the accident took place. Their parents assumed that they must have slept over at each other's house. They were spending university break in Dubai with family.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: UP man bites ear and lip of vendor on being denied free paan
text: A 28-year-old man, Shalu, was arrested on Wednesday for allegedly attacking a paan vendor the previous night in Uttar Pradesh's capital Lucknow. Shalu had demanded a free paan from the vendor and when he was refused, he allegedly hit the vendor with a stone and bit his left ear and lower lip. Passersby took the unconscious vendor to a hospital.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: How did states and UTs perform in Good Governance Index released by Centre?
text: Tamil Nadu topped the list among 18 Big States in the Good Governance Index released by the Centre on December 25. Among the North-East and Hill States, Himachal Pradesh was ranked first, while Puducherry topped the list among the Union Territories. Good Governance Day is observed on December 25, the birth anniversary of late former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Egg-standing test viral in Malaysia, Indonesia during 'ring-of-fire' eclipse
text: Malaysian and Indonesian social media users shared videos of eggs balancing on various surfaces during the 'ring-of-fire' eclipse. According to a scientific theory, which has been debunked, an egg will support itself on its narrow side during a solar eclipse. "Such a waste if you didn't try standing the egg," a user tweeted sharing a picture of 10 standing eggs.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Air India stops selling tickets on credit to govt agencies owing over ₹10L
text: Air India has stopped issuing tickets on credit to government agencies that owe it ₹10 lakh or more, a spokesperson said. Various agencies including CBI, Enforcement Directorate and Border Security Force reportedly owe Air India ₹268 crore. The government is planning to sell a 100% stake in the carrier, which posted a provisional net loss of ₹8,556.35 crore in 2018-19.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Even BJP-backed govts not willing to implement NRC: Pilot
text: Congress leader Sachin Pilot said that even BJP-backed governments were not willing to implement the NRC in their states hence others wouldn't implement it either. "We have already clarified that it's not going to be implemented in Rajasthan," he added. BJP's coalition partner Bihar CM Nitish Kumar was among several Chief Ministers who have said they won't implement NRC.
author: Shailesh

headlines: BJP govt has sinister agenda, NPR dangerous: Chidambaram
text: Senior Congress leader P Chidambaram on Thursday said that the "BJP-led government has a larger and more sinister agenda". He also claimed that the National Population Register (NPR) approved by the BJP government was different and dangerous in terms of the "text and context" of the data collection done in 2010.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: CAA was a dream of Mahatma Gandhi: Goa CM Sawant
text: Goa CM Pramod Sawant said that the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), 2019 "was a dream of Father of the Nation Mahatma Gandhi". He added that the Opposition was carrying out a misinformation campaign to create fears in the "minds of minorities". "The Act would be passed in the Goa legislative Assembly soon," he further said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Don't fear anybody: Mamata asks students to carry on CAA protests
text: West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, during a protest march in Kolkata, asked students to carry on with their protests. "Don't fear anybody. I warn the BJP not to play with fire," Banerjee said. "We express our solidarity with students of Jamia Millia, IIT-Kanpur and other universities who are protesting against the CAA and the NRC," she added.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Batsmen hit balls in nets out of anxiety, Smith out of love: Chappell
text: Talking about Australia batsman Steve Smith, who has scored 950 runs in 2019 so far, ex-Australia captain Ian Chappell said Smith's mind works differently. Chappell added that most batsmen hit a lot of balls in nets out of anxiety but Smith does it because he loves batting. "He's filling up the day, waiting for real cricket to start," he stated.n
author: Utkarsh Kumar

headlines: Hoping to make comeback into the ODI team: Ajinkya Rahane
text: India Test vice-captain Ajinkya Rahane, who hasn't played white-ball cricket in almost two years, has said that he's "hoping to comeback into the ODI team". Speaking about not being selected for the 2019 World Cup, he said that he introspected "trying to find answers". "I'm in a very good mindspace…now I have to focus on upcoming things," he added.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Real Kashmir FC win in 1st home match since Article 370 abrogation
text: Real Kashmir FC on Thursday defeated defending champions Chennai City FC 2-1 in the ongoing I-League 2019-20 in their first home match since the abrogation of Article 370. While Danish Farooq put hosts in the front in the 22nd minute, Bazie Armand doubled the lead in the 27th minute. Syed Suhail Pasha was Chennai's lone scorer in the 48th minute.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: 32-yr-old man arrested for stealing Uber car in Maharashtra
text: Police arrested a 32-year-old man from Maharashtra's Thane district in connection with Uber's stolen car. An Uber driver had filed a complaint on December 16 stating a customer fled with the car. The man forced the driver out of the car after travelling some distance, Senior Inspector Chandrakant Jadhav said. The police arrested the man after getting a tip-off.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Volkswagen's robots can turn any car park into a EV charging point
text: Volkswagen previewed its mobile charging robots that can drive to an electric car completely autonomously and communicate with it. They can take care of the entire charging process on their own without any human help. The robots are fitted with cameras, laser scanners and ultrasonic sensors. Their design is suited for use in restricted parking areas like underground car parks.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: J'khand results indicate AAP to retain power in Delhi: Sanjay Singh
text: AAP leader Sanjay Singh said that results of the Jharkhand Assembly polls indicate that the AAP government will be re-elected in Delhi with a "thumping majority". He added that the results also indicate that elections will be fought on local issues. "Today, inflation, education, health are real issues. We have worked on these issues in Delhi," he further said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Turkey to send troops to Libya in support of UN-recognised govt
text: Turkey will send troops to Libya to aid the United Nations-recognised Government of National Accord (GNA) once it gets the approval from its Parliament, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan said. He added that the Bill will be introduced on January 7 and likely be passed in the next two days. Turkey and Libya recently signed security and cooperation deals.
author: Shailesh

headlines: US woman booking cab to airport finds helicopter as cheapest option on Uber
text: A New York-based woman who was looking to book a cab to the JFK International Airport found that a helicopter ride provided under Uber Copter service was the cheapest option, cheaper than UberX and UberPool cab rides. A screenshot of the app shared by her on Twitter has gone viral. "You have to fly it yourself," a Twitter user joked.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Comedian shares pic of ₹1.5L glasses resembling PM's, asks if they come for free
text: After PM Narendra Modi shared his picture on Thursday, comedian Atul Khatri shared a screenshot, which showed ₹1.5 lakh glasses resembling those that PM wore in the picture. He tweeted, "[Do] these sunglasses come free with...[Mercedes-Maybach] car or you've to buy separately?" to which actress Kubbra Sait replied, "You can buy separately." However, some users claimed the glasses aren't original.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Police dug my son's grave, buried him in 2 hrs: Father of man killed in CAA protest
text: Munsi Ahmed, father of Zaheer Mohammad who was killed during anti-CAA protest in UP's Meerut, said that police dug Zaheer's grave and his body was buried within two hours of receiving it. "Only four family members were around when Zaheer's body was buried...When we sought more time, police told me I'd be held legally responsible for any disturbance," he added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Left parties to protest for 1 week from Jan 1-7 against CAA, NRC, NPR
text: The Left parties have called for week-long protests from January 1 to January 7, 2020, against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC), National Population Register (NPR), and economic slowdown. The parties include Communist Party of India (Marxist), Communist Party of India, Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) Liberation, All India Forward Bloc and others.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Jadavpur University students 'rusticate' Chancellor, 'disown' him as WB Governor
text: Jadavpur University students have announced their decision to 'rusticate' Jagdeep Dhankhar as the University Chancellor and to 'disown' him from the position of the West Bengal Governor. In an open letter, the students also described him as "spineless". Dhankhar had recently berated Mamata Banerjee for her decision to launch street protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Why should I go to rioters' homes: UP Min on 2 Muslims killed in CAA row
text: Uttar Pradesh minister Kapil Dev Agarwal who on Thursday refused to meet the families of two Muslim men killed in anti-Citizenship Act protests in Bijnor said, "Why should I go to the homes of rioters?" Agarwal added, "Those who are rioting and want to incite passions against the nation, how are they part of society? This is not about Hindu-Muslim."
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: UP minister skips meeting families of 2 Muslim men killed in CAA row
text: Uttar Pradesh minister Kapil Dev Agarwal on Thursday visited Bijnor district to meet victims of violence during anti-Citizenship Act protests but refused to meet the families of two Muslims who died in the violence. Agarwal met Om Raj Saini who was injured by a gunshot but refused to meet families of 20-year-old Suleman and 25-year-old Anas who died of gunshots.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Mujeeb youngest bowler to take 100 T20 wickets, breaks Rashid's record
text: Afghanistan spinner Mujeeb Ur Rahman has become the youngest bowler in history to take 100 wickets in T20 cricket. Mujeeb achieved the feat at the age of 18 years and 271 days, breaking the record of Afghanistan all-rounder Rashid Khan, who had reached 100 T20 wickets at the age of 18 years and 360 days.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Ban New Year parties on MG Road, Brigade Road: Hindu outfit to B'luru Police
text: The Hindu Janajagruti Samiti has written to Bengaluru Police Commissioner Bhaskar Rao seeking a ban on New Year celebrations on MG Road and Brigade Road. People from across the city take part in the annual New Year celebrations there. The Hindu outfit said "morality of India's youth is degrading" because of such celebrations and requested Rao not to grant permission.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Kerala hotel, staff attacked by group for not serving enough onions during meal
text: A hotel in Kerala's Thiruvananthapuram was attacked and its employees were roughed up on Wednesday night by a group of youngsters over the hotel's alleged refusal to serve more onions. The owner of 'Homely Meals' said three people came to the hotel at night and ordered non-vegetarian dishes. He claimed that they were served onions twice but they wanted more.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: BJP shares Chidambaram's video of him speaking on NPR, he responds
text: Ex-Home Minister P Chidambaram responded after BJP's IT cell in-charge Amit Malviya shared his video on NPR. "We were enumerating usual residents of India. The emphasis was on residency not citizenship," Chidambaram responded. Malviya then shared another video, wherein Chidambaram could be heard saying, "NPR...is for issuing a resident card, which will eventually lead to a citizenship card."
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Want to stop fertiliser subsidy, push organic farming: Guj minister
text: Gujarat Agriculture Minister Ranchhod Faldu has said that the government wants to discontinue the subsidy for chemical fertilisers and that farmers should start organic farming. Faldu said chemical fertilisers have affected the health of people and the fertility of the land. He said that state and Centre gave ₹5,000 crore to 56.36 lakh farmers towards subsidising chemical fertilisers in 2018-19.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: 2 jawans die during bridging exercise at College of Military Engineering
text: Two Indian Army jawans lost their lives at College of Military Engineering, Pune during bridging exercise on Thursday. At least five others were also injured in the accident. Defence officials said the accident took place when a unit was training on a mobile bridge which is used to scale obstacles in difficult terrains.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Govt likely to miss disinvestment target by ₹50,000 crore: Reports
text: The government is unlikely to complete the privatisation of Air India and Bharat Petroleum, and stake sale in Container Corporation of India by March, leading to a ₹40,000-50,000 crore shortfall in disinvestment target, Livemint reported. It has a disinvestment target of ₹1.05 lakh crore for the ongoing financial year, of which it has managed to garner ₹17,364 crore so far.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Funds raised by Indian IPOs in 2019 fall to lowest in 4 years
text: Funds raised by Indian IPOs fell to $2.8 billion this year amid an economic slowdown, the lowest in four years, according to data from Refinitiv. The proceeds hit record $11.7 billion in 2017 before falling to $5.5 billion in 2018. Meanwhile. shares of IRCTC, marketing and advertising firm Affle India, and e-commerce company Indiamart have doubled from their issues prices.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Raveena, Farah, Bharti booked for hurting religious sentiments
text: Raveena Tandon, Farah Khan and Bharti Singh have been booked for allegedly hurting Christian community's religious sentiments, reportedly by using the word "Hallelujah" on a web show. Punjab Pradesh Congress Committee's general secretary registered the complaint and alleged they were "making fun" of the word. The case was registered on Wednesday, Amritsar Rural Police SSP Vikramjeet Duggal said.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Scorsese's daughter trolls him by wrapping X-mas gifts in Marvel-themed papers
text: Oscar-winning director Martin Scorsese's daughter, Francesca trolled him by wrapping her Christmas gifts to him in Avengers-themed paper. Calling it 'hilarious', Marvel franchise 'Guardians of the Galaxy' director James Gunn wrote on Instagram, "Makes me feel less strange about the Shutter Island wallpaper my nephew wrapped my gifts in." Scorsese had recently called Marvel movies "theme parks".
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: S'pore probes Indian man for holding anti-CAA protest without permit
text: Singapore police are investigating a 32-year-old Indian national for allegedly holding a protest without a police permit in Marina Bay area against India's Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). Organising or participating in a public assembly without a police permit in Singapore is illegal. The police said it would not grant any permit for assemblies that advocate political causes of other countries.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Record 80,473 spectators attend Day 1 of Australia-NZ Boxing Day Test
text: The first day of the Boxing Day Test between Australia and New Zealand at the Melbourne Cricket Ground has recorded the largest single-day crowd for a Test between the two countries. A total of 80,473 spectators attended the first day. The previous day one crowd record for an Australia-New Zealand Test in Melbourne was 51,087.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: It's a win-win situation for Australian players: Coach Langer on IPL
text: Australia coach Justin Langer has said that the Indian Premier League experience will help the Australians to prepare for the upcoming two T20 World Cups in 2020 and 2021. Langer added that the players will play 10-14 T20 matches in IPL which was equal to what they'll play in two years. "Hopefully it's a win-win for everyone," he further said.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Steve Smith enters list of Australia's top 10 Test run-scorers
text: Former Australia skipper Steve Smith on Thursday entered the top 10 of Australia's all-time leading run-scorers in Tests. Smith has surpassed former Test captain Greg Chappell's tally of 7,110 runs and is now at tenth spot with 7113 runs. Another former skipper, Rickey Ponting, is at the top with 13,378 runs in his 168 Test-match career.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Sachin Bansal's Navi acquires tech consulting startup MavenHive
text: Flipkart Co-founder Sachin Bansal-owned Navi Technologies has acquired Bengaluru-based technology consulting startup MavenHive. As a part of the acquisition, MavenHive team along with founders, Bhavin Javia and Anandha Krishnan, will be joining Navi Technologies. MavenHive has previously worked with companies like Flipkart, Gojek and Grasshopper and helped them with its technology solutions.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal flags off 100 standard-floor buses
text: Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal on Thursday flagged off 100 standard-floor buses in the capital. "It is my dream to modernize Delhi's public transport infrastructure so that it becomes a comfortable option for every citizen," Kejriwal said. The buses are equipped with features like hydraulic lifts for the differently-abled persons, GPS trackers, panic buttons and CCTV cameras.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: UN 'decade in review' report says Malala 'most famous teenager'
text: In the UN's 'Decade in Review' report, Nobel Peace Prize winner and Pakistani education rights activist Malala Yousafzai was named as "the most famous teenager in the world" in 2012. "She won several high-profile awards, including the 2014 Nobel Peace Prize, and became a UN Messenger of Peace in 2017, with a special focus on girls' education," the report said.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Typhoon Phanfone leaves 16 dead in Philippines
text: Typhoon Phanfone has killed at least 16 people and several others have been reported missing in the Philippines besides causing large-scale destruction, mitigation authorities said. The typhoon hit the country on Tuesday with gusts of over 190 kph. Over 58,000 people were evacuated before the storm but 15,000 others were left stranded at ports after ferry services were suspended.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Helicopters used to douse fire that destroyed over 200 homes in Chile
text: Over 200 houses were destroyed in Chile's Valparaíso in a fire that began on Christmas eve, Chilean Interior and Public Security Minister Gonzalo Blumel said. Helicopters were used to douse the fires that mostly affected low-income neighbourhoods. Blumel added that the fires could have been started deliberately and claimed that "there will be no impunity" for those responsible.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Japan executes foreigner for murdering family, its 1st since 2009
text: Japan executed a Chinese man, named Wei Wei, convicted for murdering a businessman and his family in 2003. He is reportedly the first foreigner to be executed by the country since 2009. His two accomplices in the crime had fled to China where, after their arrests, one of them was executed and the other was sentenced to life in jail.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Mukesh Ambani's unlisted Reliance Retail valued at over double that of DMart
text: A share swap offer for employees of Mukesh Ambani's unlisted Reliance Retail to exit their holdings has valued the unit at ₹2.8 lakh crore, according to BloombergQuint's calculations. Reliance Retail shareholders can exchange four shares for one share of its parent Reliance Industries. The valuation set by the company, which runs 10,901 stores, is more than double that of DMart.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Even Gaitonde knew his shit: Sacred Games actor trolls Saif over CAA remark
text: Actor Aamir Bashir, who played 'Inspector Majid Ali Khan' on 'Sacred Games', trolled Saif Ali Khan after he said he "is not sure what he's protesting against and needs to think more" while commenting on CAA. "[For f**k's sake]!!! Talk to Majid, Sartaj! Even #Gaitonde knew his shit," Aamir tweeted. While Saif played 'Sartaj', 'Gaitonde' was portrayed by Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Rahul shares BBC video of detention centre in Assam, calls PM 'liar'
text: Congress leader Rahul Gandhi on Thursday shared a video by BBC News Hindi of an under-construction detention centre in Assam. Gandhi wrote, "The Prime Minister of RSS lies to Bharat Mata." This comes days after PM Narendra Modi claimed in an election rally in Delhi that there are no detention centres in India in the wake of anti-Citizenship Act protests.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: 1-yr-old without parents for a week after they get arrested during UP protests
text: A one-year-old baby girl, Arya, in Uttar Pradesh's Varanasi has been without her activist parents for a week after they were arrested and jailed by police for attending a protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The baby's aunt, who is currently taking care of her, said Arya is a breastfeeding baby, adding, "She misses her parents and looks for them."
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: It's fake: Sena MP on letter pledging support to CAA and NRC
text: Shiv Sena MP Hemant Patil on Thursday said that a letter pledging his support to the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the National Register of Citizens (NRC) is "fake". "I have not written any such letter. One of my letters issued for railway reservations has been misused here," said Patil. He said that he has also lodged a complaint with police.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Not a single rupee for fanatics killed in Mangaluru police firing: BJP MLA
text: Karnataka BJP MLA Aravind Limbavali has tweeted, "Not a single [rupee] will be paid as compensation from government of Karnataka to fanatics shot by police during Mangaluru riots." "Tax payers money should be used for constructive purpose. Unlike Congress & JDS we don't reward rioters,"  he added. The state withdrew ₹10 lakh ex-gratia it announced for families of those killed.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Time to teach lesson to Cong-led 'tukde-tukde gang': Shah in Delhi
text: Home Minister Amit Shah on Thursday said in an event in Delhi that the time has come to teach a lesson to the 'tukde-tukde gang' led by the Congress which is responsible for the unrest in Delhi. Shah said, "When the Citizenship (Amendment) Bill was discussed in Parliament, no one said anything. But they started spreading confusion after coming out."
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Shoaib Malik takes a dig at India in Christmas message, Indian fans troll him
text: Pakistan all-rounder Shoaib Malik took a dig at India while wishing his followers Merry Christmas. Malik shared a picture of himself celebrating Pakistan's win against India in 2012. "Merry Christmas...dosto and a very happy 25th December," he tweeted. An Indian fan shared a video of him getting out on golden duck against India in World Cup, writing, "Same to you."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: What is a Boxing Day Test match in cricket?
text: The Test match that starts on December 26, primarily at Australia's Melbourne Cricket Ground, is called the Boxing Day Test. According to a theory, December 26 came to be known as the Boxing Day as the servants in Victorian-era England were given boxes of gifts a day after Christmas. Australia has hosted a Boxing Day Test every year since 1990.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: No Pakistan player to be part of Asia XI for T20Is vs World XI in B'desh: BCCI
text: BCCI Joint Secretary Jayesh George has said no Pakistani player will be a part of Asia XI for T20Is against World XI in Bangladesh. He added that BCCI President Sourav Ganguly will decide the five Indians who will be a part of Asia XI. The matches will be held to celebrate the birth centenary of Bangladesh's founder Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: ICC rankings system is absolute garbage: Michael Vaughan
text: Talking about ICC rankings system, ex-England captain Michael Vaughan said, "I'll be dead honest about the ICC rankings. I think they're absolute garbage." Vaughan added the rankings are confusing as England are fourth despite just winning series at home and drawing Ashes at home. He further said New Zealand shouldn't be second-ranked as Australia are a far better team.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Scientists freeze legos to -273.15°C to check their usage in quantum computers
text: Physicists at the UK's Lancaster University froze lego bricks and a figure to -273.15°C to see if they can help in developing quantum computers. The temperature was 2,00,000 times colder than room temperature. "We found clamping arrangement between lego blocks causes lego structures to behave as an extremely good thermal insulator at cryogenic temperatures," scientist who led the team said.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Modi is so cool, while the country burns, he chills: Cong on PM's eclipse pic
text: Taking a dig at PM Narendra Modi after he shared a picture of himself looking at the solar eclipse, Congress tweeted the picture with caption, "Modi so cool, while the country burns, he chills". "Truly the Coolest PM. #JhootJhootJhoot," the party wrote. Earlier, a user tweeted that PM Modi's picture is becoming a meme, to which, PM Modi replied, "Enjoy".
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: AAP stealing credit of Centre's developmental projects in Delhi: Shah
text: Home Minister Amit Shah has accused Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal-led AAP government of stealing credit for the Centre's developmental work. Shah said that he saw an advertisement by Delhi government that drinking water will be provided to every household. He added that PM Narendra Modi had already announced that Centre will provide drinking water to all households across the country.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Savitribai Phule quits Cong 9 months after joining, says 'voice not being heard'
text: Savitribai Phule, who had joined Congress in March this year after quitting BJP, has resigned from Congress stating that her voice was not being heard in the party. She also said that she will form her own party. Phule had resigned from BJP last year, alleging that the party "was trying to create division in the society".
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Pak to import polio markers from India months after suspending trade ties
text: Pakistan cabinet has allowed one-time import of polio finger marker from India months after it suspended trade ties with New Delhi following the abrogation of Article 370 to revoke J&K's special status. Pakistan said the move was made on 'recommendations' of the World Health Organisation. The markers are used to mark the fingers of children after administering them polio vaccine.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Kids buried neck-deep in K'taka during solar eclipse to cure disabilities
text: Three disabled children were buried in mud up till the neck during a solar eclipse at the Taj Sultanpur village in Karnataka's Kalaburagi district on Thursday. The parents believe that the 'ritual' would 'cure' the children. A case has been registered against the parents and a similar case was reported at Ainoli village, Kalaburagi Deputy Commissioner B Sharath said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Israel PM taken off stage, moved into bomb shelter after rocket launched from Gaza
text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was taken off stage during a campaign rally in Ashkelon and was moved to take cover in a bomb shelter after a rocket was launched from the Gaza Strip. The rocket was, however, shot down by an Iron Dome air defence interceptor. Netanyahu resumed the event after some time.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: We should have only 2 GST rates, says NITI Aayog member
text: NITI Aayog member Ramesh Chand has said India should have just two GST slabs as against the multiple slabs currently. He also said if rates need to be changed, it should be done annually. "It has become a tendency of every sector to ask for lower GST. I feel GST issues are much larger than asking for rates," Chand added.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Need a husband who's more intelligent, beautiful, talented than me: Kangana
text: Kangana Ranaut, when asked about the qualities she wants in a husband, said, "I need somebody who's more intelligent...beautiful...and...talented than me." She further said she thought "a marriage where you can have equal companionship" would be "difficult to find" until she witnessed filmmaker Ashwiny Iyer Tiwari's marriage. Kangana added she is hopeful now that a marriage like that is possible.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Star power can't hold audience in theatres if film isn't good: Salman
text: Salman Khan has said that people say "star power" works but it cannot hold the audience in theatres "if the film is not good". "The subject is important...scenes...music have to be good. If...boring scene comes, people get busy with...phones," he added. "When fans go to theatre they should want to be you (hero)...that's my funda to do movies," Salman said.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: I'm a 'no planning' kind of person, happy how life surprised me: Mouni
text: Actress Mouni Roy, when asked how she would describe her 2019, said, "Every year is a mixed bag...Sometimes you're not well, sometimes you feel...you're on top of the world but that's life." Calling herself "no planning kind of person", Mouni said, "Anything...I...planned in life...never happened." "And whatever has happened...however life has surprised me, I'm very happy with that," she added.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Leadership is knowing limit of one's office: Owaisi on Army chief's remark
text: After Army chief General Bipin Rawat said that "leaders are not those who carry out arson and violence in cities and towns", AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi commented that "leadership is knowing the limits of one's office". "It's about understanding the idea of civilian supremacy," he added. Rawat's statement comes amid protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act across India.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: It's crime: Jurgen Klopp on teams playing twice within 48 hours in PL
text: With several teams including defending champions Manchester City set to play two matches within 48 hours this week in Premier League, Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has termed it a "crime" against these teams. "The body needs a specific amount of time to go again," he said. City manager Pep Guardiola has also written to the league over the schedule.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Bombay Shaving Company raises $6.3 mn led by Sixth Sense Ventures
text: Men's grooming startup Bombay Shaving Company has raised $6.3 million in a round led by Sixth Sense Ventures. The round also saw participation from its existing investor Colgate Palmolive Asia Pacific. As per filings, 30 angel investors including, Kiran Deshpande, ex-CEO of Tech Mahindra, and 16 partners from McKinsey, had invested in the startup back in 2016.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Russia only country to deploy hypersonic weapons: Prez Putin
text: Russian President Vladimir Putin said that Russia is the only country in the world that has deployed hypersonic weapons. He also noted that the Soviet Union, Russia's predecessor, was behind the US in designing weapons during the Cold War but the current situation is the other way round.  Hypersonic weapons travel at speeds greater than 5,000 kph or Mach 5.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Shopping, dressing up is one very girly element in my life: Kiara
text: Kiara Advani said in an interview that she has "always enjoyed shopping and getting dressed up" and added "that's one very girly element" in her life. "Sometimes, I feel like I go and shop so much...clothes are just lying in my cupboard," she further said. On being asked what fashion means to her, Kiara added, "It means just being yourself."
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Hitachi aims to power good for a smarter & healthier society
text: Hitachi is collaborating with stakeholders to accelerate and support India's quest to become a Global Economy. Hitachi Social Innovation Business aims to integrate its digital technology and expertise in infrastructure to make our society safer, smarter and healthier. Together with various partners, Hitachi aims to find solutions to the society's challenges and continue to power good.
author: Roshan Gupta

headlines: Varun, Nora get mobbed at church; photographers rescue them on scooter
text: Actors Varun Dhawan and Nora Fatehi were rescued by two photographers on a scooter after fans mobbed them during their visit to Mumbai's Mount Mary Church. A video shows Varun escaping the crowd on the scooter. He later shared a story with the photographers and said, "We got out from a major crowd...They also helped us take Nora out."
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: My daughter unaware of what I do, asks why photographers take our pics: Akshay
text: Actor Akshay Kumar, when asked if his 7-year-old daughter Nitara is aware of his superstar status, said, "Not really...She's at an age where she is...busy watching cartoons...She isn't... bothered what her dad does." He added that she asks him why paparazzi take their photographs. "I explained, 'They...have family...It's good to give them photographs...They can earn money'," Akshay said.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Miley, Liam reach divorce settlement exactly a year after getting married
text: Singer Miley Cyrus and her ex-husband, actor Liam Hemsworth have settled the details of their divorce exactly a year after they got married, as per reports. "It wasn't a complicated divorce because of their prenup and it was all handled by attorneys," reports said. Liam had filed for divorce in August 2019 citing "irreconcilable differences" as the reason.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Nysa won't tell Ajay about boyfriends, he'll be standing with gun: Kajol
text: Kajol, during her appearance on 'What Women Want', revealed her 16-year-old daughter Nysa is likely to come to her for relationship advice because her husband Ajay Devgn is "the kind of guy who'll be standing with a shotgun". "She's never going to tell her father about her boyfriends," Kajol added. The actress further said she's not a very "controlling parent".
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Mona Singh to tie the knot, pics from mehendi ceremony surface online
text: Pictures from the mehendi ceremony of actress Mona Singh, who is reportedly getting married in Mumbai on Friday to an investment banker, have surfaced online. In the pictures, Mona can be seen flaunting her mehendi and posing with friends including comedian Gaurav Gera. Reportedly, only the people who are close to her were given an invitation to her wedding.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: UP Police releases video of protesters shooting at them in anti-CAA protests
text: The Uttar Pradesh Police has released videos and photos of the violence in Meerut during the protests against Citizenship (Amendment) Act, showing two men firing at policemen. In one of the videos, a masked man in a blue jacket could be seen walking around with a gun. At least six people had died during the violent protests in Meerut.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Leaders don't lead masses to carry out violence: Army chief amid CAA protests
text: Amid violent protests against Citizenship (Amendment) Act across the country, Indian Army chief General Bipin Rawat said, "Leaders are not those who lead people in an inappropriate direction." "As we're witnessing...a large number of university and college students, the way they're leading masses...to carry out arson and violence in cities and towns. This is not leadership," he added.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: UP policeman disguises as banana seller to track protesters causing violence
text: Sub-Inspector Sunil Tomar took the disguise of a vendor selling bananas to track perpetrators of violence that took place in Firozabad during last week's anti-citizenship law protests, SHO Jeetendra Kumar said. It would have been difficult to gather information about these "mischief-makers" directly from civilians and hence, we decided to go undercover, Kumar added.
author: Trivedi Bhutnath

headlines: Will find way to be with you: German IIT student sent back over anti-CAA protest
text: German IIT-Madras student Jakob Lindenthal, who was sent back for participating in anti-CAA protests, said, "My deep respect goes to all...who carry the protests against CAA and NRC across India and...the world!" "I'll find a way to be with you," he added. Lindenthal said he was told by government officials that he violated his visa terms by participating in protests.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: We didn't see the protests coming, were unable to predict anger: Union Minister
text: Talking about anti-CAA protests across India, BJP MP and Minister of State for Animal Husbandry, Sanjeev Balyan, said, "I really didn't see the protests coming...not just me, other BJP lawmakers were also unable to predict this kind of anger." Another union minister told Reuters, "I believe the political math behind the clearance of this law was not taken into account."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: James Anderson first specialist bowler in history to play 150 Test matches
text: England's 37-year-old fast bowler James Anderson has become the first specialist bowler in history to play 150 Test matches. Anderson achieved the feat after taking the field in the Boxing Day Test against South Africa in Centurion on Thursday. Anderson dismissed Dean Elgar off the first delivery of the match. He had made his Test debut in May 2003.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: AI has potential to help India achieve GDP targets: NITI Aayog CEO
text: NITI Aayog CEO Amitabh Kant in an interview with Livemint said, "Artificial intelligence is the future of technology. It's transformative and revolutionary, with the potential to be disruptive across all aspects of human existence." He added, "For India, the GDP increment by 2035 is targeted at $957 billion." "This would have a multiplier effect across the ecosystem," he further said.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: U-turn will be known as Uddhav ji Thackeray-turn: BJP's Chandrakant Patil
text: BJP Maharashtra President Chandrakant Patil has alleged that state CM Uddhav Thackeray didn't fulfil his promise to waive full loans of farmers without limit. "U-turn will...be known as Uddhav ji Thackeray-turn," he added. "Now, he...understood...difference between announcement and implementation," Patil further said. This comes after Thackeray announced a loan waiver of up to ₹2 lakh for farmers.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: JJP MLA Ram Gautam resigns as party VP, says 'nothing right in party'
text: The Jannayak Janta Party (JJP)'s MLA from Haryana's Narnaund constituency, Ram Kumar Gautam on Wednesday resigned from the party's Vice President post. "Nothing is going right in the party. I'm upset with the way it is functioning," he said. "I was made all India Vice President...even though the party has influence in a limited pocket in Haryana," Gautam added.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: BJP-JJP alliance in Haryana was made at Gurugram mall: JJP MLA
text: JJP MLA Ram Kumar Gautam claimed that BJP-JJP alliance in Haryana was made in a meeting held at a mall in Gurugram. "I'm not hurt that I wasn't made minister, but hurt that I got to know later that the alliance was made at a mall," he added. "I've resigned from the post of party vice president," he further said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Kerala's Cheruvathur 1st place in India where today's solar eclipse was visible
text: Cheruvathur in north Kerala was the first place in India where Thursday morning's solar eclipse was visible. A large crowd of scientists, students and media people had gathered at the site to witness the 'ring of fire' solar eclipse. Major temples in Kerala, including the Sabarimala temple, were closed for four hours in the morning owing to the eclipse.n
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: 'Ring of fire' solar eclipse witnessed in different parts of India; pics surface
text: Several parts of the country, including Odisha, Kerala, Gujarat, Tamil Nadu and Karnataka are witnessing a solar eclipse on Thursday. Pictures that have surfaced online show the annular or 'ring of fire' solar eclipse, the last solar eclipse of this decade, in different parts of India. The eclipse was first viewed from Cheruvathur in Kerala.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Twitter user says PM Modi's eclipse pic is becoming a meme; PM replies 'enjoy'
text: After PM Narendra Modi posted a picture of himself looking at solar eclipse on Thursday, a Twitter user wrote, "This (the picture) is becoming a meme". Responding to the user, PM Modi wrote, "Most welcome....enjoy :)" Earlier, in his post PM Modi had said, "I was enthusiastic about #solareclipse2019. Unfortunately, I could not see the Sun due to cloud cover."
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 19-yr-old BTech student raped by lab technician in T'gana Minister's college
text: A lab technician working in Telangana's Malla Reddy Engineering College allegedly raped a 19-year-old BTech student inside a lab on Monday, police said. The 33-year-old accused had sent the student a message on WhatsApp, asking her to meet him in the lab. The college is owned and run by state's Minister for Labour and Employment Malla Reddy and his family.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: TN farmer builds temple for PM Modi, says he benefitted from his schemes
text: A farmer in Tamil Nadu's Trichy district has built a temple for Prime Minister Narendra Modi on his farm. P Shankar said that he built the temple to show his affection for PM Modi after he benefitted from several schemes. "I put my own hard-earned ₹1.2 lakh to build the NaMo Temple for our PM," he added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Time for Bollywood to revive age-old link with Kashmir: BJP
text: BJP leader and advisor to Jammu and Kashmir Lieutenant Governor GC Murmu, Farooq Khan, has urged Bollywood to "revive its age-old link with Kashmir". He asked the film fraternity to explore the Union Territory with "new dynamism" and look for opportunities to shoot movies. The ties of Bollywood with Kashmir has suffered in the past few years, Khan further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: 'Friends' theme songwriter Allee Willis dies aged 72
text: Allee Willis, writer of 'I'll Be There For You' which was used as the theme song in TV series 'Friends', died on Tuesday in Los Angeles from a cardiac arrest. "Rest In Boogie Wonderland November 10, 1947- December 24, 2019," her partner Prudence Fenton wrote on Instagram. Allee won two Grammys for 'Beverly Hills Cop' and 'The Color Purple'.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Madonna's ex sent her divorce-related court filing on Christmas: Reports
text: American singer Madonna reportedly received divorce-related court filing from her ex-husband Guy Ritchie, on Christmas. Guy on Monday filed a motion in their divorce case seeking "the enforcement or execution of a judgment or order" in a Manhattan court, as per reports. Madonna and Guy got divorced in 2008 and have two sons, Rocco and David.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Samsung's next foldable phone could have a glass display: Reports
text: Samsung's vertically folding, clamshell-style phone, which surfaced in October, might come with a foldable display made out of glass. According to reports quoting phone leaker Ice Universe's tweets, Samsung has created "an ultra-thin glass cover" for the phone. The tweet pointed to a smooth and less wrinkled appearance of the screen as proof.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Laluji asked RJD to work harder in Bihar than in J'khand: Tejashwi
text: After Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM)-Congress-Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) alliance won the Jharkhand Assembly elections, Lalu Prasad Yadav's son Tejashwi Yadav met his father. "The Jharkhand poll...[will] impact Bihar. Laluji [has asked] our men in Bihar to work four times harder than they did in Jharkhand," Tejashwi told media. Lalu Prasad Yadav is in Ranchi serving sentences in fodder scam cases.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Ola-owned Foodpanda records ₹756 crore loss in FY19
text: Ola-owned food delivery business Foodpanda has recorded a loss of ₹756.42 crore in the financial year 2019, according to the Ministry of Corporate Affairs filing accessed by Tofler. In 2018, the losses for the food delivery startup stood at ₹227.95 crore. Foodpanda's operating income increased by 12.2% to ₹81.77 crore in FY19 from ₹72.84 crore in FY18.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Casio offers up to 30% discount on new G-Shock watch collection
text: Casio is offering up to 30% discount on its latest G-Shock watch collection as part of a limited period offer. The wide range of tough waterproof digital watches in the G-Shock collection come equipped with active functionalities and a shock-resistant feature. When it comes to pushing boundaries, G-Shock is a great companion in helping you #ChallengeTheLimits, says Casio.
author: Roshan Gupta

headlines: Got 1st ad while trying to impress a girl, she was director's girlfriend: Salman
text: Salman Khan has revealed his attempt to impress a girl, who later turned out to be the director's girlfriend, got him his first commercial. "I was swimming one day...and I saw this...beautiful...lady walking past in a red sari. To impress her, I dived in the water," he added. Salman further said the ad's makers wanted someone who could swim underwater.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Freezing in Delhi, I've no warm clothes: Singer on IndiGo misplacing baggage
text: Singer Akriti Kakar on Tuesday criticised IndiGo, alleging the airline misplaced one of her bags. Claiming it was marked 'Fast Forward', Akriti tweeted that after she landed she was told the bag wasn't loaded on the flight. "How can you bring one bag and leave the other behind! Now in this cold freezing Delhi, I've no warm clothes," she added.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: I wasn't protesting but hiding in a lane when I was shot: Class 10 boy in UP
text: A Class 10 boy, who was injured during anti-CAA protests in Uttar Pradesh's Lucknow, said he was going to his sister's house when stone pelting began. "I tried to hide in a lane but was shot in the stomach," the 17-year-old recalled. A 15-year-old boy also said he wasn't protesting but hiding in a lane when he was shot at.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 400 booked for violating Sec 144 by organising candle march in AMU
text: The police have registered a case against 400 unidentified persons for violating the CrPC Section 144 by organising a candle march inside the Aligarh Muslim University campus on December 23 in solidarity with people who have lost their lives in anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protests. "There was no permission for the candle march," said Senior Superintendent of Police (SSP) Akash Kulhary.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Leander Paes to end his 29-year professional tennis career in 2020
text: Leander Paes has announced he would retire from professional tennis in 2020, saying the next year is going to be an "emotional one". He added he'll play a few select tournaments next year. The 46-year-old, who turned professional in 1991, has won 18 doubles and mixed doubles Grand Slam titles and singles' bronze medal at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Manufactured lies: Chat app ToTok developers deny allegations of spyware
text: The developers of 'ToTok', a popular UAE-based messaging application, have responded to the allegations by the US of the app being used as a spy tool by the UAE government. The developers called the allegations "manufactured lies", adding that they built ToTok with user security and privacy as their priority. Both Google and Apple have removed ToTok from their platforms.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Free Wi-Fi to all villages connected via BharatNet till March 2020: Prasad
text: Wi-Fi services provided through BharatNet in villages will be free till March 2020, Telecom and Information Technology Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said on Wednesday. "We have already connected 1.3 lakh gram panchayats through BharatNet network...Our target is to take this to 2.5 lakh gram panchayats," he said. Currently, 48,000 villages connected under the BharatNet project have Wi-Fi access.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: 'Terrorist, go back,' Bhopal university students chant in front of Pragya
text: Students and NSUI workers raised "Pragya Thakur, go back" and "atankwadi, wapas jao (terrorist, go back)" slogans against BJP MP Pragya Thakur after she visited a university in Madhya Pradesh's Bhopal on Wednesday. A video shows the group raising slogans in front of her. Meanwhile, Pragya called the people raising slogans "traitor", adding that she'll take action against them.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 'Ring of fire' solar eclipse begins, visible from parts of India
text: The final solar eclipse of the decade has begun in Eastern Hemisphere and can be seen in southern parts of India. It started at around 8 am in India and will end by 1:35 pm. An annular solar eclipse happens when Moon covers the Sun's centre, leaving the Sun's outer edges to form a 'ring of fire' around the Moon.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: A giant missed opportunity: US lawmaker after EAM Jaishankar cancels meeting
text: US Congresswoman Pramila Jayapal said the cancellation of a meeting by External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar was a "giant missed opportunity for countries that value dialogue and dissent". "It's also a sign of weakness for any democracy to refuse to allow those who have criticisms to participate", she added. Jayapal has been critical of the restrictions in place in Kashmir.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Indian soldier martyred, woman killed as Pak violates ceasefire: Report
text: A soldier of the Indian Army was martyred and a 22-year-old woman, Naseema Begum, was also killed in the ceasefire violation by Pakistan Army in Jammu and Kashmir's Uri sector on Wednesday, reports said. The Pakistan Army was targeting civilian population on the Line of Control (LoC) from its artillery guns deployed in villages in Pakistan-occupied Kashmir (PoK), reports added.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: No passenger death in FY 2020, a first in Railways' 166-yr history: Goyal
text: Railways Minister Piyush Goyal has said zero passenger death was witnessed in the current financial year, that is 2019-20, which is for the first time in the Indian Railways' 166-year-long history. A report shared by Goyal on Twitter stated that the total numbers of consequential accidents, like collisions and derailment, decreased by nearly 95% over the last 38 years.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Karl Marx's grave in London gets CCTV cover after attacks by vandals
text: CCTV cameras have been installed at Karl Marx's grave in Highgate cemetery in London after it was vandalised twice this year. The investigations into both the attacks were limited due to lack of any witnesses or forensic evidence to identify the suspect. The German philosopher's memorial is among British structures of exceptional historical interest.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Tiger pouncing towards 7-yr-old in Ireland stopped by glass barrier; video viral
text: A tiger pounced towards a seven-year-old boy at a zoo in Ireland's capital Dublin but was stopped by a glass barrier. In a video that went viral online, the boy, named Sean, could be seen smiling for the camera when the tiger pounced. "My son was on the menu in Dublin Zoo," Sean's father wrote while sharing the video.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: J&J found guilty of not passing GST rate cut benefits, fined ₹230 crore
text: The National Anti-Profiteering Authority under the GST regime has found Johnson & Johnson (J&J) guilty of not passing on GST rate cut benefits to the tune of ₹230 crore. The company has been directed to deposit the amount in consumer welfare funds of central and state governments within three months. Uttar Pradesh will receive the highest amount of ₹54 crore.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: How does India's bad loan ratio compare against other emerging economies?
text: India has the worst bad loan ratio among nine emerging economies including Brazil and China as of June at 9.2%, according to RBI's annual report on Trends and Progress of Banking in India. The ratio stood at 8.9% as on March 31. "Various sector-specific issues continued to weigh on the asset quality of banks in India," the report said.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: I used Deepika's craft in 'Chhapaak', not her star power: Meghna Gulzar
text: Director Meghna Gulzar said in an interview that she has used Deepika Padukone's craft in her upcoming film 'Chhapaak'. Commenting on using actress' star power, Meghna added, "I think that is the function of promotion and marketing, which is not me." She further said that Deepika is "so popular" that her fans will want to come and watch 'Chhapaak'.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: I'm fortunate I got to do 4 different kinds of films in 2019: Sonakshi
text: Sonakshi Sinha, who starred in four films namely 'Kalank', 'Khandaani Shafakhana', 'Mission Mangal' and 'Dabangg 3' in 2019, said that she was "very fortunate to be part of four different kinds of films". "For me, as an actor it was fulfilling and satisfying thing," she added. "I am ending the year with a nice bang...I'm very happy," Sonakshi further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Internet services restored in Lucknow after 6-day shutdown
text: Internet services in UP's capital Lucknow were restored today after a six-day shutdown that began on December 19 following violence in the anti-CAA protests.
