A man had died of an alleged firearm injury in the protests in Lucknow. As many as 10 cars, 20 motorcycles, three buses and four news vans were set on fire during protests in the city.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Dhawan scores 1st ton for Delhi since Test debut for India
text: On Day 1 of Delhi's Ranji Trophy match against Hyderabad, Shikhar Dhawan scored his first hundred for the team since 2013 when he made Test debut for Team India. Dhawan is at the crease with 137* off 198 balls. The senior opener has also made a comeback in Team India after being named in the limited-overs series against Sri Lanka.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: I want Naseem in Under-19 World Cup squad: Pakistan U-19 coach
text: Pakistan Under-19 coach Ijaz Ahmed said that he wants Naseem Shah, who became the youngest fast bowler to take a five-wicket haul in Tests, in the squad for the Under-19 World Cup if the Bangladesh series doesn't take place. Pakistan are to host Bangladesh in January for three-T20I and two-Test series but the latter has refused for Tests in Pakistan.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Pakistan's Mohammad Hafeez banned from bowling in ECB meets
text: A bowling review group has banned Pakistan all-rounder Mohammad Hafeez from bowling in tournaments conducted by the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) over illegal bowling action. Hafeez had contested an independent assessment that found his elbow's extension for off-spin delivery exceeding the 15 degrees limit. He was reported by on-field umpires during a Vitality Blast match in August.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: CM's absence at unveiling of ex-PM Vajpayee's portrait hurt me: WB Guv
text: West Bengal Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar said the absence of CM Mamata Banerjee at the unveiling of late ex-PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee's portrait at the Raj Bhavan has "hurt" him. He added that Banerjee "didn't even send a representative" for the function. "I personally know that from 2001 to 2004 Atal ji contributed hugely to career...of CM (Banerjee)," he further said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: 40 people rescued after fire breaks out in Delhi's Krishna Nagar building
text: The fire service personnel rescued 40 people after a fire broke out in a four-storey building in East Delhi's Krishna Nagar on Thursday. Plastic waste materials were stored in the ground floor, while people lived on the upper floors of the building which had one staircase. "This time...people went on the terrace and rescue operation was easy," an official said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Leh-Manali 'Atal Tunnel' will change region's fortunes: PM Modi
text: PM Narendra Modi said the "strategic" tunnel under the Rohtang Pass christened as 'Atal Tunnel', connecting Himachal Pradesh's Manali to Ladakh's Leh, "will boost tourism" and "change the fortunes of the region". It was named after late ex-PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee on his 95th birth anniversary. The 8.8 km-long tunnel is the world's longest above an altitude of 3,000 metres.
author: Shailesh

headlines: 80 suspected terrorists, 35 civilians dead in Burkina Faso clash
text: At least 35 civilians, including 31 women, were killed by suspected terrorists on Tuesday when the militants attacked a military base in Burkina Faso. Around 80 militants were killed by the Army in an attempt to repel the attack on the base. President Roch Marc Kabore declared two days of national mourning in response to the attack.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Introspect if what you did was right: PM to anti-CAA protesters in UP
text: PM Narendra Modi has condemned the violence in Uttar Pradesh during the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protests. "People who damaged public property and were involved in violence in the name of protest in UP should introspect if what they did was right," PM Modi said in his address at the foundation laying ceremony of Atal Bihari Vajpayee Medical University in Lucknow.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: CAA won't be implemented in MP till Cong is in power: CM Kamal Nath
text: Madhya Pradesh CM Kamal Nath on Wednesday said the Citizenship (Amendment) Act was against the society, Constitution and religion and announced it would not be implemented in the state till Congress was in power. "Do Modi ji and Amit Shah ji think we are illiterate? We understand their intention," said Nath who led a march against the CAA in Bhopal.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Dinda abuses bowling coach, refuses to apologise; dropped from Bengal squad
text: Fast bowler Ashoke Dinda has been dropped from Bengal squad after he abused their bowling coach Ranadeb Bose and then refused to apologise. "It shouldn’t have happened. A senior player like him...we desperately needed him for the match against Andhra," Bengal coach Arun Lal said. "The game goes on. Nobody is indispensable," Lal further said.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Sourav Ganguly’s 4-nation tournament will be flop idea, says Rashid Latif
text: Ex-Pakistan captain Rashid Latif has said that four-nation tournament proposal revealed by BCCI President Sourav Ganguly will "flop" like "Big Three model". “By playing such a series, these four countries want to isolate other member nations...which isn't good news. But I think this will be a flop idea like Big Three model, which was introduced few years back," he added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Gabbar ko sirf chota gabbar hi maar sakta hai: Dhawan shares video with son
text: Opener Shikhar Dhawan took to Instagram to share an old video of himself spending time with his son. In the video, Zoravar can be seen jokingly beating Dhawan and asking him to play cricket. "My head coach motivating me to play...Gabbar ko sirf chota Gabbar hi maar sakta hai...Zoravar and my wife are coming...and I'm so excited," Dhawan wrote.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Wisden names its five cricketers of the decade, Kohli only Indian among them
text: Wisden has named its top five cricketers of the decade, with Virat Kohli being the only Indian among them. The 'Five Wisden Cricketers of the Decade' include former Australian captain Steve Smith, Australia Women all-rounder Ellyse Perry, South Africa pacer Dale Steyn and former South Africa captain AB de Villiers. Perry was recently named ICC Women's Cricketer of the Year.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: He won my heart in 40 minutes: Ex-Pak spinner Saqlain Mushtaq on Ganguly
text: Sharing an anecdote about BCCI President Sourav Ganguly from their playing days, ex-Pakistani spinner Saqlain Mushtaq said Ganguly came to Sussex's dressing room and offered him cup of coffee during his comeback match from injury. "Ganguly enquired about my knees, life and family...We just started talking. He sat with me for 40 minutes and ended up...winning my heart," Mushtaq added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Amazon's 1st CFO was killed by van delivering company's own packages: Report
text: Amazon's first CFO Joy Covey was killed in 2013 after colliding with a van delivering the company's packages, according to a report by BuzzFeed News and ProPublica. While her collision with a delivery van was known, the new report revealed for the first time that the van was carrying Amazon packages. The driver was a subcontractor for logistics company OnTrac.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: It was once-in-a-lifetime opportunity: Designer behind Google's Santa Tracker
text: US-based creative designer Haraldur Thorleifsson on Tuesday shared the story about how he got "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" to design Google's interactive site to track Santa Claus. In a Twitter thread, he talked about how he gave all his money to designers to build the prototype and completed 6-9 months of work in just 2.5 months. "It changed my life," he added.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: US woman gets Bill Gates as secret santa on Reddit, receives 37 kgs of books
text: A 33-year-old Michigan-based woman named Shelby, who got Microsoft Co-founder Bill Gates as her secret santa on participating in 95 RedditGifts exchanges, received 37 kilograms of books as gifts. Shelby, a marketer by profession, said her box of gifts was too big to fit in her car. She also received movies, video games and Lego building sets.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Puducherry CM petitions President to recall Kiran Bedi as Lt Governor
text: Puducherry Chief Minister V Narayanasamy on Wednesday sought the intervention of President Ram Nath Kovind to recall Lieutenant Governor Kiran Bedi, saying she has been impeding the implementation of various welfare measures and decisions of his cabinet. He said that Bedi had not contributed anything to the development of Puducherry ever since she became the Lieutenant Governor.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Cutting ribbon for work of others: Akhilesh Yadav criticises BJP
text: Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav has accused the BJP-led Uttar Pradesh government of stealing the credit for the construction of Lok Bhavan as PM Narendra Modi unveiled former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee's statue at Lok Bhavan in Lucknow. Yadav tweeted that the public is ready to throw them out of power who are cutting the ribbon for others' work.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Jumla bells, jumla bells, jumlas all the way: Cong takes dig at govt
text: The Congress on Wednesday shared four illustrations targeting Prime Minister Narendra Modi and ministers in his Cabinet, captioning them, "Jumla bells, jumla bells, jumlas all the way. Oh what fun it is to see what an honest govt might say." PM Narendra Modi is saying, "All I want for Christmas is Nehru Ji's approval" in the illustration.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Who is Amba Prasad, the 31-year-old youngest MLA in Jharkhand Assembly?
text: Congress party's 31-year-old Amba Prasad is the youngest MLA in Jharkhand's new Assembly after winning from Barkagaon constituency. Her father Yogendra Prasad Sao was elected from the same seat in 2009 but was forced to resign after his links with Maoists came to light in 2014. Amba's mother Nirmala Devi fought from the same seat and won in 2014.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: 300 mn-yr-old fossil shows 'lizard' with its tail around young one
text: Canada's Carleton University researchers found the earliest evidence yet of four-limbed vertebrates looking after their young, with the discovery of an over 300 million-year-old fossil. The fossil depicts a 20 cm-long 'lizard-like' animal with its tail wrapped around its young one. The fossil predates the previous oldest record of this behaviour by 40 million years, Carleton University said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Give your name as Ranga-Billa, address as 7 RCR in NPR: Arundhati Roy
text: Author Arundhati Roy opposed the National Population Register (NPR), claiming it'll serve as a database for NRC. "When NPR authorities come...fudge your name. We'll decide on five names, such as 'Ranga-Billa', 'Kung Fu kutta'...give your address as 7 Race Course Road (now 7, Lok Kalyan Marg)," Roy said. The Prime Minister's official residence is 7, Lok Kalyan Marg, New Delhi.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: 1st university for transgender community in India to come up in UP
text: The first university for the transgender community in India will be opened in Uttar Pradesh's Kushinagar district. "In the university, the transgender community will be able to study right from class one to PG and even do research and get PhD degree," Akhil Bhartiya Kinnar Siksha Seva Trust President Dr Krishna Mohan Mishra said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: France blocks export of ₹190 crore painting found in woman's kitchen
text: France has blocked the export of an early Renaissance masterpiece found hanging in an elderly woman's kitchen and declared it a national treasure. Christ Mocked, by the 13th-century Italian artist Cimabue, sold to a foreign bidder for €24 million (₹190 crore) in October. The country now has 30 months to find funding to acquire the picture itself.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Posters of 'violent' anti-CAA protesters put up by police in Varanasi
text: The UP Police put up posters of people alleged to have instigated violence during the protests against CAA and NRC in Varanasi. The police asked the public to help identify the suspects in return for a reward and also promised to protect their identity. The UP Police used videos and CCTV footage from the scenes to obtain the suspects' pictures.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Congress misleading people on CAA by spreading lies: Anurag Thakur
text: Union Minister Anurag Thakur on Wednesday said the Congress is "misleading the people by spreading lies" on Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). "Congress party led by Sonia Gandhi is creating an atmosphere of distress among the people," he said. "While in power in 2010, they were in favour of passing the same Bill. Then why are they protesting now?" he added.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: 5th ranked Australia better than 2nd ranked NZ in Tests: Vaughan
text: Ex-England captain Michael Vaughan has said that the fifth-ranked Australia are a better Test team than second-ranked New Zealand. "I certainly don't…have New Zealand as the second-best Test match nation in the world," he said. Vaughan had earlier said that only Team India can challenge Australia in Australia.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Liquid crystal-within-crystal made, may lead to next-gen displays
text: Chicago University and Argonne National Laboratory researchers successfully developed a new way to sculpt a liquid "crystal within a crystal". Such crystals-within-crystals can reflect light at certain wavelengths that others can't and could be used for next-generation display technologies. They also can be manipulated with temperature, voltage or added chemicals, leading to low-energy sensors.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Cong's Priyanka & Rahul are live petrol bombs: Haryana Minister
text: Haryana Minister Anil Vij called Congress leaders Rahul Gandhi and Priyanka Gandhi Vadra "live petrol bombs". While urging the public to "beware", he said, "wherever they go they ignite fire and cause loss to public property". The police had stopped Rahul and Priyanka on Tuesday from going to UP's Meerut to meet families of those killed in anti-CAA protests.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Gujarat Anti-Corruption Bureau official caught taking ₹18L bribe
text: Police inspector DD Chavda attached to the Gujarat Anti-Corruption Bureau (ACB) was arrested on Tuesday for allegedly accepting ₹18 lakh in cash as bribe from a retired government servant. The government servant was the complainant in a corruption case. Deputy Superintendent of Police, ACB Ahmedabad said that further probe in the case is underway.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: J'khand CM-designate Soren meets Sonia, invites her for swearing-in
text: Jharkhand Chief Minister-designate and Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM) leader Hemant Soren met Congress President Sonia Gandhi and invited her for his swearing-in ceremony scheduled in Ranchi on December 29. Soren said he will also invite Prime Minister and Home Minister for the oath-taking ceremony. JMM-Congress-Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) alliance won the state Assembly elections claiming 47 seats.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: 50% chance Notre Dame will be entirely saved: Cathedral Rector
text: Notre Dame cathedral rector Monsignor Patrick Chauvet said that there was a "50% chance" that the cathedral will be entirely saved. He added that there's also a 50% chance that the scaffolding installed before the April fire may fall onto the three vaults of the building. "As you can see the building is still very fragile," he further said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Taliban abducts 27 members of peace group in Afghanistan
text: Taliban militants on Tuesday kidnapped 27 peace activists from a highway in Afghanistan's western Farah province, officials said on Wednesday. The activists, part of 'People's Peace Movement', were travelling with six cars when their convoy was stopped by the Taliban on a main highway. They were then taken to an unknown location.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: I was thrown out of my school when I was in fourth grade: Salman Khan
text: Salman Khan recently appeared on 'The Tara Sharma Show' and said he was thrown out of his school when he was in fourth grade. "Actually, I don't know what wrong did I do when I was growing up...I was highly recommended into another school," said Khan. "From there, they requested my earlier school to take me back," he added.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: UP DGP gets NHRC notice over violence in anti-CAA protests
text: The National Human Rights Commission of India has issued a notice to Uttar Pradesh DGP over the violence during protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The Commission said that a complainant had alleged several incidents of human rights violations. "Youth have been killed, the Internet has been suspended and the police themselves are destroying public property," the Commission said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Police acted in self-defence: Aligarh SSP on action on AMU students
text: Aligarh Senior Superintendent of Police Akash Kulhary has said that the police used non-lethal weapons as part of self-defence with minimum force on December 15 after "aggressive" students at the Aligarh Muslim University resorted to violence and "deliberately" pelted stones. "We have said from the starting that the AMU students were aggressive. They turned the situation unusual," Kulhary said.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Ashwin goes unnoticed sometimes: Ganguly on decade's highest wicket-taker
text: BCCI President Sourav Ganguly took to social media to congratulate off-spinner Ravichandran Ashwin for taking the most international wickets this decade. Sharing a post by ICC which listed the top five wicket-takers of the decade, Ganguly wrote, "Most international wickets for Ashwin this decade...what an effort...just get a feeling it goes unnoticed at times...super stuff."nn
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Sharad Pawar taught us how to form govt with less seats: Maharashtra CM
text: Maharashtra Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray said that NCP chief Sharad Pawar taught them how to form the government with less number of MLAs in the legislative assembly. The Shiv Sena had fought the Maharashtra Assembly elections in alliance with the BJP, but later broke the alliance and formed the government in coalition with the Congress and the NCP.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Quikr confirms firing 900 employees, halting of at-home beauty services
text: Bengaluru-based online classifieds platform Quikr confirmed to Inc42 that it's firing around 900 employees or 30% of workforce citing "customer demands" and "rationalisation of operating model". It also confirmed its at-home beauty services under the name AtHomeDiva have been discontinued. The clarification comes after reports claimed that Quikr fired 2,000 employees following a major scam.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Man asks Kejriwal 'Why didn't we see you with muffler this winter?', CM responds
text: A man took to Twitter to ask Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal why hasn't he started using muffler this winter. The man added, "It's very cold...the public is asking where is your muffler." Responding to the man, Kejriwal wrote, "I have been using muffler from a long time. You guys haven't noticed. It's very cold. Everyone should take care of themselves."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: 19 devotees die of cardiac arrest while trekking to Sabarimala
text: As many as 19 devotees died of cardiac arrest while trekking to Sabarimala during the ongoing pilgrimage season which began in mid-November, authorities said. Out of the 19 people, 15 passed away at Pamba, while the other four died at a government medical college, the Travancore Devaswom Board, which manages the temple, said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Family sleeps with angithi in room, 2 kids suffocate to death
text: Two children suffocated to death and four other members of their family were hospitalised in a serious condition after they slept with a coal-brazier (angithi) at their room in Punjab. The family slept with angithi still on and even closed the door, cutting off any possible ventilation, police said. Smoke engulfed the room and kids died of asphyxiation, they added.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: CBI to probe alleged Yamuna Expressway scam, books ex-CEO, 20 others
text: The CBI has taken over the probe into the alleged Yamuna Expressway scam and booked former CEO of Yamuna Expressway Industrial Development Authority (YEIDA) PC Gupta and 20 others. Uttar Pradesh government has alleged that YEIDA had purchased land in seven Mathura villages for ₹85 crore between 2013-15 which resulted in a loss of ₹126 crore to the government.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Murthy's son-in-law Rishi may run UK's new 'economic super-ministry': FT
text: Infosys Co-Founder Narayana Murthy's son-in-law Rishi Sunak is being tipped by senior Conservative Party members to run a new 'economic super-ministry', the Financial Times reported. Sunak, the UK's Chief Secretary to the Treasury, is in line for promotion to a full cabinet portfolio in a reshuffle, it added. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is expected to create an enlarged business ministry.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: US prez candidate Bloomberg says his campaign unknowingly used prisoners
text: Billionaire US presidential candidate Michael Bloomberg said his campaign unknowingly used prison workers to make telephone calls on his behalf. Bloomberg added that he came to know about it through a reporter and his campaign had ended its relations with the company that used prison labour. "We're making sure our vendors more properly vet their subcontractors moving forward," he said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Payments banks' deposit base rises over 100% to ₹883 crore in 2018-19
text: Indian payments banks saw their combined deposit base double to nearly ₹883 crore in 2018-19 compared to ₹438 crore in the previous fiscal, the RBI said in a report. However, their losses rose to ₹626.8 crore in 2018-19 from ₹515.6 crore a year ago. Payments banks can accept deposits only up to ₹1 lakh per customer and cannot lend.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Allow us to quit without serving notice period, clear our dues: Air India pilots
text: After Civil Aviation Minister Hardeep Singh Puri said Air India will have to cease operations if it's not privatised, the airline's pilots have urged the government to waive off their notice period requirement for quitting. The pilots also requested Puri to clear their dues as they are in "no position to continue working with uncertainty looming large over Air India".
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Kim, Kanye gift their daughter ₹46.7 lakh worth Michael Jackson jacket
text: Media personality Kim Kardashian and her husband Kanye West on Christmas Eve gifted their daughter, North, the original Michael Jackson jacket which he wore during actress Elizabeth Taylor's 65th birthday party. "North is...big Michael Jackson fan," Kim wrote on Instagram. She revealed that they won the jacket in an auction at a winning bid of $65,625 (approx ₹46.7 lakh).
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: We will all make our place: Janhvi on facing competition from Sara
text: Janhvi Kapoor, when asked if she sees Sara Ali Khan as her competition, said, "I think...we will all make our place in this industry." "I get motivated when I see her," she added. Thanking Sara for not signing her Bollywood debut film 'Dhadak', Janhvi said, "Things panned out well for [Sara] with...decisions she made and for me with...decisions I made."
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Trying something new in B'wood is like swimming against tide: Emraan
text: Actor Emraan Hashmi has said, "[I]t's like swimming against...tide...[w]hen you are known for a particular cinema, and you want to venture out and try something new in [Bollywood]." "There's going to be...phase where things might not work," he added. Emraan further said that the belief that people will eventually "acknowledge that someone is doing good stuff" keeps him going.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Actresses justifying gender pay gap should feel like an equal: Kangana
text: Kangana Ranaut has said that "successful actresses", who say "they don't deserve equal pay" because actors "get big openings" and actresses don't, should "feel like an equal". Adding that she doesn't feel "inferior" to others, Kangana said, "You should tell yourself...you don't have any shortcomings." Earlier, Taapsee Pannu, Alia Bhatt and Sonakshi Sinha had justified earning less than actors.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Won't survive in Bigg Boss as I can't stay away from family: Ananya
text: Actress Ananya Panday has said that, if given a chance to be in the Bigg Boss house, she wouldn't be able to survive there as she can't stay away from her family for long. "I also...[can't] leave my phone for that long actually," she added. "Like Farah (Khan)...[who]...sometimes...hosts the show with Salman sir, something like that would be...fun," Ananya said.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: We're influential people, can't randomly make statements: Ajay on CAA
text: Actor Ajay Devgn, while talking about CAA and the ongoing protests against it, said, "Because we are influential people, we need to be sensible...and know the facts before we make a statement." "We need to keep quiet till we exactly know what's happening. We can't just randomly...make statements," he added. "Our society is...tricky...people [might]...take it [in] another context," Ajay explained.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Trent Boult to play Boxing Day Test against Aus: Williamson
text: New Zealand pacer Trent Boult will play the Boxing Day Test against Australia at Melbourne Cricket Ground, skipper Kane Williamson confirmed on Wednesday. Tom Blundell will also play, replacing opening batsman Jeet Raval, Williamson further announced. Boult had missed the 1st Test against Australia after suffering from a rib injury during the 1st Test against England last month.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Won't play Tests in Pakistan, we stand firm on our ground: B'desh
text: Bangladesh Cricket Board (BCB) has said that they "stand firm" on their decision to not play Test matches in Pakistan. "We can play the T20Is but if we are to play Tests then it should be in a neutral venue," said BCB chief executive. Pakistan were to host Bangladesh in January for three T20Is and two Tests.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: We're a bit further behind than hoped: Man Utd manager Solskjaer
text: With Manchester United at the eighth spot in Premier League standings after 18 games, manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer said they are a "little bit further behind" than what he was hoping for. "This season will be used to find a team for next season," he added. The Red Devils, with 25 points, have suffered five defeats this season so far.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: I will be back within a year: Bolivia's ousted President Morales
text: Bolivia's ousted President Evo Morales said that he plans to return to his home country by next Christmas. He also said that he is helping his party prepare for an upcoming 'special election'. Morales, who ruled Bolivia for almost 14 years, left office in November after public protesters accused him of rigging the October 20 presidential polls in his favour.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Executing his murderers will hide the truth: Khashoggi's fiancee
text: After a Saudi Arabian court sentenced five people to death for journalist Jamal Khashoggi's murder, his fiancee said executing them would conceal the truth about who gave orders for the murder. "I'm calling upon every authority in the world to condemn this kind of court decision and urgently prevent any execution," Hatice Cengiz added.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Russia's most advanced Su-57 fighter jet crashes during trial
text: One of Russia's Sukhoi Su-57 stealth fighter jets, which is reportedly the country's most advanced warplane, crashed on Tuesday. Russia's United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) said the incident took place in the Khabarovsk region where the pilot ejected safely. The fighter jet was undergoing a series of flight tests when the incident happened.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Israel admits 'mistake' over Gaza strike that killed 9 in Nov
text: Israeli Army said it was a "mistake" when nine people were killed, eight of them civilians, in a strike on what it believed to be a militant Islamic Jihad compound in Gaza in November. The strike had targeted a commander of the militant group under "estimation" that the compound was "not believed to be accessible to members of the public".
author: Shailesh

headlines: Salman, Shah Rukh, Aamir should break their silence on CAA: Anubhav Sinha
text: 'Article 15' director Anubhav Sinha called on Salman Khan, Aamir Khan and Shah Rukh Khan to break their silence on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. "I am not saying they should agree with me or others. Their opinion can be the opposite of what we have," Sinha said. "I...understand why they may not be able to speak out," he added.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: She was crying, so I sent her: Ajay on Nysa going to salon after granddad's death
text: Talking about how his 16-year-old daughter Nysa was trolled after she went to a salon following his father Veeru Devgn's demise, Ajay Devgn said he had told his daughter to go as she "was crying all day". Ajay said his daughter came back home "howling" after trolls posted her pictures on social media criticising her. "It harms children," he added.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Adele posts Christmas pics after weight loss; fans say they can't recognise her
text: British singer Adele shared pictures with Grinch and Santa Claus for Christmas, following her weight loss. Thanking Grinch in her post, she wrote, "We both tried to ruin Christmas but then both our hearts grew!" Meanwhile, her fans said they can't recognise her in the pictures, with one commenting, "When people said it was you I thought they were kidding".
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Winning elections not a good reason to highlight differences between us: Harsha
text: Amid the anti-CAA and anti-NRC protests across India, commentator Harsha Bhogle penned a post on Facebook, writing, "Winning elections isn't a good enough reason for highlighting differences between us." "My naive view of the world tells me that creating opportunities through liberalisation and openness and togetherness could win more elections," Harsha further said.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Harsha Bhogle responds to Australian journalist who said 'India is broken'
text: Responding to Australian journalist Dennis Freedman calling India broken and saying PM Narendra Modi is consistently being compared to Nazis, cricket commentator Harsha Bhogle wrote, "My India isn't broken. It is full of vibrant young people doing amazing things too." He added, "We might voice our dissent, our disappointment at times but we are fiercely Indian."n
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Police shouted Jai Shri Ram during action in AMU: Fact-finding report
text: A fact-finding report on the violence at Aligarh Muslim University last week alleged that police shouted "Jai Shri Ram" while attacking students and called them "terrorists". It alleged that police fired stun grenades which are used in war-like situations however police said stun grenades are used to disperse crowds. Five students were stripped and beaten with belts, the report alleged.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Stop NPR work in Telangana, Owaisi urges CM K Chandrashekar Rao
text: AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Tuesday appealed to Telangana CM K Chandrashekar Rao to stay work on National Population Register, which is scheduled to begin in April next year. "With folded hands, I'm appealing to the CM to stop NPR which isn't good for the country," Owaisi said, hours after the Union Cabinet gave its approval for updation of NPR.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: K'taka govt withdraws ₹10 lakh ex-gratia to 2 killed in anti-CAA protest
text: The compensation of ₹10 lakh each to the family of two people killed during anti-CAA protests in Karnataka's Mangaluru has been withdrawn by the state government on Wednesday. CM BS Yediyurappa said compensation will only be given if they are found innocent after due investigation. Notably, police mentioned their names in the FIR registered in connection with the Mangaluru violence.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Let's not burden youth with talk of war, cultural differences: Harsha in FB post
text: Amid protests against CAA across India, commentator Harsha Bhogle shared a Facebook post appealing the government to not burden the next generation with talk of war and cultural differences. "Let them be...In a happy, open, secular, liberal world, they can become the best," he added. "India has been nurtured by people who are liberal and secular at heart," he wrote.nn
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: How did a Twitter app bug help match 1.7 crore phone numbers to accounts?
text: Ibrahim Balic, a UK-based Turkish security researcher, matched 1.7 crore phone numbers to Twitter users' accounts over a two-month period by exploiting a bug in Twitter's Android app. Balic found that it was possible to upload lists of generated phone numbers through Twitter's contacts upload feature. "If you upload your phone number, it fetches user data in return," he added.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Leading drone maker DJI's patent shows an all-terrain vehicle with camera
text: A new Chinese patent by Shenzhen-headquartered DJI, one of the world's leading drone makers, shows a land-based all-terrain vehicle with a suspension holding a stabilised camera. Such camera platforms can capture ground-level shots that a drone cannot capture. The rover-like vehicle could rival the Freefly Tero, a remote-controlled four-wheel vehicle designed to hold a camera.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Man pickpocketing since 2004 found living in posh flat, police recover ₹13.53L
text: A pickpocket, who was allegedly involved in over 400 cases since 2004, was arrested in Hyderabad by Government Railway Police and RPF. A total of 668 grams gold and ₹13.53 lakh in cash was recovered from him, the GRP said in a release. The GRP said he had rented a high-end flat in Hyderabad's Chandanagar area, for ₹30,000/month.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: 21-yr-old student fakes kidnapping for trip with boyfriend, then files FIR
text: A 21-year-old woman from Nagpur made a fake story about her own abduction to hide from her family that she went out with her boyfriend, police said. She and her parents filed an FIR, alleging that she was abducted by four men on her way to college. However, CCTV footage showed her getting on a motorcycle with a man.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 23-year-old woman kills 54-year-old man for sexually harassing her for 4 years
text: A 23-year-old  woman has been arrested for murdering a 54-year-old man at a playground in Washermenpet in Chennai. The woman was being sexually abused for over four years by the man, as per reports. The man had also threatened her and her family that he would leak private photos of her if she married someone else.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: 30,000 women got uterus removed to earn during menstruation: Cong to Maha CM
text: Congress' SC Department Chairman Nitin Raut on Wednesday wrote to Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray stating that around 30,000 women, working in sugarcane fields of the state, had to get their uterus removed, as they weren't getting paid during their menstrual cycle. Raut urged Thackeray to take measures so that "they don't land in a situation where they risk their lives".
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Tibetans have power of truth, China has power of guns: Dalai Lama
text: Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama said in a Christmas message, "(Tibetans) have the power of truth. Chinese communists have the power of gun. In the long run, power of truth is much stronger than power of gun." "China has one of the highest population of Buddhists. (They've) started realising the kind of Buddhism (Tibetans) practice is true," he added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Soldiers at LoC sing 'Jingle Bells' to celebrate Christmas; video goes viral
text: A video of around 30 Indian Army soldiers singing 'Jingle Bells' to celebrate Christmas at the Line of Control (LoC) in Kashmir has gone viral on social media. Two human-sized snowmen with red scarves and caps and a soldier dressed in a Santa Claus costume could also be seen in the video.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Bank robber in the US throws money in the air, shouts 'Merry Christmas'
text: A 65-year-old man who allegedly robbed a bank in the US' Colorado threw the stolen cash into the air while shouting "Merry Christmas" to passers-by. Police said he "threatened the use of a weapon" and left the bank with an undisclosed amount of cash. An eyewitness said the bystanders retrieved some of the money and returned it to the bank.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: I was fired for getting pregnant: Former Trump adviser
text: Arlene Delgado, former adviser to US President Donald Trump's 2016 campaign, has filed a sex-discrimination lawsuit, claiming she was fired after becoming pregnant following an affair with her supervisor. Delgado further alleged that Sean Spicer, who was later appointed Trump's Press Secretary, had told her that the White House is "no place for a new mom".
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Problems of corporate governance becoming evident at private banks: RBI
text: The RBI has said that "fault lines are becoming evident" in corporate governance at private banks. In its annual report on Trends and Progress of Banking in India, it highlighted the possibility of defaults rising in retail lending space. "Over the last couple of years, the space vacated by risk-averse state-run banks was taken up by private banks," it added.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Pat Cummins best bowler in the world: Aus Test skipper Paine
text: Ahead of the Boxing Day Test against New Zealand, Australia skipper Tim Paine termed teammate Pat Cummins as the "best bowler in the world". "Not just for one series, or one Test, or two Tests here or there, he has done it every game," he added. This year, Cummins became the second-fastest Australian pacer to take 100 wickets.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Players desperate to prove a point: Root ahead of Test series vs SA
text: Talking about replacements ahead of the Boxing Day Test against South Africa, skipper Joe Root said that the team has "very competitive players" who will be desperate to prove a point. The availability of several England players including Stuart Broad, Jofra Archer, is in question after they contracted "a flu-like illness".  "We're very lucky...we've got a big squad," he added.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: J'khand CM-designate Soren to meet Sonia to invite her for swearing-in
text: Jharkhand Mukti Morcha (JMM) leader and Jharkhand Chief Minister-designate Hemant Soren will meet Congress interim President Sonia Gandhi on Wednesday to invite her for his swearing-in ceremony scheduled for December 29. Soren will also invite Rahul Gandhi, Priyanka Gandhi and ex-PM Manmohan Singh. JMM-Congress-Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) alliance won the state Assembly elections claiming 47 seats.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: PM unveils 25-ft tall bronze statue of ex-PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee in Lucknow
text: On former Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee's 95th birth anniversary, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday unveiled his statue in Uttar Pradesh's Lucknow. The 25-feet tall bronze statue is located in Lucknow's Lok Bhawan. UP Governor Anandiben Patel, Defence Minister Rajnath Singh and UP CM Yogi Adityanath were present with PM Modi during the statue's unveiling.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: God continues to love us all, even the worst of us: Pope Francis
text: At the Christmas Eve mass in St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City, Pope Francis said, "Christmas reminds us that God continues to love us all, even the worst of us." He added, "How often do we think that God is good if we are good and punishes us if we are bad. Yet that is not how he is."
author: Shailesh

headlines: Pakistan not to remove Maryam Nawaz from Exit Control List
text: The Pakistan government on Tuesday decided that the name of Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) Vice President Maryam Nawaz will be kept on the Exit Control List (ECL). The cabinet unanimously rejected Maryam's request who wanted to travel London to see her ailing father Nawaz Sharif. Maryam was put on the ECL, which bars people from leaving Pakistan, in August 2018.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Brides today are looking for individuality: Designer Anamika Khanna
text: Talking about bridal wear, fashion designer Anamika Khanna has said that "there's a huge shift", as brides today "have a mind of their own." "There was a time...brides were told by their folks what to wear. But today...they're independent, well travelled...know who they want to be," she added. "They want to...be the most beautiful bride in...world," Anamika further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Loved 'Kabir Singh', he was supposed to be f**ked up: Janhvi
text: Actress Janhvi Kapoor has said that she "loved" 'Kabir Singh' because cinema as art is supposed to be a reflection of "someone's reality" and not "cater to societal norms". "If you...make sanitised, society-approved...characters, then what's the point?" she asked. "He's supposed to be f**ked up [character]...That's maybe someone's reality...You can't filter it, then it's not art," Janhvi added.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Raveena trolled for spelling mistake in her tweet, actress replies
text: Amid anti-CAA protests, Raveena Tandon tweeted a cartoon which misspelt 'protest' and 'vandalise' as 'potest' and 'vandlise' respectively. It read, "Whoever wants to potest...burn your own vehicle...vandlise...own property." A Twitter user trolled her by writing, "English to check kar lete yaar," to which she replied, "Those who want to understand will do so. I can't correct it...haven't made it."
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Sonam justifies going to Saudi music festival amid ‘human rights crisis’ there
text: After celebrities across the world were criticised for attending Saudi Arabia music festival and ignoring "human rights crisis" in the country, Sonam Kapoor justified her attendance saying, "I was treated with immense respect and love as a Hindu brown female actor." Criticising her, Instagram account Diet Prada said, "Typical tone deaf response by celebrities to receive preferential treatment."
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Disney cuts lesbian kiss scene in 'Star Wars: The Rise...' in Singapore
text: Singapore's media regulatory body has said that Disney has cut a same-sex kiss scene in 'Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker' in its Singapore release. "The applicant has omitted a brief scene, which under...Film Classification Guidelines would require a higher rating," an official said. Without the lesbian kiss scene, the latest 'Star Wars' film is rated PG-13 in Singapore.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Twitter users call Anurag casteist for anti-Mandal protests, he apologises
text: A user on Twitter asked Anurag Kashyap if he has ever joined a protest, to which the filmmaker responded, "Yes. August Kranti...Anna Hazare...protested against the Mandal Commission, 27 years ago." Many users called Anurag 'casteist' for joining anti-Mandal protests, as the Commission recommended reservation in jobs for SC, ST and OBC. Anurag apologised "for the teenager that he was."
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Muslims have 150 countries to live, Hindus only have Bharat: Gujarat CM
text: At a pro-Citizenship (Amendment) Act rally in Ahmedabad on Tuesday, Gujarat CM Vijay Rupani said that Muslims have 150 countries to go to, "for Hindus there is only one country – Bharat". Rupani added that while the population of Indian Muslims is thriving, the Hindus in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan are declining. BJP took out 62 pro-CAA rallies across Gujarat.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Can finish off anti-CAA protesters in an hour: BJP MLA
text: Amid countrywide protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, BJP MLA Lila Ram said he can wipe out those opposing CAA and NRC in an hour once he gets an order. "This India doesn't belong to Gandhiji or Jawaharlal Nehru, but to PM Narendra Modi and Amit Shah," he added. "My message was to illegal immigrants and terrorists," he later clarified.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Sachin Tendulkar's 'X' category security withdrawn by Maharashtra govt
text: Former Rajya Sabha member and cricketer Sachin Tendulkar's 'X' category security has been withdrawn after the Maharashtra government announced security revamp following the evaluation by the threat perception committee. Sachin's security previously included a police constable with him all the time. Meanwhile, MLA Aaditya Thackeray's security has been upgraded from 'Y' category to 'Z' category.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: AR tool that gives surgeons 'X-ray vision' gets US approval
text: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has approved Chicago-based startup Augmedics' augmented reality (AR) surgical tool that virtually lets surgeons have an "X-ray vision". The tool provides visualisation of a patient's anatomy in 3D, coupled with live CT images projected on surgeons' retinas. "The Xvision System is...the first of its kind for surgery," Augmedics CEO Nissan Elimelech claimed.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Visual confirmation Santa travelling south over India: ISS astronaut
text: The North American Aerospace Defence Command (NORAD) shared a video last night with ISS astronaut Andrew Morgan saying, "We have obtained visual confirmation that Santa (Claus) is currently travelling south over India." NORAD has maintained its Santa Tracker website since after a newspaper misprinted a department store's Christmas hotline number, connecting a little girl to the US defence agency.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Twitter bug lets researcher match 1.7 crore phone numbers to accounts
text: A security researcher matched 1.7 crore phone numbers to Twitter user accounts by exploiting a flaw in the micro-blogging platform's Android app. The hacker, Ibrahim Balic, found that it was possible to upload entire lists of generated phone numbers through Twitter's contacts upload feature. "If you upload your phone number, it fetches user data in return," Balic told TechCrunch.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Mann rushes towards journo during argument, stopped by AAP leaders
text: AAP MP Bhagwant Mann got into an argument with a journalist after the latter questioned his party's visibility, saying that SAD seems to be the main Opposition party in Punjab. The incident's video shows other AAP leaders stopping the MP after he rushes towards the journalist during the argument. Mann also called Sukhbir Badal "foolish child" during the argument.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: PM launches ₹6,000-cr Atal Bhujal Yojna on ex-PM Vajpayee's birth anniversary
text: PM Narendra Modi on Wednesday launched Atal Bhujal Yojana in New Delhi on the birth anniversary of former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee. The scheme aims to improve groundwater management through community participation in seven states — Gujarat, Haryana, Karnataka, MP, Maharashtra, Rajasthan and UP. The scheme is expected to benefit nearly 8,350 Gram Panchayats in 78 districts in these states.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Uber Co-founder Kalanick sells his entire stake in Uber worth $3 bn
text: Uber Co-founder and former CEO Travis Kalanick has sold his entire holdings in the ride-hailing giant worth over $3 billion since November, filings revealed. Notably, Uber on Tuesday announced Kalanick's resignation from the board, effective December 31. Kalanick was ousted as Uber CEO in 2017 over lawsuits pertaining to promoting a company culture of sexual harassment and discrimination.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Over 20 Ola, Uber drivers fined in a week for cancelling rides in Hyd
text: The Cyberabad Traffic Police fined over 20 cab and bike-taxi drivers in Hyderabad, less than a week after announcing the ₹500 fine. Cyberabad Police also warned Ola and Uber over allegations that they have started hiding details of the drivers. "It was nothing but abetting an offence and hiding details of evidence," Cyberabad Deputy Commissioner of Police (Traffic) said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Musk says people still don't need degrees to work at his companies
text: Tesla and SpaceX's billionaire founder and CEO Elon Musk, when asked if he still stands firmly on potential employees not necessarily having college degrees, said, "Yes." "There's no need even to have a college degree at all, or even high school," Musk had said in an interview in 2014. He had stated Bill Gates and Steve Jobs as prominent examples.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: NASA, Caltech design 'tweezer clock', a more precise atomic clock
text: California Institute of Technology (Caltech) and NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) researchers designed a new optical atomic clock which could be the most accurate and precise yet. Nicknamed the "Tweezer clock," it leverages 'laser tweezers' to manipulate individual atoms. "One of the goals of physicists is to be able to tell time as precisely as possible," a Caltech physicist said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: 2 students held for fake holiday order, friends gather to apologise to DM
text: Two Class 12 students in Uttar Pradesh's Noida were held on Monday for allegedly forging District Magistrate's signature and issuing fake holiday order. A day later, over 30 students from their school gathered outside DM's office, holding their ears to apologise on behalf of the two. "We understand it was wrong, but their careers will be ruined," a student said.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Haryana woman kills policeman husband, confesses to minister in letter
text: A woman in Ambala handed over a letter to Haryana Home Minister Anil Vij, "confessing" she killed her policeman husband in 2017. Vij said the woman asked him to have her hanged for the crime. She killed her "alcoholic" husband by gagging him with a piece of cloth when he was about to vomit after drinking too much, police said.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Rajasthan farmer places poisoned grains in farm, kills 23 peacocks
text: A farmer was arrested in Rajasthan's Bikaner after he was found guilty of poisoning as many as 23 adult peacocks. The farmer told authorities that he had sown vegetable seeds on his farm and later placed poison-laced grains around the nursery to avoid crop damage. Apart from the peacocks, a few pigeons and rats were also poisoned.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Delhi records longest 'extreme cold day spell' in December in 22 years
text: Delhi has recorded its "longest and extreme cold day spell" in December since 1997, with cold-day conditions prevailing for 10 days, according to India Meteorological Department. In 1997, there was a cold spell for 13 days in December. The minimum temperature recorded in Delhi on Tuesday was 5.7° C, which was its second coldest night of the season.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Video shows Delhi police asking students to vacate hostels; DCP says it's edited
text: A video has surfaced online, purportedly showing a Delhi policeman asking students in Mukherjee Nagar to vacate their hostels and PGs till January 2 and return home, citing law and order situation. He can be seen telling them about Section 144 being imposed. DCP (North-West) claimed the video is "edited", adding that they're writing to Twitter to remove the video.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Brazil Prez loses memory after slipping in bathroom, recovers it later
text: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro was hospitalised after he slipped in his bathroom at the presidential palace and lost his memory. The 64-year-old recovered his memory later and was discharged from the hospital on Tuesday. "I didn't know, for instance, what I had done during the day yesterday...I slipped forward and fell on my back. I lost my memory," Bolsonaro said.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Security of people above 'Dabangg 3' box office collection: Salman
text: Salman Khan has said that people's security comes first and then his latest release 'Dabangg 3'. Commenting on the film's box office collection, he added, "In North India, section 144 was imposed and so those collections haven't come. But they will go and see the film...first, it is their security...then comes Dabangg 3." This comes amid anti-CAA protests across India.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Sacred Games only Indian show in NYT's 30 Best shows of decade
text: 'Sacred Games' is the only Indian TV show which has been included in the New York Times' list of 30 Best International TV Shows of the decade. The list said that 'Sacred Games' "mixes Bollywood energy with a literary style and touches of magical realism." India's 'Delhi Crime' and 'Stories By Rabindranath Tagore' found Honourable Mentions.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Manoj, Diljit, Fatima to feature in 'Suraj Pe Mangal Bhari'
text: Actors Manoj Bajpayee, Diljit Dosanjh and actress Fatima Sana Shaikh have been roped in for Abhishek Sharma-directed film 'Suraj Pe Mangal Bhari'. "[It's] a...family comedy that...is set in the innocence of the 1990s when there [were]...no mobile phones," Abhishek said. Production house Zee Studios on Tuesday announced that the first schedule of the film will begin on January 6, 2020.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Goa traffic policemen dress as Santa, offer chocolates to violators
text: In a unique initiative, Goa traffic policemen on Tuesday dressed as Santa and distributed chocolates and educated traffic rule violators about safety regulations. "We used the occasion to spread the message in our own special way," an officer said. Meanwhile, Goa CM Pramod Sawant said elaborate security arrangements have been made anticipating rush of tourists in the state.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: 'Deepfaked' Home Alone movie clip features Sylvester Stallone's face
text: YouTube channel 'Ctrl Shift Face' uploaded a video titled "Home Stallone" which combined a few clips from Hollywood movies like Home Alone. It features Hollywood actor Sylvester Stallone's face 'deepfaked' onto the eight-year-old lead character's body. The seven-minute-long video follows the original story till the lead is forgotten at home but features other clips which change the storyline.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Anup Jalota sings at memorial on Vajpayee's birth anniversary; PM attends event
text: Bhajan singer Anup Jalota sang devotional songs at an event held to commemorate former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee on his birth anniversary on Wednesday. PM Narendra Modi and President Ram Nath Kovind also attended the event and paid tribute to the leader at Sadaiv Atal Memorial in Delhi. The former Prime Minister passed away aged 93 last year.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 28 people asked to pay ₹14L in UP in first notices sent out over protest damages
text: Rampur district administration in Uttar Pradesh has sent out the first set of notices to 28 residents for recovery of damage to government property, including police motorcycles, barriers and sticks, in anti-CAA protests. Holding them responsible, the notices have sought an explanation from the residents on why recoveries should not be made from them for damage worth ₹14.86 lakh.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Police have to fire when someone's life is in danger: Shah on CAA row
text: Home Minister Amit Shah while speaking on the police action during the anti-Citizenship Act protests said that police have to fire when someone's life is in danger. He added that if the police don't fire in such situations then they are not doing their duty. Shah said that incidents of police following rioters inside hospital ICUs should have been avoided.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Citizenship will not be revoked if names are missed in NPR: Shah
text: Home Minister Amit Shah on Tuesday said that it is possible that some names will be missed in the National Population Register (NPR), however, citizenship of those people will not be revoked because of it as this is not the process of National Register of Citizens (NRC). He added that nobody would lose their citizenship because of the NPR.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Tharoor backs German student asked to leave India for protesting CAA
text: Congress leader Shashi Tharoor on Tuesday tweeted in support of the German student studying in IIT Madras who was reportedly asked to return to his country for taking part in anti-Citizenship Act protests. Tharoor asked Human Resource Development Minister Ramesh Pokhriyal to instruct IIT Madras to withdraw Jakob Lindenthal's expulsion. Tharoor said that no democracy punishes freedom of expression.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Won't implement CAA if even 1 Jharkhandi is uprooted due to it: Soren
text: Jharkhand Chief Minister-Designate Hemant Soren on Tuesday said that he will not implement the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) if even one person from his state is uprooted because of it. He said that he has not gone through the documents regarding the National Register of Citizens (NRC) and the citizenship law but he would do a "holistic review" of them.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: CMs who opposed NRC should stop NPR process as well: CPI(M)
text: The CPI(M) has said that all the chief ministers who opposed the National Register of Citizens should also stop the National Population Register process. CPI(M) leader Sitaram Yechury said, "NPR is equal to NRC. How much more will the Modi government lie?" Yechury added that the government had said in Rajya Sabha that NPR is the base document for NRC.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Wisden releases ODI team of the decade, includes three Indians
text: Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli and MS Dhoni are the three Indians included in Wisden ODI team of the decade. David Warner has been named as Rohit's opening partner, while AB de Villiers has been included as number four batsman. Bowling attack includes Mitchell Starc, Dale Steyn, Lasith Malinga and Trent Boult, while Shakib Al Hasan is all-rounder in the team.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Open to discuss BCCI's proposal of 4-team event with ICC members: ECB
text: The England and Wales Cricket Board has said that a four-nation tournament was raised at a meeting with the BCCI earlier this month and added that they are open to discussions with other ICC members. The annual tournament proposed by the BCCI will involve India, England, Australia and one other invited nation.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Pyka's self-flying crop-spraying electric aircraft gets $11 million
text: American drone startup Pyka raised an $11-million seed funding round to develop its self-driving winged small aircraft, called the Egret. It aims to automate pesticide-spraying on crops. Pyka, the founding team of which comprises ex-employees of firms including Google X, Waymo and Morgan Stanley, claims to be the only global company with a commercially approved large autonomous electric aircraft.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Italian sculptor Michelangelo's 'David' 3D-printed to 0.1 cm height
text: Exaddon, a spin-off company of Swiss research university ETH Zurich's spin-off, created a 3D-printed model of Italian sculptor Michelangelo's 'David' which has a height of just 0.1 centimetre. "Michelangelo's David exists now in the size of a little ant," Exaddon wrote, naming the two-microgram model 'Tiny David'. The original David statue stands about 5.18 metre tall.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: BJP's Shazia accuses party of discrimination, clarifies 'religion not an issue'
text: Delhi BJP leader Shazia Ilmi raised an issue on party WhatsApp group that she's facing discrimination by party leadership. Ilmi said, "I never wanted to raise this through the media, but someone has leaked the internal WhatsApp group chat." "This shouldn't be seen through a religious angle, rather it has to do with politics of the state leadership," she added.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Fake FB account posted 'Ram Mandir in Mecca': Wife of K'taka man held in Saudi
text: The wife of Karnataka's Harish Bangera, who was arrested in Saudi Arabia for allegedly posting "next Ram Mandir in Mecca" on Facebook, has said the message was posted from a fake account created in her husband's name. Sumana added that she advised Harish to post an apology video to avoid trouble. Harish's employer handed him over to police, she said.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Molestation accused reaches HC dressed as woman, claims he's turning into one
text: Delhi High Court has dismissed the plea of a man who sought quashing of criminal proceedings against him for allegedly molesting a woman colleague. He came to court dressed in formal attire worn by women, wearing makeup, and claimed that he was in the process of transitioning into a female. He asserted that he has gender dysphoria since childhood.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: 12.44 lakh new jobs created in October 2019: ESIC payroll data
text: Around 12.44 lakh new jobs were created in October 2019 as compared with 12.23 lakh in the previous month, according to payroll data of Employees' State Insurance Corporation (ESIC). Gross enrolments of new subscribers with ESIC were 1.49 crore during the financial year 2018-19. During the September 2017-October 2019 period, around 3.22 crore new subscribers joined the ESIC scheme.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Centre withdraws 72 companies of security forces from J&K
text: The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) on Tuesday decided to withdraw 72 companies of the Central Armed Police Forces (CAPFs) from Jammu and Kashmir with immediate effect. It includes 24 companies of the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF), and 12 each of Border Security Force (BSF), Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP), Central Industrial Security Forcen(CISF) and Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB).
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Total frauds at banks rise 74% to ₹71,543 crore in FY19: RBI
text: Banks reported a total fraud of ₹71,543 crore in 2018-19, a 74% increase as against ₹41,167 crore in 2017-18, according to an RBI report. The number of fraud cases reported by lenders jumped to 6,801 in 2018-19, compared to 5,916 cases in 2017-18. Public sector banks (PSBs) accounted for 55.4% of the number of bank fraud cases reported in 2018-19.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: I'm not sure yet; need to think more: Saif on anti-CAA protests
text: Commenting on the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) protests, Saif Ali Khan said that there are so many things that "give us concern about what we're reading". "Until I'm sure what I'm protesting against...whether it's going to be taken that way...need to think more," he added. "There might be a possibility...I'll end up representing different kind of protest," Saif further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Fan asks Rishi to add 'sly smile' to Christmas pic, actor responds
text: Rishi Kapoor on Monday tweeted a picture of himself wishing his fans Merry Christmas. A fan commented, "Dear @chintskap...thanks but you could spread more cheer if there was the sly sweet smile of yours added to the pic." Rishi responded by sharing another picture in which he can be seen smiling with his family and captioned it, "Ye lo!"
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: JVM(P) lends support to JMM-led alliance in Jharkhand
text: Babulal Marandi's JVM(P) on Tuesday extended support for the winning alliance of JMM-Congress-RJD in Jharkhand. This came a day after results for state Assembly polls were announced. "Our party will support Hemant Soren, unconditionally, because he has the required majority," said Marandi, who is also former Jharkhand CM. JMM President Hemant Soren had earlier called on Marandi at his residence.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Chinese man involved in US hackings now teaches in China: Report
text: A Chinese malware broker, who was sentenced in the US in relation to a malicious software linked to major hackings, is working as a high-school computer teacher in China, Reuters reported. Out of the courses he teaches, one involves lessons on internet security. Yu Pingan had spent 18 months in a federal detention centre. He was arrested in August 2017.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: We could've scaled much faster in India: AngelList India Partner Somani
text: Talking about what was missing from venture capital firm AngelList's journey in India so far, AngelList India's Partner Utsav Somani said that it had a team of two till March 2019, Inc42 reported. He added the firm could have "scaled much faster". Somani also said the company was lagging behind in its product in terms of having a tech backlog.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Tunnel under Rohtang Pass to be renamed after late former PM Vajpayee
text: PM Narendra Modi-led Union Cabinet on Tuesday approved renaming of the strategic tunnel under Rohtang Pass in Manali, Himachal Pradesh after late former PM Atal Bihari Vajpayee. The renaming of the tunnel will take place on December 25, 2019, which marks 95th birth anniversary of Vajpayee. The 8.8 km-long tunnel is world's longest tunnel above an altitude of 3,000 metres.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Indo-Pak enmity reason for SAARC not prospering: B'desh Minister
text: Bangladesh Foreign Minister AK Abdul Momen said, "[S]outh Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) isn't prospering, one main reason is the enmity between India and Pakistan." He added that other regional initiative like BIMSTEC (Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical & Economic Cooperation) should do better. India and Pakistan have blamed each other for lack of progress.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Kim may give me a beautiful vase: Trump on N Korea's Christmas gift
text: US President Donald Trump said that he may get a "beautiful vase" from North Korea's leader Kim Jong-un "as opposed to a missile test" for a Christmas present. North Korea had recently said that it's up to the US to decide what Christmas gift it wants. "I may get a nice present from him (Kim Jong-un)," he added.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Backed efforts to defuse Indo-Pak tensions in 2019: China
text: Speaking on post-Pulwama tensions between India and Pakistan, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said, "China supported the efforts of the two sides to defuse tensions and manage differences through dialogue." He was answering a question on highlights of China's neighbourhood diplomacy in 2019. On February 14 this year, 40 CRPF jawans were martyred in a Jaish-e-Mohammed terror attack.
author: Shailesh

headlines: JMM's Hemant Soren to take oath as Jharkhand CM on Dec 29
text: JMM leader Hemant Soren will take the oath as the Chief Minister of Jharkhand for the second time at 1 pm on December 29. The JMM-Congress-RJD grand alliance won Assembly elections after winning 47 seats. Hemant Soren won the Assembly elections from both the seats (Dumka and Barhait) he contested.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Kapil travels with Sumona in Delhi Metro, tweets 'no need to stay in traffic'
text: Comedian Kapil Sharma on Tuesday shared pictures of himself and his television show co-star, Sumona Chakravarti, that showed them commuting in Delhi Metro. "No need to stay in traffic anymore...jus (just) take a metro," Sharma tweeted. Earlier today, Section 144 was implemented in Delhi's Mandi House amid anti-CAA protests. Delhi Traffic Police also issued an advisory for Christmas eve.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Chidambaram, Stalin among 8,000 booked for anti-CAA rally in Chennai
text: Chennai Police on Tuesday booked DMK President MK Stalin, former Union Minister P Chidambaram among 8,000 others for staging rally against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens. The rally was held by Tamil Nadu's Opposition party DMK and its allies on Monday. Cases were filed under three IPC sections for unlawful assembly and conducting rally without permission.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: I am clearly stating that there's no link between NRC and NPR: Amit Shah
text: In an interview with ANI on Tuesday, Home Minister Amit Shah said, "I am clearly stating that there is no link between NRC (National Register of Citizens) and NPR (National Population Register)." He added that data collected during NPR process will not be used for NRC. He further said that minorities especially Muslim community need not fear.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Pay taxes on time: BJP leader warns actors protesting against CAA
text: Kerala Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha (BJYM) leader Sandeep Varier warned film industry members protesting against CAA to file taxes on time lest they are raided by I-T officials. In his Facebook post, Varier addressed actors who "make political statements in front of a microphone and...public". He said, "Tomorrow, if you get caught dodging taxes, don't cry complaining of political vendetta."
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: PM Modi was right, there's no discussion on nationwide NRC: Amit Shah
text: Home Minister Amit Shah has said there is no need to debate nationwide NRC as there is no discussion on it right now. "PM Modi was right, there is no discussion on nationwide NRC yet either in the Cabinet or Parliament," he added. This comes after Shah said in the Parliament on November 20 that NRC will be implemented nationwide.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Kerala and WB CMs shouldn't stop NPR and keep poor out of benefits: Shah
text: Home Minister Amit Shah on Tuesday said that he is appealing to Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan and West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee to not stop work on the National Population Register. Shah said NPR will include the poor people who would then get benefits from the Centre. Shah added, "Don't keep the poor out of development programs for your politics."
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Fool Nahi, Cool Bano: BJP's new campaign targets anti-CAA protesters
text: Delhi BJP on Tuesday posted a number of videos on Twitter as part of a new CAA and NRC awareness campaign. The videos shared with hashtag 'Fool Nahi, Cool Bano' sought to counter 'rumours' about CAA. They urged people to 'know the truth' about the law that seeks to grant citizenship to persecuted religious minorities from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Pakistan's 16-year-old pacer Naseem Shah breaks down in press conference
text: After helping Pakistan secure a 263-run victory over Sri Lanka in Karachi Test, 16-year-old pacer Naseem Shah broke down during press conference. Shah, who became the youngest fast bowler to take a five-wicket haul in Tests, said he always wanted to dedicate his maiden five-wicket haul to his mother. Naseem lost his mother while he was touring Australia last month.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Wrestler Geeta Phogat, husband Pawan Kumar blessed with baby boy
text: Commonwealth Games gold medal-winning wrestler Geeta Phogat and her husband, wrestler Pawan Kumar, were blessed with a baby boy on Tuesday. Revealing the news on Twitter, Geeta wrote, "He is here...we are so much in love...please give him your love and blessings...he made our life perfect now...Nothing can describe the feeling of watching your own baby be born."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: I haven't forgotten how to bat: Shikhar Dhawan ahead of 2020 season
text: Ahead of T20I series against Sri Lanka in January, opener Shikhar Dhawan said, "I was hit on finger, then on the neck, bruised eye and then stitches on the knee. Good news is New Year is coming." He added, "The start-stop thing doesn't affect me as I haven't forgotten how to bat. My class is permanent and I'll score runs."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Prostitution racket operating through mobile apps busted in Mumbai
text: The Social Service (SS) branch of the Mumbai Crime Branch on Tuesday busted a prostitution racket that was being run through mobile phone apps like Bingo, WhatsApp and TikTok. The police arrested two people and rescued three women from a hotel. The police are searching mastermind Jayesh Bora, who provided customers with a link of an app to choose women.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Told him I'll always be a loser to my kids due to you: Mahindra on meeting Gates
text: Anand Mahindra tweeted about his meeting with Microsoft Co-founder Bill Gates during his first India trip in 1997 and tweeted that he told Gates, "Thanks to you, I'll always be a loser to my kids!" Mahindra said his daughter asked about Mahindra's classmates from Harvard who became famous. When Mahindra mentioned Gates, she replied, "What a loser you are Dad!"
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Uber Co-founder Travis Kalanick to leave the company's board
text: US-based ride-hailing major Uber on Tuesday announced that Co-founder Travis Kalanick will resign from the company's Board of Directors effective December 31, 2019. In a statement, Kalanick said, "At the close of the decade, and with the company now public, it seems like the right moment for me to focus on my current business and philanthropic pursuits."
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: BHU student refuses to accept degree over arrest of anti-CAA protestors
text: Rajat Singh, a student of Banaras Hindu University, refused to accept his degree over the arrest of nearly 70 anti-CAA protestors in Uttar Pradesh's Varanasi on Tuesday. "I oppose these arrests. I oppose the law. I oppose any law that attempts to divide the nation," Rajat said. Further, Rajat condemned the BHU administration for being indifferent towards the arrests.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: 200 engineering grads vandalise JSW office alleging 'unfulfilled' job assurances
text: Over 200 engineering graduates on Tuesday vandalised the office of a company owned by the JSW Group in Odisha's Paradip, alleging it didn't keep its assurance of giving them jobs. Members of the students' organisation of Biju Patnaik University of Technology allegedly barged into the office of JSW Infrastructure Ltd. They broke furniture, computers and other articles inside the office.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Spanish teacher wears bodysuit showing internal organs to teach anatomy
text: A 43-year-old Spanish school teacher, Veronica Duque, wore a bodysuit depicting human anatomy for her students to teach them about the subject. "Knowing how hard it's for kids this young to visualise the disposition of internal organs, I thought it was worth giving it a try," she said. Duque added that she had found the suit online by pure chance.
author: Shailesh

headlines: No HC order on petition for recovery of damages in Jamia incident
text: The Delhi High Court on Tuesday refused to pass an order on a petition by BJP leader Ashwini Upadhyay seeking permission to file an intervention application in Jamia Millia Islamia (JMI) violence. Upadhyay stated that the violence resulted in over ₹20 crore worth of damage to public property. The Court didn't accede to the request and said, "We will see."
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Pondicherry University graduates boycott convocation over CAA
text: Several Pondicherry University graduates boycotted their convocation ceremony held on Monday amid nationwide protests against CAA and NRC. The event was presided over by President Ram Nath Kovind. Among those who boycotted the event was a gold-medallist MSc graduate in Electronic Media. University students' council had urged students to boycott the event as a mark of protest.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Proposed CO2 capture system could reduce truck emissions by 90%
text: Researchers at Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (EPFL) patented a new concept that could cut trucks' carbon emissions by almost 90%. The system used in the concept captures released CO2 and converts it into liquid and stores it on vehicle's roof. The liquid is later delivered to a service station where it is turned back into fuel using renewable energy.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Indian apps surpass Chinese apps in downloads in India in 2019: Study
text: Indian apps have reclaimed their top position as the most downloaded apps according to an AppsFlyer study called 'State of App Marketing in India 2019'. The study noted that Indian apps recaptured their position as the largest group in top 200 apps in India (by install volume). Last year saw Chinese apps at the top position in the Indian market.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Startups showcase high-tech products for Indian Army
text: Indian Army invited 10 startup innovators to a seminar to showcase their high-tech products which the military could use. Army Chief Bipin Rawat also released statements mentioning the issues around which the startups must try to build their products. Currently, the ideas which won previous challenges by the Army are being funded for developing their proposed products.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: PhonePe needs 3 to 4 years to achieve profitability: CEO Sameer Nigam
text: PhonePe's CEO Sameer Nigam told Business Standard that the digital payments app needs another three to four years and an additional $1 billion-fund to achieve profitability. "We need capital to grow...We have something good going on here," Nigam said. Earlier this month, PhonePe received $82 million from its Singapore parent entity PhonePe Private Limited.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: SpaceX runs 10th-straight successful multi-chute Crew Dragon test
text: SpaceX successfully completed its 10th consecutive multi-chute system test for safe launching and landing of crewed spacecraft flights. This system controls SpaceX's Crew Dragon commercial spacecraft's descent. In November, SpaceX announced 13 successful tests of upgraded Mark 3 parachutes for Crew Dragon. It demonstrated system's ability to land safely even if one of four main parachutes failed.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: 5 hospitalised after Australian mall stampede during gift giveaway
text: Five people were hospitalised and 12 others were treated at the scene by paramedics after a stampede ensued at a mall in Australia during a gift vouchers giveaway. Hundreds of people had gathered at the mall for the release of balloons containing the gift vouchers. Footages from the incident show the crowd rushing to collect the ballons after their release.
author: Shailesh

headlines: China, S Korea, Japan agree to promote US-N Korea nuclear talks
text: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, Japanese PM Shinzo Abe and South Korean President Moon Jae-in, at a trilateral summit, agreed to work towards promoting US-North Korea denuclearisation talks. Li said that "dialogue and consultation is the only effective way to solve the issues of the Korean Peninsula". Free trade and economic cooperation were also discussed at the summit.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Nepal detains 122 Chinese for suspected cyber, financial crimes
text: Nepal Police, in coordination with Chinese Police, has detained 122 Chinese on suspicion of being involved in cyber and financial crimes. Laptops and passports of the suspects were seized while they are held at different police stations, Kathmandu chief of police said. "This is the first time that so many foreigners have been detained for suspected criminal activities," he added.
