The reserves jumped to $433.70 billion as of September against $412.87 billion in March. At the end of September, the foreign exchange reserves cover of imports stood at 10 months.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Got big shoes to fill if I debut in web series: Kareena on Saif's work
text: Actress Kareena Kapoor, while referring to her husband Saif Ali Khan's work in web show 'Sacred Games', said, "I've big shoes to fill in if I ever debut on a digital platform." "But right now I have not got any...interesting...offers," she added. Kareena further called Saif a "brave actor" who turned his career around in digital space with 'Sacred Games'.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Chulbul Pandey is corrupt, will be most hated guy in real life: Salman
text: Salman Khan has said his character from the Dabangg franchise, Chulbul Pandey, is an "obnoxious guy" and will be the most hated guy in real life. He added such a character, who's a "perfect husband", is "corrupt" and "does wrong things but for the right reasons", looks good on screen but nobody would like such a personality in real life.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Used to think I didn't have the face of a hero: Vicky Kaushal
text: Actor Vicky Kaushal has revealed that since he was "a lanky boy" and "only those with a chocolate boy image could become a hero", he used to think he "didn't have the face of a hero". "Back then, there were no actors...only...heroes," Vicky said. He added that there is no definition of a hero now and people focus on talent.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: I'm with the students: Siddhant Chaturvedi on anti-CAA protests
text: Siddhant Chaturvedi has said he's supporting all the students who're protesting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in various parts of the country. "I wanted to be there...but I was shooting," he added. Siddhant further said he didn't put out the first look of his upcoming film, 'Bunty Aur Babli 2', till late evening because he was affected by the protests. n
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: CAA is one more nail in the coffin of a democratic India: Jim Sarbh
text: Talking about the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Jim Sarbh said, "You have to view the Bill (now an Act) from...context of history, and...context of history is the current government [has] an ongoing theme of...intimidation and persecution of Muslims." "In these extremely biased hands, I believe that [the] law is one more nail in the coffin of...democratic, secular India," Jim further said.n
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Dhanush, Vijay share Best Tamil Actor at Filmfare Awards South
text: Dhanush and Vijay Sethupathi shared the Best Tamil Actor (Popular) for 'Vada Chennai' and ''96', respectively, at 2019 Filmfare Awards South.  While Ram Charan won the Best Telugu Actor (Popular) for 'Rangasthalam', Yash won the Best Kannada Actor (Popular) for 'K.G.F: Chapter 1'. Meanwhile, Trisha bagged the Best Tamil Actress (Popular) and Keerthi Suresh took the Best Telugu Actress (Popular).
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Saini makes ODI debut after replacing Chahar in 3rd ODI
text: Delhi fast bowler Navdeep Saini made his ODI debut after replacing Deepak Chahar in the third ODI against West Indies on Sunday. The 27-year-old had made his international debut in August when he faced the Windies side in the first T20I in India's tour of West Indies. Saini has played five T20Is so far and has picked up six wickets.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Razorpay appoints ex-American Express exec Arpit Chug as CFO
text: Payments provider Razorpay has named former American Express India Chief Financial Officer (CFO) Arpit Chug as its new CFO. As part of the new role, he will work with Razorpay's lending arm Razorpay Capital and its neo-banking platform RazorpayX. Chug worked with American Express for over 17 years, leading financial teams across different verticals.nn
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Preliminary results show Prez Ghani winning Afghan Prez polls
text: Preliminary results of the September 28 Afghan presidential polls show that President Ashraf Ghani has won 50.64% of the total vote, giving him a majority. However, the final results will be announced later and the Independent Election Commission (IEC) will also address complaints by candidates during the period. Afghan Chief Executive Officer Abdullah Abdullah won 39.52% of the total vote.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Stand up and respect Parliament for CAA: PM Modi to crowd at Ramlila Maidan
text: While addressing people at Delhi's Ramlila Maidan, PM Narendra Modi asked the crowd to stand up and respect Parliament for the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019. Accusing rival political parties of creating fear and chaos, and trying to defame India abroad, PM Modi said, "We've never asked anyone if he goes to temple or mosque when it comes to implementing schemes."
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Burn my effigy if you hate me, don't mislead people: PM to rivals on CAA
text: PM Narendra Modi while addressing people in Delhi said, "My rivals should burn my effigy if they hate me but they should not mislead the people on Citizenship (Amendment) Act." "Rumours being spread that Muslims will be sent to detention centres," he added. "I challenge those spreading lies to find anything discriminatory in any of my works," PM Modi added.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Akshay Kumar gets criticised by Twitter users for 'abusing Lord Ram' in dialogue
text: Several Twitter users criticised Akshay Kumar for allegedly abusing Lord Ram in a dialogue in the new trailer of 'Good Newwz'. In the trailer, a man says, "My child's name is Hola Ram as he was born during Holi", to which Akshay replies, "It's good that he wasn't born during Lohri." A user commented, "How dare you abuse...[G]ods of India?"
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Atif Aslam welcomes 2nd child with wife Sara, shares 1st pic of newborn
text: Pakistani singer Atif Aslam on Saturday announced the birth of his second child with wife Sara Bharwana. "Ladies and gentlemen our NEW arrival Alhamdulilah. Both mother and baby are fine. Keep us in your prayers and don't forget to say Mashallah," he wrote. Atif and Sara are also parents to a boy named Ahad Atif, who was born in 2014.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Acid attack survivor who inspired Chhapaak denies being paid 'only ₹13 lakh'
text: Acid attack survivor Laxmi Agarwal, who's the inspiration behind Deepika Padukone starrer 'Chhapaak', took to Instagram to deny reports of being upset for getting paid "only ₹13 lakh" for the film. Sharing screenshots of some reports, Laxmi wrote, "It's a fake news." Directed by Meghna Gulzar, 'Chhapaak' is scheduled to release on January 10, 2020.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Dia shares pic of Mumbai sky, says 'skyline not visible due to pollution'
text: Actress Dia Mirza on Saturday shared a picture of the Mumbai sky and wrote that the skyline isn't visible. "No, #Mumbai this isn't winter fog. It is #AirPollution," she added while also sharing a screenshot of the Air Quality Index (AQI) in Mumbai. "Can't even see the skyline. The air is so bad," Dia had written on her Instagram Story.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Little irritating when people repeatedly call me Vicky's brother: Sunny Kaushal
text: Speaking about being called "Vicky Kaushal's brother" by the media, actor Sunny Kaushal said, "What they say is factually correct but...with time the tag shall pass and I shall make my own space here." "It's a little irritating when people repeatedly say so, but I understand where they're coming from," he added. Sunny had starred in the 2018 film 'Gold'.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Tharoor trolls Paresh Rawal over his 'Myanmar to India - 1769 kms' tweet
text: Shashi Tharoor trolled actor and BJP MP Paresh Rawal over his tweet in which he wrote, "Myanmar to India - 1769 kms, Myanmar to China - 2km. But why the Rohingyas want to come to India? and not China?" "What's with these BJP netas & their schooling...Paresh Rawal clearly didn't pay attention in geography class!" Tharoor tweeted.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: News of Parineeti's removal from 'Beti Bachao...' over CAA tweet false: Govt
text: Spokesperson of Women & Child Development Department, Haryana Government denied reports of Parineeti Chopra's removal as 'Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao' campaign's state brand ambassador over her tweet against violence on students amid anti-CAA protests. "MoU was for 1 year, till April, 2017," the spokesperson said. Earlier, Haryana Congress leaders criticised state government over her alleged removal.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Feels like 2nd life: Policeman after bullet pierces his vest, gets stuck in wallet
text: Police constable Vijendra Kumar in Uttar Pradesh's Firozabad had a narrow escape on Saturday after a bullet fired during anti-CAA protest pierced through his bulletproof vest and got stuck in the wallet. "There were four ATM cards and pictures of Shiv Ji and Sai Baba (in the wallet)," he said. "It feels like this is my second life," Kumar added.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Godhra-like situation may arise if majority lose patience: K'taka Minister
text: Amid the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protests, Karnataka Minister CT Ravi said that a 'Godhra-like' situation can arise if the majority "lose patience". This comes after Congress leader UT Khader said that Karnataka will burn if the Citizenship (Amendment) Act is implemented. "Just because the majority community here is patient, you are trying to put fire everywhere," Ravi also said.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Unprovoked targeting of innocent students: Jamia in its report to MHRD
text: Jamia Millia Islamia submitted a fresh report to the Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD) requesting a judicial inquiry into police's entry in the university last week. "This unprovoked targeting of the innocent students who have nothing to do with crowd resulted into severe and inhuman beating," the report said. A student lost his eyesight during police action, it added.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Anti-drone teams, snipers deployed for PM Modi's rally in Delhi
text: Security has been tightened and a special traffic arrangement has been made for PM Narendra Modi's rally on Sunday at Delhi's Ramlila Maidan. A police official said as many as 1,000 personnel from local police, anti-drone teams and NSG commandos have been deployed. "No commercial vehicle will be allowed from Raj Ghat to Delhi Gate crossing," the traffic police said.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: MP kisses policeman's shoe to protest politician's 'will make police lick my boots' remark
text: YSR Congress Party MP Gorantla Madhav kissed the shoe of a policeman in Andhra Pradesh's Anantapur to protest against former TDP MP JC Diwakar Reddy's remark on police. Reddy had said he'll "make police lick his boots" after TDP returns to power in the state. Anantapur District Police Officers' Association has sought an unconditional apology from Reddy for his remark.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: 2 men beat a man after tying him to tree, one urinates in his mouth in Odisha
text: Two men tied a man to a tree and beat him before one of them urinated in his mouth after he asked for water in Odisha's Khordha district. Police said that the incident seems to have been triggered over past enmities. The police added that a case has been lodged and the two accused have been arrested.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Pak sentences university professor to death for alleged anti-Islamic FB posts
text: A Pakistani court on Saturday convicted a 33-year-old university professor of blasphemy, sentencing him to death for allegedly spreading anti-Islamic ideas on Facebook. The charges against Junaid Hafeez, who was arrested in March 2013, included liking an allegedly blasphemous Facebook page. His lawyer said the decision was "unfortunate", adding, "We will appeal against this verdict."
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Cuba gets its first Prime Minister since 1976
text: Cuban President Miguel Díaz-Canel has appointed Manuel Marrero Cruz as the country's first Prime Minister in more than 40 years. The post of Prime Minister, which was scrapped in 1976 by the then-revolutionary leader Fidel Castro, was reinstated under the rules of a new constitution passed earlier this year. Cruz is also serving as the Tourism Minister.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Students don't have any religion, we must empower them: Ayushmann
text: Talking about the ongoing protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, actor Ayushmann Khurrana said the government should realise that there shouldn't be a communication gap between them and the students. He added that students are the future of the country and we should empower them. "This is not just about minority institutions. Students don't have any religion," Ayushmann further said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: His humour binds us together: Giorgia on boyfriend Arbaaz Khan
text: Model-actress Giorgia Andriani, while talking about her boyfriend and producer Arbaaz Khan, said, "It's his humour that binds us together. [W]e are always laughing and cracking jokes." "He keeps me balanced. I live in my fairytale...he...[brings] me back to the real world," she added. Giorgia further said that she likes Arbaaz's laughter and his positivity keeps her going.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Passed out drunk at award show, woke up and thought I had died: Margot
text: Australian actress Margot Robbie has revealed that when she was 18 years old, she "got so drunk" at an award show that she "passed out in one of the toilet stalls". She added that as no one was around when she woke up, she thought, "Did I die? Is this purgatory?" "[I]t was such a weird surreal experience," Margot said.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: James Bond actress Claudine Auger passes away at 78
text: French actress Claudine Auger, known for starring in 'James Bond' film 'Thunderball', passed away following a "long period of illness" at the age of 78 in Paris. With 'Thunderball', she became the first French actress to feature as a Bond girl in the franchise. Auger is also known for starring in films like 'Triple Cross' and 'The Killing Game'.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Surprised that people liked my negative character in 3 idiots: Boman
text: Talking about his film '3 Idiots', Boman Irani said he's "pleasantly surprised" that people liked his "unhappy" and "negative" character, Viru Sahastrabudhhe, in the film. "[It] redeemed himself in the end and that's what helps add to the relatable nature of the character," he added. Boman further said the film is special to him and he's grateful that it's loved.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: 'Kalank' was my first failure as an actor: Varun Dhawan
text: Actor Varun Dhawan, while talking about the poor box-office performance of Abhishek Verman-directed film 'Kalank', said, "It was my first failure as an actor." "I think ups and downs are a part of life and we learn from it," he added. Varun further said that he has now put all his positive energy into his upcoming film 'Street Dancer 3D'.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: 'The Irishman' may be the last film I'll make: Scorsese
text: Martin Scorsese has said theatres have been controlled by the superhero films and there's no room left for other kinds of films. "You have 12 screens and 11 are...superhero [films]. You enjoy superhero films, fine, but you need 11 screens?" he questioned. "I don't know how many more I can make, maybe this is...the last one ('The Irishman')" Scorsese added.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Decomposed body of Sahitya Akademi awardee Nanjundan found at his home
text: Bengaluru Police found the decomposed body of Kendra Sahitya Akademi award winner G Nanjundan on Saturday from his residence. According to the police, Nanjundan lived alone and had not turned up for classes at Bangalore University, where he worked as a professor, for the past few days. As per reports, cardiac arrest is suspected to be the cause of death.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: SpiceJet crew misbehaved with me: BJP MP Pragya Thakur
text: BJP MP Pragya Singh Thakur filed a complaint against SpiceJet, accusing the airline crew of misconduct and refusing to allot her the seat she had booked. "I informed the authorities that the SpiceJet crew had misbehaved with me. This has happened once before as well," Thakur said. Bhopal Airport Director Anil Vikram said an inquiry into Thakur's complaint is underway.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: 15 people killed, 705 arrested in anti-CAA protests in UP since Dec 10
text: At least 15 people have died across Uttar Pradesh in the violence during protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Praveen Kumar, IG (Law and Order), said. Since December 10,  705 people have been arrested and around 4,500 people were released after preventive arrest. Out of the 263 injured police personnel, 57 personnel received firearm injuries, he added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Internet services to be suspended in Jaipur tomorrow from 6 am, metro from 8 am
text: Jaipur Commissionerate has announced that Internet services in the capital city of Rajasthan will remain suspended between 6 am and 8 pm on Sunday to maintain law and order situation. The Jaipur Metro Rail Corporation has also announced the suspension of metro services from 8 am to 2 pm on Sunday for safety and security reasons.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: How can a Test end as drawn, not tied when scores are level?
text: A Test is considered drawn, and not tied if the batting team has wickets remaining when the time expires, even if the scores are level. A Test can be termed tied only if the chasing side gets all-out with the scores level. The Bulawayo Test between England and Zimbabwe was declared drawn with the scores level, on December 22, 1996.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Chinese woman proposes to boyfriend with property deed, BMW keys; video viral
text: A video of a Chinese woman proposing to her boyfriend with a property deed and keys to a BMW has gone viral on social media. The woman proposed to her boyfriend on December 11, exactly a year after they started dating. The woman's family sponsored the house and car, local media reported.n
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Sourav Ganguly should allow his daughter to share her views freely: Nagma
text: Actress-politician Nagma has urged BCCI President Sourav Ganguly to allow his daughter Sana to share her views freely. This comes after Ganguly said his daughter was too young to know about anything in politics and denied that Sana posted anything on Instagram regarding CAA. "I congratulate @sanaganguly on her views on the current situation prevailing in the country," she added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: BJP announces contact programme to 'expose opposition lies' on CAA
text: BJP on Saturday announced a mass contact programme "to expose Opposition parties' lies" on Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). The campaign will also inform people about the National Register of Citizens (NRC). BJP general secretary said, "BJP...will contact [over] three crore families, organise rally in every district...hold over 250 press conferences...to inform masses about the new law."
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Don't fall into trap of communalism: 1,000 academics write in support of CAA
text: Over 1,000 academics, intellectuals and research scholars released a statement in support of CAA. An atmosphere of fear and paranoia is being created in the country by "fear-mongering", the group said and urged people not to fall into the trap of "propaganda and communalism". CAA doesn't prevent any other ethnicities seeking citizenship through regular processes, the statement read.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Govt should include Muslims under CAA: BJP ally Shiromani Akali Dal
text: BJP ally Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) said the government should include Muslims under the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. "People of all religions reside in our country...this is our strength that they stay together as a team," SAD President Sukhbir Singh Badal said. CAA seeks to grant Indian citizenship to persecuted Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Christians, Jains, and Parsis from neighbouring countries.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Mobile Internet services restored in Meghalaya after 8 days
text: Mobile Internet services were restored in Meghalaya on Friday, eight days after they were suspended in the wake of anti-CAA protests, an official said on Saturday. According to a Meghalaya Home Department official, the ban imposed on mobile Internet, bulk messaging services and operation of social media platforms was lifted after the law and order situation improved in the state.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Bhim Army chief denied bail, remanded to 14 days judicial custody
text: Bhim Army chief Chandran Shekhar Azad's bail plea was dismissed by a Delhi Court on Saturday. Azad was arrested earlier today for leading a protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act. FIR against Azad alleged that he "instigated the crowd" to march from Jama Masjid to Delhi Gate where the crowd turned violent. Azad was remanded to 14 days judicial custody.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Breaking, Shaheen can now bowl inswingers too, serious talent: Ramiz Raja
text: After Pakistan pacer Shaheen Afridi took his maiden five-wicket haul in Tests, ex-Pakistani batsman Ramiz Raza tweeted, "Breaking: Left armer Shaheen Afridi can now bowl in swingers too!" He added, "It means he now has a complete set of skills to take 300 Test wickets and be a force in all formats! And all that at 19. Serious talent."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Alphabet grants new CEO Sundar Pichai largest ever stock award again
text: Alphabet's new CEO Sundar Pichai would receive $240 million in performance-based stock awards over next three years, the highest ever promised to any executive of the company. In 2016, he received $199 million in stock awards, the highest ever for any Alphabet executive back then. Pichai, who is also Google's CEO, will take home $2 million in salary starting 2020.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Kerala Guv Arif Khan supports CAA, says govt kept Gandhiji, Nehru's promises
text: Backing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Kerala Governor Arif Mohammed Khan has said the Centre kept promises that Mahatma Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru and Congress had made to people who were living deplorable lives in Pakistan. He said the Act's foundation was laid in 1985 and 2003. "Pakistan was formed as a Muslim nation, so will they persecute Muslims there?" he questioned.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Arrest warrant against Tharoor for defaming 'Nair' community women in book
text: A court in Trivandrum today issued an arrest warrant against Congress MP Shashi Tharoor in connection with a case filed against him for allegedly defaming 'Nair' community women in his book. The book in question is the 'The Great Indian Novel' published in 1989. The warrant comes after Tharoor failed to present himself or through his lawyer at the court.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Death penalty awarded to man for murdering, raping engg student in Ranchi
text: A CBI court on Saturday awarded death penalty to a man who had raped an engineering student and later burnt her to death in Jharkhand's capital Ranchi in 2016. The CBI, during its investigation, found that the accused was a habitual offender and had been in Lucknow jail in connection with another rape.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Decathlon refuses to sell to IAS officer without contact info, he says it's illegal
text: A Decathlon store in Bengaluru refused to sell products to IAS officer Captain P Manivannan who declined to share his contact details. Manivannan said it's not legal to deny service because a customer refuses to share such details. Decathlon replied, "We'll not take risk of selling to customers who we cannot contact for emergencies, or whose purchase history isn't recorded".
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Muslim nations consider gold, barter trade to beat future sanctions
text: Iran, Malaysia, Turkey and Qatar are considering trading among themselves in gold and through a barter system to protect their economies against potential future sanctions, Malaysian PM Mahathir Mohamad said.  At the end of an Islamic summit in Malaysia, Mahathir said it was important for Muslim countries to be self-reliant. He praised Iran and Qatar for withstanding economic embargoes.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Homeless man in Germany attacks cyclist to go to prison; jailed for life
text: A homeless man has been jailed by a German court for deliberately knocking down a cyclist in June in an attempt to go to prison. The court said that he was motivated by greed and therefore his act qualified as attempted murder. The 48-year-old victim is still suffering from the psychological and physical effects of the accident, reports said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Ex-White House Press Secretary apologises for mocking Joe Biden's stutter
text: Former White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders has apologised for mocking former US Vice President Joe Biden's stutter. "I've worked my whole life to overcome a stutter. And it's my great honour to mentor kids who have experienced the same. It's called empathy. Look it up," Biden had tweeted in response to Sarah's tweet mocking him.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Jaypee Group loses 1,000-hectare land that has India's only F1 circuit
text: The Yamuna Expressway Authority cancelled the allotment of 1,000 hectares of land to Jaypee Group on which India's only Formula One motor racing circuit is built. The company defaulted on payments of over ₹500 crore, it said. The authority added that modalities are being framed to safeguard the interests of third parties who invested in projects on this land parcel.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Govt tries to stop Mukesh Ambani's Reliance from selling assets
text: The government is trying to stop Reliance Industries from selling its assets including a plan to sell 20% stake in its refining and petrochemicals business to Saudi Aramco. The demand was made in a case against Reliance and British Gas in Delhi High Court. The government has sought to prevent them from selling assets, and honouring a $4.5-billion arbitration award.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: I just go by my gut feeling: Rakul Preet Singh on her film choices
text: Rakul Preet Singh has said that there are different factors involved when it comes to choosing a script. "Sometimes you love the script...the character, the director or the setup," she added. "Sometimes it's also an actor you really want to work with, even when you don't have a strong role. I just go by my gut feeling," Rakul further said.n
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Shivam Dube, Jason Holder play table-tennis ahead of 3rd ODI
text: The BCCI and the Windies cricket board shared a video of Indian all-rounder Shivam Dube playing table tennis against Windies' all-rounder Jason Holder ahead of the sides' 3rd ODI in Cuttack. In the video, both the players can be seen scoring a couple of points off each other, while Shreyas Iyer can be seen watching the match between the two.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: City manager Pep Guardiola best in the world: Zinedine Zidane
text: Real Madrid manager Zinedine Zidane has termed the Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola as "best coach in the world". "I respected him a lot as a player and I do as a coach," he added. Real Madrid, who won the Champions League title thrice under Zidane, will face Guardiola's side in the knockouts phase of Champions League this season.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: US' Coral raises $4.3 mn to build at-home manicure machine: Report
text: California-based Coral Labs has reportedly raised $4.3 million to build an at-home manicure machine that paints nails by just sticking a finger in and waiting for few seconds.The machine paints one nail at a time and takes about 10 minutes to produce a fully-painted, dried nail. It uses a hooded camera and some proprietary computer vision algorithms to paint accurately.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Apple opens its $1 mn fault-finding bounty programme for all
text: Apple has now opened its bug bounty programme for all security researchers, offering up to $1 million in reward for discovering major flaws in its operating systems. Earlier the programme used to be invite-only and exclusively offered payouts for iOS bugs. Now, it includes all the operating systems, including macOS, tvOS, watchOS and iCloud.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Mumbai-Nagpur Expressway to be named after Bal Thackeray: Maha govt
text: Maharashtra government on Friday said the upcoming Nagpur-Mumbai Expressway will be named after Shiv Sena founder Balasaheb Thackeray. Maharashtra cabinet earlier gave approval to naming the project 'Hindu Hruday Samrat Balasaheb Thackeray Maharashtra Samruddhi Mahamarg'. The expressway, which is expected to cost ₹46,000 crore, will cut travel time between the two cities to around eight hours.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Anurag Kashyap's Twitter followers drop to 76,000 from 5.2 lakh
text: Filmmaker Anurag Kashyap's Twitter follower count has dropped from more than 5,25,000 to about 76,000. Many users on the microblogging platform said they were earlier following Kashyap but their accounts automatically unfollowed him. Kashyap posted a screenshot of his current followers and said, "And Twitter has drastically reduced my followers".
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Cong not on streets against CAA, NRC: JD(U)'s Kishor on Sonia's video
text: JD(U) Vice-President Prashant Kishor on Saturday criticised Congress leadership for its 'absence' from "citizens' fight against CAA-NRC." "The least [the] party could do [is] to make ALL Congress CMs join...CMs who...said they will not allow NRC...Or else these statements [mean] nothing," he tweeted. This came in response to Congress Chief Sonia Gandhi's video statement criticising CAA and NRC.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Kerala couple protests CAA, NRC with pre-wedding photoshoot, pics go viral
text: Pictures of a Kerala couple holding placards protesting the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens (NRC) in their 'save-the-date' photoshoot have gone viral. "We both wanted to pass on a positive message. We never thought it would be accepted so widely," the man said. Reacting to one of their pictures, actress Swara Bhasker wrote, "Pic of the day."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Missed exam application deadlines due to 9-day Assam Internet ban: Students
text: Several students in Assam said they missed deadlines to apply for competitive examinations due to the Internet ban in the state in the wake of protests over the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. Internet services were banned in Assam on December 11 and were restored on Friday. The Gauhati HC had ordered to restore Internet services following several PILs challenging the ban.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Sonia, Rahul to lead Congress protest against CAA at Raj Ghat tomorrow
text: Congress will hold a 'dharna' at Raj Ghat tomorrow from 2 pm to 8 pm against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens. Congress' interim President Sonia Gandhi and Rahul Gandhi will lead the protest. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Narendra Modi will be addressing a rally in Delhi's Ramlila Maidan tomorrow.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: BBL match in Australia's capital Canberra called off due to bushfire smoke
text: The Big Bash League match between Sydney Thunder and Adelaide Strikers in Australia's capital Canberra was abandoned due to heavy bushfire smoke on Saturday. Around 100 fires were burning across Australia's New South Wales, of which six were characterised as "emergency level". "We can smell the smoke and the air quality itself is something else," one of the umpires said.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Virat Kohli turns 'Santa Claus', surprises kids in Kolkata shelter home with gifts
text: Team India captain Virat Kohli surprised kids at a shelter home in Kolkata by turning Santa Claus for them and presenting them with gifts. After distributing the gifts, Kohli revealed his identity to the kids after which they ran towards him and hugged him. "These moments are special for me," Kohli said about his experience.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Fans turn Ronaldo's flying header into memes, his team shares pics
text: Cristiano Ronaldo's club Juventus took to Instagram to share memes created by various fans using the picture of the forward's flying header. Ronaldo had jumped to a height of 8.39 feet to score with a header against Sampdoria in Seria A on Wednesday. The pictures shared by Juventus showed Ronaldo on Moon and on top of the mountain, among others.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Indian citizens don't have to declare religion for bank accounts: Govt
text: Finance Secretary Rajeev Kumar on Saturday clarified that there is no requirement for Indian citizens to declare their religion for an existing bank account or opening one. "Do not fall for baseless rumours about any such move by banks," he added. This comes after a report said banks may ask customers to list their religion following a 2018 RBI circular.n
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Maharashtra CM announces loan waiver of up to ₹2 lakh for farmers
text: Maharashtra Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray on Saturday announced a loan waiver of up to ₹2 lakh for farmers. "Crop loans outstanding till September 30, 2019, will be waived by my government...The scheme will be called Mahatma Jyotirao Phule loan waiver scheme," Thackeray said. A special scheme would be offered to the farmers who repay their loans on time, he added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: 2 cruise ships collide in Mexico; 6 people injured
text: At least six people were injured when two cruise ships collided in the port of Mexico's Cozumel. Wind gusts and strong currents knocked the ship off course, the captain of one of the cruise ships, said. The collision did not cause any disruptions to the planned itineraries of either ships, Carnival Corporation, the world's largest cruise operator, said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Nirav Modi threatened to kill company director if he returned from Cairo: CBI
text: In a supplementary chargesheet filed in the ₹14,000-crore PNB scam case, the CBI alleged that Nirav Modi threatened to kill a "dummy director" of his company when he expressed his desire to return to India from Cairo. Nirav's brother Nehal Modi also offered ₹20 lakh to the director for recording a favourable statement before a judge in Europe, CBI alleged.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: WWE presents Salman Khan with customised World Championship title
text: The WWE presented Bollywood actor Salman Khan with a customised WWE World Championship title belt to celebrate the release of his new film. Fitted with side-plates featuring Salman's name emblazoned in gold, the title was revealed by Gaelyn Mendonca, the host of WWE Now India, during the show.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Don't want people to think I'm out of control, that's not true: Kangana
text: Kangana Ranaut has said she doesn't want people to think that she's "out of control" and added, "That's not true. It's completely misunderstood." "I'd never be where I'm today if I hadn't planned my actions the way I've," she said. Kangana added if she ever had a "public meltdown" or a "nasty fight", that's what she exactly wanted to do.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Shah got CAA-NRC to divert attention from economy: Raj Thackeray
text: Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) President Raj Thackeray on Saturday said the Union Home Minister Amit Shah, with this "one move" (CAA-NRC), diverted all attention from the economic crisis "gripping the country". He also said that people coming from Bangladesh and Pakistan should be thrown out irrespective of their religion. "India had not taken the contract of humanity," Thackeray added.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Police post set on fire amid anti-CAA protest in Kanpur
text: The Yateem Khana police post in Kanpur, UP was reportedly set on fire by anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) protesters on Saturday. Fire tenders were rushed to the spot. Police used tear gas shells and caned the protesters to chase them away, reported PTI. Kanpur Additional Director General of Police (ADGP) said Rapid Action Force was called to control the situation.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: 15 arrested in Daryaganj violence sent to 2-day judicial custody
text: A Delhi court has sent the 15 people arrested in connection with violence during protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in Delhi's Daryaganj to two-day judicial custody. Violence had erupted after a protest march from Jama Masjid to Jantar Mantar was stopped by police at Delhi Gate. A car was set on fire by protesters outside DCP's office in Daryaganj.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Rajasthan will not implement CAA: CM Ashok Gehlot
text: Rajasthan Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot on Friday said that Rajasthan, along with at least seven other states, will not implement the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). "This (act) has shocked all communities including Hindus and Muslims. This Act is disturbing for all," he said. "It is the trick of the BJP, Modi and Shah for polarisation," Gehlot added.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Over 3.5K booked by police in Ghaziabad for anti-CAA protest: Report
text: Ghaziabad Police on Saturday booked over 3,500 people for taking part in a protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in the city. Around 300 of those booked have been identified, said the police. The District Magistrate said that some "anti-social elements instigated" people to protest while they were returning home after offering prayers at a mosque.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: EPL side Everton appoints Carlo Ancelotti as manager
text: English Premier League side Everton have appointed Carlo Ancelotti as their manager on a four-and-a-half-year-deal. Ancelotti, who is replacing Marco Silva, will take charge of his first match at home against Burnley on Boxing Day. Ancelotti won the double with Chelsea in 2010 and has since managed Paris St-Germain, Real Madrid, Bayern Munich and Napoli.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Never took responsibility initially, but know my game now: Iyer
text: Speaking about his number four role in the Indian team, Shreyas Iyer said, "I never used to take responsibility... I know my game really well right now and I can play accordingly." "I feel that whatever the situation demands, you got to play accordingly. And I'm really happy about what I did in the first game," Iyer added.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: I'm 100% Spurs: Manager Mourinho ahead of Chelsea clash
text: Speaking about their upcoming Premier League match against Chelsea, Tottenham Hotspur manager Jose Mourinho said he has "no space" for any of his previous clubs. "I gave everything to all of them, but they are my previous clubs," he added. Mourinho, who started his Premier League coaching career with Chelsea, won three league titles for the Blues in two spells.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Ex-Man Utd player Blind diagnosed with heart muscle inflammation
text: Former Manchester United defender Daley Blind, who plays for Ajax, was diagnosed with a heart condition after suffering from dizziness during the Champions League game against Valencia on December 10. Tests had revealed that he had a heart muscle inflammation also known as cardiomyopathy. Blind has been fitted with a subcutaneous implantable cardioverter-defibrillator for the condition.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Arsenal appoint Mikel Arteta as new manager
text: Former Arsenal midfielder Mikel Arteta has been appointed as the club's new manager and will replace Unai Emery, who was sacked last month. "This is a huge honour. Arsenal is one of the biggest clubs in the world," Arteta said. The Gunners are currently 10th in Premier League standings after having won five games in their 17 matches this season.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Indian pace attack currently best in Test cricket: Dale Steyn
text: A Twitter user asked South African pacer, Dale Steyn, about the bowling line-up he feels is currently the best in the world, to which Steyn gave his vote to the Indian Test bowling attack. Steyn was also asked about his favourite batsman and he gave his vote to compatriots Quinton de Kock, AB de Villiers and Indian captain Virat Kohli.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Mizo weightlifter Jeremy breaks 27 records to win silver in Qatar
text: Youth Olympic gold medallist Jeremy Lalrinnunga on Friday broke a total of 27 records to win silver in the men's 67kg category at the 6th Qatar International Cup. Jeremy lifted 140kg in snatch and 166kg in clean and jerk to finish second. With his total effort of 306kg, he broke his own Youth World and Asian record among others.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: 1,000 women sing 'anthem' against rape on Chile's streets
text: Over 1,000 women in Chile's capital Santiago sang 'A Rapist In Your Way', a protest song about rapes and rising violence against women, which has become a viral anthem. Women were seen wearing a black blindfold and a handkerchief tied around their neck. For the past two months, Chile has been experiencing unrest where protests over inequality overtook the country.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: I earn my bread & butter via singing gigs, don't earn much in Bollywood: Diljit
text: In a recent interview, actor and singer Diljit Dosanjh said, "I earn my bread and butter through my singing gigs only which is why I never miss any opportunity on that front. I don't earn much in Bollywood." He further said people only come to concerts if the songs are hit and don't care if you're a "big film star".
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: I can fry pakoras too: Anurag to troll who said his films will flop after tweet on PM
text: Reacting to filmmaker Anurag Kashyap's tweet criticising Prime Minister Narendra Modi, a troll tweeted, "Release your next film...You and your films will meet such a fate that you will only work in theatre all your life." Responding to the troll, Anurag wrote, "Making films is not the only work in this world, I know how to fry pakoras too."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Complaint filed against Farhan in Hyderabad for his tweet on CAA
text: A complaint has been filed against Farhan Akhtar in Hyderabad for allegedly posting a "seditious" tweet on Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The complainant alleged that Farhan created "fear" and "chaos" among Dalits, Muslims, transgenders and atheists through his tweet and instigated them to "wage war" against India. Farhan had shared a post which explained the Act and National Register of Citizens.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Twinkle wears 'onion earrings' gifted by Akshay, shares pic of its growing shoot
text: Twinkle Khanna shared a picture of herself wearing earrings made of onions, which were gifted to her by Akshay Kumar. "I'm glad I got the chance to wear my priceless gifts that were brought home from a shoot, before they started sprouting shoots themselves:) #OnionsAreAGirlsBestFriends," she wrote. She also shared a picture of a shoot sprouting from the earrings.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: RJD supporters use buffaloes, stop trains in anti-CAA protests in Bihar
text: Rashtriya Janata Dal (RJD) supporters used buffaloes to block highways during the anti-CAA protests in Bihar on Saturday amid the party's call for 'Bihar Bandh'. Train movement was also affected as the supporters stopped trains and blocked tracks. RJD leader Tejashwi Yadav participated in the Mahagathbandhan (Grand Alliance) rally in Patna to protest against CAA.n
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Maharashtra won't implement CAA, NRC: NCP Chief Sharad Pawar
text: Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) Chief Sharad Pawar on Saturday said that Maharashtra will not implement Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and National Register for Citizens (NRC). "CAA and NRC have been brought in...to adversely affect the religious and social harmony in the country," he said. "They (BJP) are using it to divert attention from economic issues," he added.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Our PM is deaf and dumb, he is busy learning new lies: Anurag Kashyap
text: Amid the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protests across India, filmmaker Anurag Kashyap tweeted, "Our Prime Minister...is deaf, he is dumb and beyond emotions." Anurag added, "He can just give speeches and nothing else. He cannot see and hear. He is busy learning new lies." On December 16, Anurag returned to Twitter after four months and called the government "fascist" over CAA.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: 40 detained amid anti-CAA protests in Daryaganj including 8 minors
text: At least 40 people were detained and 15 were arrested in connection with protests over the amended Citizenship Act in Delhi's Daryaganj on Friday. According to a police official, those arrested have been charged with rioting. Among those detained, at least eight were minors who were released on Saturday morning. More arrests are likely in this matter, said the Police.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: I have been receiving death threats from an international number: Gambhir
text: BJP MP Gautam Gambhir on Friday wrote to Delhi Police, alleging that he received death threats to him and his family from a caller using an international number. He urged the police to lodge a case and ensure the safety and security of his family. He added that the number of the alleged caller showed "+7 (400) 043".
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Ethiopia becomes 11th African nation to have a satellite in space
text: Ethiopia launched its first-ever satellite into space successfully on Friday, making it the 11th African country to have a satellite in space. The satellite was designed by Chinese and Ethiopian engineers and the Chinese government paid about $6-million of the more than $7-million manufacturing costs. The satellite will be used for weather forecast and crop monitoring, as per officials.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Phosphine could be an 'unmistakable' sign of alien life, says MIT
text: MIT researchers found that phosphine is produced by 'anaerobic' organisms, including bacteria and microbes, that don't require oxygen to thrive. Researchers found phosphine cannot be produced in any other way, making it a "pure biosignature", at least for a certain kind of life. "If phosphine is detected from a rocky planet...it'd be an unmistakable sign of extraterrestrial life," MIT said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Researchers use lasers to create alternative system for ultrasound
text: MIT engineers have made use of an eye- and skin-safe laser system to develop an alternative to conventional ultrasound that doesn't require contact with the body to observe the patient. Researchers scanned the forearms of several volunteers and observed common tissue features such as muscle, fat, and bone, down to about six centimeters below the skin.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: 21-yr-old woman raped by 3 uncles, says 'my parents gave them permission'
text: A 21-year-old woman from Haryana's Hisar has alleged that she was raped by her three uncles on multiple occasions for years, adding that her parents allowed the relatives to do so. The woman said she decided to file a police complaint after her younger sister was also being subjected to similar abuse. An investigation has been launched into the case.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: HC orders re-postmortem of 4 accused in Hyderabad vet's rape & murder case
text: The Telangana High Court on Saturday ordered a re-postmortem of the mortal remains of the four accused in the rape and murder case of a veterinarian in Hyderabad. All the four accused were killed in a police encounter earlier this month. The Supreme Court had ordered a three-member inquiry into the encounter case.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Factually inaccurate: India on Malaysian PM's remark on CAA
text: After Malaysian PM Mahathir Mohamad criticised Citizenship (Amendment) Act on sidelines of the Kuala Lumpur Summit, India said, "Mohamad's comment was factually inaccurate." "Malaysia should refrain from commenting on India's internal developments, especially without a right understanding of the facts," the External Affairs Ministry added. Mohamad had said, "People are dying because of this law."
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Ramachandra Guha an 'urban naxal' who operates in dark world: BJP
text: Karnataka BJP shared a post on historian Ramachandra Guha, calling him an "urban naxal" who "operates in a dark world and is completely unknown to the common man". "They make their presence felt through inciting violence and organizing protests at the behest of their Masters," the tweet read. BJP's remark comes after Guha was detained during anti-CAA protest in Bengaluru.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: India to auction 8,305 megahertz of airwaves, seeks to raise ₹5.2 lakh crore
text: The Digital Communications Commission has approved a ₹5.23 lakh crore spectrum auction that is likely to take place in March-April next year. The government will auction 8,305 megahertz (MHz) of spectrum, including 6,050 Mhz of 5G airwaves, Telecom Secretary Anshu Prakash said. The panel decided not to reduce the reserve price from TRAI's recommendation despite demands from telecom operators.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Ranbir Kapoor, Shraddha Kapoor to star in Luv Ranjan's upcoming film
text: Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor have been roped in for filmmaker Luv Ranjan's yet-to-be-titled film. The film, which is scheduled to release on March 26, 2021, will be produced by Ankur Garg and Ranjan. It was earlier speculated that Deepika Padukone and Ranbir will work together in a "quirky twisted love story", which will be directed and produced by Ranjan.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Chance to pick MS Dhoni, S Fleming's brains: Sam Curran
text: After being picked by the IPL side Chennai Super Kings, England cricketer Sam Curran said, "It's obviously going to be a great opportunity for me to pick their [MS Dhoni and Stephen Fleming] brains." "Can't wait to come to Chennai and meet all my new teammates, playing under MS Dhoni our captain and our coach Stephen Fleming," Curran wrote.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: After Google, Twitter warns Indian users about data breach
text: After Google began alerting Indian users about a data breach due to a Chrome bug, Twitter is directly notifying Android users worldwide including India about a potential data breach. Twitter said a malicious code inserted into app's restricted storage areas may have given hackers access to Direct Messages, protected Tweets and location information, and even control over tweeting and messaging.
author: Dharna

headlines: US study reveals rampant racial bias in facial recognition systems
text: A US study showed evidence of facial recognition systems misidentifying members of some groups up to 100 times more frequently than others. The study states characteristics like age, gender, and race affect the accuracy of the algorithms used by the systems. In some cases, Asian and African American people were misidentified as much as 100 times more than Caucasian faces.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Frog that 'walks' due to opposable thumbs discovered in Brazil
text: A rare species of frog that 'walks' like a monkey because of its opposable thumbs has been discovered in forests in northern Brazil. The green coloured 'Phyllomedusa camba' tree frog, which is a critically endangered species, walks instead of hopping because its thumbs operate independently from the rest if its fingers, like a human hand.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: 151 urban bodies go to polls in Chhattisgarh
text: A total of 151 urban bodies, 10 municipal corporations, 38 municipal councils and 103 nagar panchayats, went to polls in Chhattisgarh on Saturday. A total of 40,05,353 voters, including 20,00,303 women and 443 third gender persons were eligible to exercise their franchise with over 10,000 candidates in fray. A total of 5,427 polling stations were set up for the elections. n
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Half of Chhattisgarh can't prove citizenship if NRC enacted: CM
text: Chhattisgarh CM Bhupesh Baghel said that over half of his state's population won't be able to prove citizenship if NRC is implemented. "They neither have land records nor land. Their forefathers were illiterate…from where [will they] bring 50-100 years old documents," he asked. "Gandhi had opposed the identification scheme of Britishers in Africa. Similarly, we will oppose NRC," he stated.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Iran calls US Secretary of State Pompeo 'loudspeaker for bullying'
text: After the US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced new sanctions against Iran on Thursday, the latter called him "loudspeaker for bullying, deceit and disdain". Iran's Foreign Ministry spokesman Abbas Mousavi also called the US foreign policy "inefficient, delusional, static and bullying". Among other sanctions, Pompeo had announced that the US would restrict visas for Iranian officials.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Hang me, but I won't answer: Philippines President to ICC
text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte on Friday said that the International Criminal Court (ICC) can jail or hang him over alleged extrajudicial killings in his war on drugs, but he will "never answer any question coming from" the court. "And if you hang me for all what I did, go ahead. It will be my pleasure," he added.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Sent on leave 5 months ago, CARE Ratings CEO Rajesh Mokashi resigns
text: CARE Ratings CEO and MD Rajesh Mokashi has tendered his resignation, five months after the credit rating agency sent him on leave. Mokashi was to be on leave till CARE investigated an anonymous complaint received by SEBI which reportedly alleged that the firm's rating decisions were influenced by the management. Arun Kumar will continue to be the firm's interim CEO.
author: Dharna

headlines: Protest outside Jamia University against Citizenship (Amendment) Act
text: A protest was held outside the Jamia Millia Islamia University against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act on Saturday. Protestors were seen holding posters reading "Stop dividing India, boycott CAA and NRC" and "We need humanity not brutality". Earlier in the day, Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad was taken into custody after he escaped while being detained by Delhi Police on Friday.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Banks may ask customers to list their religion over law similar to CAA
text: Banks may ask customers to list religion after a 2018 RBI circular allowing minorities from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan with long-term visas to open accounts and own property, The Times of India reported. The changes are similar to CAA that provides citizenship to minorities from these countries. Earlier, a foreigner could open accounts regardless of religion or country of origin.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Police response to guns will also be with guns: BJP leader on Mangaluru firing
text: BJP National Secretary H Raja said that police had to resort to firing in Mangaluru during anti-CAA protests as the agitators threatened to kill "hundreds of people." "There was no option left for the police. We'll reply with stone if a stone is thrown at us and our reply to a gun will also be through a gun," he added.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 8-yr-old playing in lane dies in stampede after police lathi-charge UP protestors
text: An eight-year-old boy playing with his friend in a lane in Uttar Pradesh's Varanasi died in a stampede after police lathi-charged a violent mob protesting against Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The boy was reportedly rushed to a hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries. At least 11 people have been killed in the protests across Uttar Pradesh.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Insects came out and started crying after medicine was sprayed: BJP leader
text: Gujarat BJP leader Pradipsinh Vaghela has tweeted, "Dawa chhidakne par keede bahar aakar bilbilane lage, toh iska matlab saaf hai ki dawa bilkul sahi hai (After medicine was sprayed, insects came out and started crying. So the meaning is clear that the medicine is completely correct)." The leader's tweet comes amid protests against Citizenship (Amendment) Act across the country.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Bhim Army chief arrested a day after protesting against CAA
text: Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad was arrested by the Delhi Police today, a day after being detained over the anti-CAA protest. Azad had escaped while being detained on Friday and was taken into custody earlier today. He was denied permission earlier for a protest march from Delhi's Jama Masjid to Jantar Mantar.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: US Navy bans TikTok on govt-issued phones over security threats
text: The US Navy has banned popular lip-syncing video platform TikTok, owned by Chinese startup ByteDance, on government-issued mobiles citing a threat to cybersecurity. The Navy issued a notice saying users who did not remove the app would be blocked from the Navy Marine Corps Intranet. Notably, US Army cadets were instructed to restrict using TikTok last month.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Rolls-Royce unveils its electric plane aimed to be world's fastest
text: British luxury automaker Rolls-Royce unveiled its single-seater electric plane, which it hopes will fly in late spring next year. Work will now begin on integrating the electrical propulsion system to enable the zero-emissions plane to attempt the record for being the world's fastest, Rolls-Royce said. It added that it is aiming for a target speed of over 480 kmph.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: MP Cong MLA Banwari Lal Sharma passes away at 61 after battling cancer
text: Congress MLA in Madhya Pradesh Banwari Lal Sharma passed away at the age of 61 at a Bhopal hospital on Saturday. The legislator from Jaura constituency in Morena district is said to have been undergoing treatment for cancer at AIIMS for a long time. Sharma's last rites will be performed at his ancestral Jaalthap village in Morena district.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Shashi Tharoor shares wrong map of India on poster titled 'Bharat Bachao'
text: Congress MP Shashi Tharoor on Twitter shared a wrong map of India on a party poster titled 'Bharat Bachao' (Save India), which portrayed the nation without its northern-most territory. Tharoor deleted the post after being criticised by people on the microblogging site. The leader had posted the image announcing an anti-CAA protest rally he'll be leading in Kerala's Kozhikode.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 4 drivers killed on Brazil gangster's order after his mother's Uber cancelled
text: Four rideshare drivers in Brazil were tortured and murdered on a Brazilian gangster's orders after his sick mother's Uber ride was cancelled, a Brazilian governor said. The men, aged 23-48, were called to a Salvador slum last week and killed, while a fifth taken at gunpoint managed to escape. Two suspects including the gangster were killed in a police encounter.
author: Dharna

headlines: Chandrayaan-2 Project Director not part of next mission: Officials
text: M Vanitha, the Project Director for India's second Moon mission Chandrayaan-2, is not part of the next lunar mission Chandrayaan-3, ISRO officials revealed. Vanitha was replaced by P Veeramuthuvel from Tamil Nadu. Officials feel Veeramuthuvel would have a clear mindset and lead Chandrayaan-3 team better as he would not have the burden of past disappointment, The New Indian Express reported.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: BJP leader leads pro-CAA rally, shouts 'desh ke gaddaro ko, goli maro saal*n ko'
text: BJP leader Kapil Mishra led a rally in support of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in Delhi and shared a video. In the video, Mishra and his supporters were heard shouting, "Desh ke gaddaro ko, goli maro saal*n ko," a slogan targeting anti-CAA protestors. "If we can win in the Parliament, we can win on the streets as well," he wrote.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Man drugs auto driver's 15-yr-old daughter, steals gold & cash from home
text: An auto-rickshaw driver's 15-year-old daughter was allegedly drugged and robbed by an unidentified man in Chennai on Thursday. Around 10 sovereigns of gold jewellery and cash worth ₹45,000 were stolen from the driver's house. The girl was alone at home when the accused forced her to inhale a handkerchief, which was laced with a sedative.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Don't show content that may instigate violence: Govt to news channels
text: Amid countrywide protests over Citizenship (Amendment) Act, the government has issued an advisory asking news channels to refrain from broadcasting content which is "likely to instigate violence or which promotes anti-national attitudes". The Information and Broadcasting Ministry also asked news channels "not to show content that...maligns or slanders any individual in person or certain groups."
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: US could 'pay dearly' for human rights criticism: North Korea
text: North Korea on Saturday warned that the US would "pay dearly" for criticising its human rights record. It said that the US' "verbal abuse" would only aggravate tensions on the Korean Peninsula. This comes after UN General Assembly condemned North Korea's "long-standing and ongoing" violations of human rights in an annual resolution sponsored by countries including the US.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Malaysia's ex-PM swears in mosque he had no role in 28-yr-old model's murder
text: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak took an oath at a mosque on Friday denying allegations he ordered the 2006 murder of a 28-year-old Mongolian model. Najib was Deputy Prime Minister and held the defence portfolio when Altantuya Shaariibuu was shot dead and her body was blown up by military-grade explosives in a forest near the capital, Kuala Lumpur.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: ICC to probe alleged war crimes in Palestinian territories
text: The International Criminal Court's (ICC) chief prosecutor Fatou Bensouda on Friday said she would launch a full investigation into alleged war crimes in the Palestinian territories. "I have sought confirmation that the 'territory' over which the court may exercise its jurisdiction comprises the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and Gaza," she added.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Revolution is brought by youth, not celebrities: Sushant Singh
text: Talking about Bollywood celebrities who're refraining from commenting on Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Sushant Singh said that whenever a revolution has happened, it has been brought by the youth and not the celebrities. "Now, too, the youth is opposing...through peaceful protests," he added. Sushant further said that people should appreciate the celebrities who're taking a stand against the Act.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Entire country is weeping, burning: Filmmaker Mukesh Bhatt on CAA
text: Talking about the ongoing protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, filmmaker Mukesh Bhatt said, "Entire country is weeping [and] burning. If you still can't see anything then it's unfortunate." Condemning violence during the protests, he added that the government has to notice why the protests are happening. "If...our...children have taken to...streets then...something is wrong," he said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: People are being divided on basis of religion: Vishal Bhardwaj on CAA
text: Talking about the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Vishal Bhardwaj said the "current scenario" in the country is grim, adding, "People are being divided on...basis of religion." "[This] is not the India I grew up in," he added. Vishal also shared a cartoon on Twitter, which took a dig at the government for imposing Section 144 in various parts of the country.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: SIT to probe violence during anti-CAA protests in Assam
text: Assam Chief Minister Sarbananda Sonowal has announced that a Special Investigation Team (SIT) will probe the violence during the protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). "Whoever was involved will not be spared," Sonowal added. Last week, five people had died during the clashes between protesters and police with several cities and towns being placed under curfew including Guwahati.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Online food orders fall 30% amid CAA protests, internet shutdowns: ET
text: The ongoing protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and internet shutdowns in parts of India are affecting online food delivery and e-commerce businesses. The volume of online food delivery orders on platforms like Zomato and Swiggy fell 25-30%, the Economic Times reported. Executives from grocery startup Grofers said the deliveries were disrupted due to roadblocks and traffic jams.
author: Dharna

headlines: Facebook to stop using users' phone numbers for recommending friends
text: Facebook has announced that it will no longer use phone numbers, that users provide for two-factor authentication, to recommend friends to them under "People you may know". The change, effective 2020 globally, is in connection with Facebook's $5-billion settlement with the US trade commission. Earlier, it stopped using phone numbers to target ads after backlash for not disclosing the same.
author: Dharna

headlines: US woman gets her body implanted with house key, magnet, LED lights
text: A 31-year-engineer in the US got her body implanted with a microchip to open her house door, a magnet in her finger to sense electromagnetic fields and magnet-triggered LED lights in her arm. Winter Mraz said she received the 'upgrades' in addition to a 3D-printed knee implant following a car crash. She said the "cyber-enhancements" helped her with day-to-day activities.
author: Dharna

headlines: CFC emission rise could delay ozone hole healing by 20 yrs: Study
text: A modelling study in the journal Nature Communications has stated that the recently discovered increase in emissions of trichlorofluoromethane (CFC-11) may delay the recovery of the Antarctic ozone hole by over a decade if it continues. CFC-11 contributes about one-quarter of the anthropogenic chlorine transported into the stratosphere, which causes the deterioration of the ozone layer.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: SC asks bank to pay school that lost ₹30 lakh in net-banking fraud
text: The Supreme Court has ruled that a public-sector bank was liable to pay ₹25 lakh to a school whose ₹30 lakh was siphoned-off by miscreants through net-banking. The principal of a West Bengal-based DAV Public School alleged that Indian Bank linked the school's bank accounts which weren't availing net-banking facilities with his personal account without consent, hence facilitating the fraud.
author: Dharna

headlines: Death toll in UP anti-CAA protests rises to 11; 25 vehicles set ablaze
text: The death toll in Uttar Pradesh in Friday's violence over the Citizenship (Amendment) Act has risen to 11. Police said that around 25 vehicles were set ablaze during the agitation, adding that they took a total of 667 persons into custody as a part of "preventive action". Officials and police said at least 38 policemen were injured in the violence.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: US woman hires plane in search of her stolen dog, offers ₹5 lakh reward
text: A woman in San Francisco, US, has hired a plane to search for her stolen dog Jackson and is also offering a reward of $7,000 (nearly ₹5 lakh). The Miniature Australian Shepherd was stolen from outside a grocery store last week. The plane will fly over San Francisco with a banner of the website she set up to find Jackson.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Police said they'd tear my beard: UP journo who was detained due to 'confusion'
text: Journalist Omar Rashid has alleged he was detained from a Lucknow restaurant during anti-CAA protests. He told The Hindu, that police asked about whereabouts of some "Kashmiris" due to his Kashmiri background and threatened that they'll 'tear out all of his beard'. Rashid added that police later apologised to him and said he was picked up due to a "confusion".
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Bhim Army chief held after escaping police custody during anti-CAA protest
text: Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad was taken into custody on Saturday, after he escaped while being detained by Delhi Police on Friday during protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. Azad said he was inside Jama Masjid during the protest. More than 40 people, including at least three minors, were detained on Friday after clashes broke out during the agitation.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: AMU student loses hand after protest; one says police thrashed them in hospital
text: A PhD student's hand has been amputated after he was injured during clashes between AMU students and police earlier this week. Some students alleged that police had hit them while they were protesting peacefully against CAA. A 19-year-old student said around 20 students were taken to a hospital for treatment and the police had thrashed them there as well.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: I sent him to buy ration when he was shot: Wife of UP man killed in protest
text: The wife of 32-year-old Mohammad Wakeel, who died of bullet injury during violent anti-CAA protests in Lucknow on Thursday, said, "I told him to get ration." His mother said Wakeel wasn't out to protest, but had gone to buy groceries and medicines after there were rumours that curfew will be imposed. His brother said they don't know who shot him.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 22-yr-old 'Turkish Crime Family' hacker pleads guilty to Apple blackmail
text: A 22-year-old man, who claimed he was an online hacking group Turkish Crime Family's spokesman, pleaded guilty in London to a blackmail attempt on Apple. Kerem Albayrak initially demanded Apple transfer him $75,000 (over ₹53 lakh) in cryptocurrency or thousand $100 iTunes gift cards. In return, Albayrak promised to delete a database that he claimed held 319 million Apple accounts.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Twitter suspends 88,000 accounts spreading Saudi propaganda
text: Twitter has suspended 88,000 accounts which it said were linked "to a significant state-backed information operation" originating in Saudi Arabia. It accused the accounts of violating its "manipulation policies". "Primarily, accounts were amplifying messages favourable to Saudi authorities, mainly through inauthentic engagement tactics such as aggressive liking, retweeting and replying," it added.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Sundar Pichai gets ₹1,721 crore pay package on becoming Alphabet CEO
text: Google CEO Sundar Pichai has been granted a ₹1,707 crore ($240 million) stock package alongside a ₹14 crore ($2 million) annual salary effective 2020, as part of his recent elevation to the role of Alphabet CEO, filings revealed. Pichai will also receive ₹640 crore ($90 million) in performance-based stock units. His compensation in 2018 was nearly ₹13.3 crore ($1.9 million).
author: Dharna

headlines: Motorola delays ₹1 lakh foldable Razr as demand exceeds prediction
text: Motorola is delaying the launch of its foldable Razr phone, saying that the demand for the device priced $1,500 (over ₹1 lakh) has outstripped its supply predictions. Announced in November, the phone was planned to be available for pre-order in December and begin shipping to customers in January. The company declined to say when the phone would go on sale.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Govt approves VSAT to improve internet for soldiers in remote areas
text: Department of Telecommunications has approved the use of very small aperture terminal (VSAT) to improve internet connectivity for soldiers posted in remote locations. VSAT is a two-way ground station which transmits and receives data from satellites to improve communication in remote locations. Up to 1,409 locations have been suggested by the Ministry of Home Affairs and Ministry of Defence.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Orbit is hard, best wishes for landing: Musk on failed Boeing mission
text: Responding to NASA's update on the Boeing Starliner crew capsule's failure to reach the International Space Station (ISS) and its plans to return back to Earth, billionaire Elon Musk said, "Orbit is hard." "Best wishes for landing and swift recovery to next mission," the SpaceX CEO added. Notably, SpaceX has already successfully sent uncrewed Crew Dragon capsule to the ISS.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Lyft says names of users like Dick, Cocks violate rules; criticised
text: US ride-hailing giant Lyft faced heavy criticism online after it flagged dozens of users, including Cara Dick, Mike Finger, Nicole Cumming and Kevin Cocks, stating that their names violated the app's community guidelines. Further, Lyft's message included a 48-hour deadline to change the names. Apologising for the same, Lyft later blamed this over an "error" while updating their safety systems.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Trump signs $738-billion defence bill, inaugurates US Space Force
text: US President Donald Trump signed a $738-billion defence spending bill on Friday and also inaugurated the newest, sixth branch of the US military, the US Space Force. Trump called the funding the "largest-ever investment in the US military" and "in fact, the largest ever by far". It represents a $21-billion increase over what the US Congress enacted for fiscal 2019.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Scientists confirm 'super-puff' planets as dense as cotton candy
text: Astronomers using NASA's Hubble Space Telescope data confirmed a new class of "super-puff" planets with their density as low as that of cotton candy. Astronomers found three of these 'super-puffs' located in the Kepler 51 star system about 2,400 light-years away from Earth. "The fluffy globes are the lowest density exoplanets ever discovered beyond Earth's solar system," researchers said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: BJP MP responds to US Senator's tweet on EAM Jaishankar cancelling meet
text: After External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar cancelled a meeting with US lawmakers over the presence of Congresswoman Pramila Jayapal, Senator Elizabeth Warren said, "Efforts to silence Jayapal are...troubling." Responding to Warren's comments, BJP MP Rajeev Chandrasekhar said, "Don't want to waste time listening to Jayapal's nonsense." Jayapal criticised government's Kashmir moves in her report.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: BJP minister gives citizenship to 7 Pak refugees amid countrywide anti-CAA protests
text: BJP minister Mansukh Mandaviya on Friday handed over citizenship certificates issued by Indian government to seven Pakistani refugees in Gujarat. He said it is PM Narendra Modi-led government's effort to offer a dignified life to minorities who faced religious persecution in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan. This comes amid countrywide protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. n
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: 9-year-old's hymen was intact: US state's ex-governor on pardoning child rapist
text: Former governor of US' Kentucky Matt Bevin has said he pardoned a man, who raped a nine-year-old, on his last day in office because the victim had been found to have her hymen intact. The 41-year-old was serving a 23-year sentence for rape, incest, sodomy and other sexual offences. Bevin pardoned 428 people in the final days of his term.
author: Ankush Verma

headlines: Google searches for 'Operation Twist' surge in India
text: Google searches for 'Operation Twist' surged in India after the RBI announced its version of the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy. Most searches for the term came from Delhi followed by Maharashtra. The central bank said it will buy long-term bonds, while simultaneously selling short-term government securities in an effort to cheapen long-term borrowing and boost bank lending.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Universal basic income will boost consumption, not tax cuts: Ex-CEA
text: A universal basic income rather than cuts in personal income tax can boost consumption in India, said former Chief Economic Adviser (CEA) Arvind Subramanian. He added that personal income tax cut would only benefit the top 5-7% people, who are actual taxpayers. There has to be a direct benefit transfer or basic income that reaches the poor people, Subramanian said.
author: Dharna

headlines: Gully Boy seen by 10,000 American critics, this opens new doors: Zoya
text: Filmmaker Zoya Akhtar has said it was disappointing that 'Gully Boy' didn't make it for Oscars 2020, adding, "But...you move on to your next film." Zoya further said that the film has opened new doors for the industry as it's been seen by "10,000 American critics". 'Gully Boy' was India's official entry in the Best International Feature Film category.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Alia, Ranveer's 'Gully Boy' most tweeted Hindi film of 2019
text: Alia Bhatt and Ranveer Singh starrer 'Gully Boy' has been named as the most tweeted Hindi movie of 2019, according to #ThisHappened 2019 Twitter report. Shahid Kapoor's 'Kabir Singh', which has attained the second position, is followed by 'Mission Mangal', 'Kesari' and 'Housefull 4'. Hrithik Roshan's 'Super 30' and Vivek Agnihotri's 'The Tashkent Files' are also among the top 10.n
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: Our lives aren't different from lives of other couples: Deepika
text: On being asked about how she manages work and home, Deepika Padukone said, "There are a lot of married couples...everyone's...busy and I don't think our lives are...different." Deepika added she and Ranveer Singh understand each other's "professional demands" as they're in the same profession. "But...you got to make time for each other...That's something where we're on...same page," she said.
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: She wants to sound like SRK, Big B: Shweta on her daughter's debut
text: Actress Shweta Tiwari, while talking about her daughter Palak Tiwari's debut, said that she's waiting for the right project to come. "She keeps saying...'When people come to interview me, I want to sound like [Amitabh Bachchan] and Shah Rukh Khan, larger than life'," Shweta added. She further said that Palak doesn't want to "hop into her career without proper education".
author: Udit Gupta

headlines: YouTubers' campaign raises $20 million to plant 20 million trees
text: The TeamTrees campaign, started by YouTubers Jimmy Donaldson or 'MrBeast' and former NASA engineer Mark Rober, has surpassed its goal of raising $20 million to plant 20 million trees. Tesla CEO Elon Musk donated $1 million to the campaign, while Twitter and Square CEO Jack Dorsey contributed $350,000. YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki who donated $200,000 was among the 5,00,000 donors.
author: Dharna

headlines: 'Night Mode' light more harmful for eyes, affects sleep cycle: Study
text: According to University of Manchester scientists, blue colours associated with twilight have a lesser harmful effect on the eyes than white or yellow lights of equivalent brightness, usually found in smartphones' 'Night Mode'. The findings suggest that using dim, cooler, lights in the evening and bright warmer lights in the day may be more beneficial.
