Enforcement for the new rules should take effect in the "coming weeks," Facebook said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: US firm designs garage for Cybertrucks in which the owners can also live
text: US-based company Lars Buro has designed 'Cybunker', a garage that can accommodate two Tesla Cybertrucks and its owners. The company claims the 1,800 square-foot garage can withstand the toughest environmental conditions and works as an off-grid residence with furniture. The designers said they were inspired to build 'Cybunker' after learning that Cybertruck cannot fit in a standard 20x20ft garage.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Uber fined $4.4 million in US over 'permitting culture of sex abuse'
text: Ride-hailing giant Uber was fined $4.4 million to settle sex discrimination charges by the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) brought in 2017. Uber was found to have "permitted a culture of sexual harassment and retaliation against individuals who complained about such harassment," EEOC said. Notably, Uber Co-founder Travis Kalanick was ousted as the CEO over the same.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: 13 cab drivers booked, issued challans for refusing rides by Cyberabad Police
text: Cyberabad Traffic Police has booked 13 cab drivers for refusing rides to passengers after confirming their bookings and raised e-challans against their vehicles. The action was initiated after residents posted complaints with proofs via official WhatsApp number of Cyberabad Traffic Police, officers said. The complaints are being registered under Section 178 of the Motor Vehicles Act.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: OYO firing 500 employees in India, may fire up to 2,000 by Feb: Report
text: India's most-valuable hospitality startup OYO is in the process of firing around 500 employees in India, Entrackr reported. Another media report claimed that the Gurugram-based startup could likely fire up to 2,000 employees by February. This comes just weeks after the SoftBank-backed startup announced the appointment of Rohit Kapoor as the new CEO for India and South Asia region.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: We welcomed refugees from all over the world: India on Pak PM's refugee remark
text: India rejected Pakistan PM Imran Khan's remark that millions of Muslims could flee India, causing a refugee crisis. "Throughout history, India has welcomed refugees from all over the world. The Zoroastrians had sought refuge in India...Thousands have sought refuge in India from some of our neighbouring countries," Rajiv Chander, India's Permanent Representative to the UN, Geneva, said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: These people are crazy: Trump to Democrats after impeachment
text: US President Donald Trump, who has been impeached, said the rival Democratic Party is "consumed with envy and hatred". "These people are crazy," he added. He stated that the Democratic Party, which controls the House of Representatives where the votes for impeachment took place, was "trying to nullify the ballots of tens of millions of patriotic Americans."
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Who are the other US Presidents who have been impeached?
text: Andrew Johnson was the first US President to be impeached in 1868 for violating the Tenure of Office Act by firing a cabinet secretary without Congress' consent. Bill Clinton was impeached in 1998 on perjury and obstruction of justice, with the investigation revolving around his affair with Monica Lewinsky. Both were acquitted by the Senate and remained in office.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: What are the impeachment charges against Donald Trump?
text: The US House of Representatives has voted to impeach President Donald Trump, accusing him of abusing his power as president by pressuring Ukraine to help him get re-elected in 2020. Trump had asked Ukraine to investigate his potential Democratic rival Joe Biden. Trump is also charged with obstructing Congress for preventing his administration from cooperating with the impeachment investigation.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Difficult to pass on GST rate cut benefits on ₹2 or ₹5 packs: Nestlé
text: Nestlé India MD Suresh Narayanan has said it is a challenge to pass on GST rate cut benefits on ₹2 or ₹5 packs. Nestlé was recently fined ₹90 crore for not passing on GST benefits. "For such products, the benefit is ₹25p or ₹50p. We don't have those different coins. How will I pass on...even if I want," Narayanan added.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: My brother Aparshakti deserves lead roles: Ayushmann
text: Ayushmann Khurrana at a media event said that he feels his younger brother Aparshakti Khurana "deserves to be a lead actor". "It's very difficult to become a character actor and engage people. Aparshakti has done an amazing job in his recent films," he added. Ayushmann further said that he "takes time to open up" but Aparshakti is an extrovert.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Rahul-Rohit's tons, Kuldeep's hat-trick help India beat WI by 107 runs
text: India defeated West Indies by 107 runs in the second ODI in Visakhapatnam on Wednesday to level the three-match series 1-1. The match witnessed Indian openers KL Rahul (102) and Rohit Sharma (159) slam their third and 28th hundreds in ODI cricket, respectively. Further, Chinaman bowler Kuldeep Yadav took his second hat-trick in ODI cricket.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Schools in Noida, Ghaziabad closed for 2 days due to cold weather
text: All schools in Uttar Pradesh's Noida, Greater Noida and Ghaziabad will remain shut on Thursday and Friday due to the cold weather, officials said on Wednesday. Schools have been closed in other districts of UP, including Saharanpur, Bareilly and Pilibhit. Delhi recorded its lowest maximum temperature in 22 years on Tuesday.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Section 144 to be imposed in Bengaluru for 3 days from 6 am tomorrow
text: Section 144 will be imposed in Bengaluru and several other parts of Karnataka for three days from 6 am tomorrow. The orders come ahead of protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) which were set to be held on Thursday. "It is just a precautionary measure as we do not want violence," Karnataka Home Minister Basavaraj Bommai said.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Dams are built over rivers: Renuka to troll who called her 'dam actress'
text: Actress Renuka Shahane on Tuesday trolled back a man for tweeting, "Your just dam actress." The actress responded, "Do you mean "damn"? Dams are built over rivers, to harness electricity. You don't mean I'm a dam, right?" Twitter users reacted to Shahane's comeback with tweets like, "Dam good answer Renuka ji" and "Slam Dunk is passe. Slam Damn and how."
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: My mom is Hindu, biological dad was Christian, adopted dad Muslim: Dia
text: Actress Dia Mirza on Wednesday tweeted, "My mother is a Hindu, my biological father was a Christian, my adopted father - a Muslim. In all official documents, my religion status stays blank." She also asked, "Does religion determine I am an Indian?" Her tweet comes two days after the actress tweeted, "I stand in solidarity with the students of India."
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Both captains get out for a golden duck in an ODI for the first time in history
text: The India-West Indies ODI in Visakhapatnam marked the first instance of both the captains getting out for a golden duck in an ODI. Team India captain Virat Kohli was caught by Roston Chase off West Indies captain Kieron Pollard's bowling, while Pollard was caught behind by Rishabh Pant for a first-ball duck off fast bowler Mohammad Shami's bowling.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Sachin, Binny and Bhavish showed Indian startups can compete: PhonePe CEO
text: PhonePe's CEO Sameer Nigam told YourStory, "In the last 10 years, Flipkart's Sachin Bansal and Binny Bansal, and Ola's Bhavish Aggarwal have shown that Indian startups can compete." He said, "Every multinational is coming as a competitor." Nigam added, "You have two options...Either you raise capital and compete or you throw in the towel and say Indian startups can't compete."
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Srinagar's Jamia Masjid opens after record 135 days since Art 370 move
text: Srinagar's Jamia Masjid re-opened on Wednesday after record 135 days since Article 370 revocation on August 5. Anjuman-e-Auqaf, the body managing the 14th-century mosque, said that they held a meeting on Tuesday after security forces were removed from the gates and decided to go ahead with the prayers. Reports said some people became emotional and kissed the mosque's wooden pillars.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Only 1 lawyer can speak at a time in UK: CJI as lawyers argue during CAA hearing
text: As several lawyers argued simultaneously during the hearing over Citizenship (Amendment) Act, Chief Justice SA Bobde asked lawyers to argue one at a time. "In UK, only one lawyer can address the court at a time," he said. Attorney General KK Venugopal, representing the Centre, cited Pakistan's Supreme Court's example, saying only one lawyer speaks while standing on a podium.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Nirbhaya gangrape convict moves HC claiming he was juvenile during time of offence
text: Pawan Kumar, one of the four convicts in the Nirbhaya gangrape case, has moved the Delhi High Court claiming that he was a juvenile at the time of the offence in December 2012. Kumar, who was awarded death sentence, has sought an ossification test to ascertain his claim of juvenility. The plea filed is listed for hearing on Thursday.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Situation along LoC can escalate any time: Army Chief Bipin Rawat
text: Army Chief General Bipin Rawat on Wednesday said that the situation along the Line of Control (LoC) can escalate any time and the country has to be prepared for escalatory matrix. His remarks came in the backdrop of an increase in ceasefire violation by Pakistan along the LoC in Jammu and Kashmir since the abrogation of Article 370 in August.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: MP university expels 23 students protesting professors' alleged caste bias
text: The Makhanlal Chaturvedi National University of Journalism and Communication (MCU) in Madhya Pradesh expelled 23 students who protested against two professors' alleged caste bias. The students were expelled because they were involved in violence, the university said. Former Madhya Pradesh CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan tweeted in support of the students and demanded the withdrawal of their expulsions.
author: Shailesh

headlines: GST Council votes for first time, fixes uniform 28% rate on lotteries
text: The GST Council, in its 38th meeting on Wednesday, voted for the first time in its history and decided to levy a uniform rate of 28% on lotteries. Earlier, lotteries conducted by state governments within the state were taxed at 12% while state-authorised lotteries sold outside were taxed at 28%. The single rate will be effective from March 1, 2020.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Tata Sons' conversion from public to private company illegal: Tribunal
text: The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal has said the Registrar of Companies' decision to convert Tata Sons into a private limited company from a public limited company was illegal and  "prejudicial" to minority shareholders. The court ordered that Tata Sons be classified again as a public company, giving minority shareholders like the Mistry family more autonomy to sell their shares.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: 190 stone-pelting incidents in Kashmir Valley since Art 370 repeal
text: Since the revocation of Article 370 in Jammu and Kashmir on August 5, 190 stone-pelting incidents have been reported in the Kashmir Valley, officials said. Till December 8, around 250 people involved in such incidents were in jails, they added. There were 802 incidents of stone-pelting in 2018, the officials further said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Opposition is trying to spread violence in Delhi: Kejriwal
text: Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal said the Opposition is deliberately trying to spread violence in Delhi at a time when "it is clear that AAP is winning the (upcoming) assembly elections". "Those who are involved in the violence are doing it as they are scared to lose (the elections)," Kejriwal said. He added that he is worried about Delhi's situation.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Younis Khan refuses to be special guest in Pak's 2nd Test vs SL
text: Former Pakistan captain Younis Khan has rejected Pakistan Cricket Board's invitation to be a special guest during the second Test against Sri Lanka in Karachi on Thursday. "Disappointing, upsetting that he's not coming," PCB CEO Wasim Khan said. Younis is reportedly unhappy with the board over the refusal of his request to get full charge of the national Under-19 squad.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Regret not coming to Pak for ODI, T20I series: SL skipper Dimuth
text: Sri Lanka Test and ODI captain Dimuth Karunaratne on Wednesday said that he regrets his earlier decision to pull out of the limited-overs Pakistan tour in September-October this year. "I can say that I feel really safe here," he added. Sri Lanka Cricket had sent a second-string squad for the series after 10 players had pulled out citing security reasons.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: New Instagram feature to let users post multiple images in one Story
text: Instagram has rolled out a new feature that will now let users upload multiple images in one Story. The new 'Layout' feature, available on the Stories platform, will allow users to upload up to six images at once, from the previous one image earlier. The feature is said to be available to all users by the end of the week.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Hindu-Muslim, India-Pak no answer to students' concerns: Congress
text: Congress leader Randeep Singh Surjewala said, "Hindu-Muslim or India-Pakistan is no reply to youth's questions on unemployment, rising cost of education, and trampling of Constitution." He added that PM Narendra Modi-led government was responding to students' protests with batons, tear gas and bullets. Students' protests will "grow stronger" if the Centre fails to talk to them, he further said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: US startup that created wearable patch to improve memory raises $2.6 mn
text: Neurostimulation wearables startup Humm has raised $2.6 million in a funding round led by Berlin-based VC firm BlueYard Capital along with Berkeley SkyDeck Fund, among others. The startup has created a wearable patch with neurostimulation which claims to improve memory within just 15 minutes of use every day. Humm was one of the startups selected for Berkeley SkyDeck accelerator programme.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: E-pharmacy startup Medlife raises $15.5 million in debt funding
text: Bengaluru-based online pharmacy startup Medlife has raised about $15.5 million from Wilson Global Opportunities Fund in a debt funding round. The startup is planning to raise external funding of about $150 million in the next six months, Inc42 reported. Medlife is "looking to acquire 140 street pharmacies and is already in talks with the same," its Co-founder Tushar Kumar said.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Identity of 'Bharatvarsh' can't be allowed to be destroyed: Ex-Prez Mukherjee
text: Former President Pranab Mukherjee said that the identity of "Bharatvarsh", that is India, can never be allowed to be destroyed. There are seven practising major religions, 122 languages and 1,600 dialects in the country, he added. "We are 1.3 billion people of 3 ethnic groups - Caucasian, Dravidian and Mongoloid...living under one identity - Indian," he further said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Germany moves to ban gay 'conversion therapies'
text: Germany's cabinet on Tuesday approved a draft law banning 'conversion therapies' designed to force heterosexuality on homosexuals. The legislation will punish violations with imprisonment of up to one year or a fine. "Homosexuality is not a disease. The term therapy is therefore misleading. We want to ban conversion therapies as much as possible," Health Minister Jens Spahn said.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Bank of Baroda underreported bad loans by ₹5,250 cr in FY19: RBI
text: Bank of Baroda (BoB) underreported bad loans by ₹5,250 crore in the financial year 2018-19, a Reserve Bank of India (RBI) report said. The bank reported non-performing assets worth ₹69,924 crore for the year ending March 2019 but RBI's report stated NPAs at ₹75,174 crore, leading to gross NPA divergence of ₹5,250 crore. BoB's share dropped 3% following RBI's report.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Kuldeep Yadav becomes first Indian to take two hat-tricks in international cricket
text: India Chinaman Kuldeep Yadav has become the first Indian to take two hat-tricks in international cricket. The 25-year-old, who took his first ODI hat-trick against Australia on September 21, 2017, took the wickets of West Indies' Shai Hope, Jason Holder and Alzarri Joseph to claim his second ODI hat-trick today. It was the fifth ODI hat-trick by an Indian bowler.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Amit Shah should take care of his health, he's a very important person: Akshay
text: Akshay Kumar, when asked if he had any questions for Home Minister Amit Shah during Agenda AajTak 2019, said, "The only thing I'd ask and tell him, is to take care of his health." "He's a very important person for our country," Akshay added. "I'd suggest him not to eat anything after 6.30 pm...It's good for the body," he said.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: 'Gully Boy' out of Oscars 2020 race as it is a copy: Director Vivek Agnihotri
text: Sharing an article on 'Gully Boy' being out of the Oscars 2020 race, filmmaker Vivek Agnihotri tweeted, "This embarrassment happened because...Godmother Aparna Sen chose a copy over original films." The article stated why 'Gully Boy' was disqualified from Oscars as it's inspired by American film '8 Mile'. Aparna Sen had headed the jury for the selection of the Oscar entry.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Many countries for Muslims, not one for Hindus: Gadkari on CAA row
text: The Citizenship (Amendment) Act is a necessity since there is no country specifically for Hindus, said Union Minister Nitin Gadkari. He said, "There is no country in the world for the Hindus. Earlier, Nepal was one Hindu nation...so where will the Hindus, Sikhs go? For Muslims, there are several Muslim nations where they can get citizenship."
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Puducherry to not implement Citizenship Act: CM Narayanasamy
text: Puducherry Chief Minister V Narayanasamy on Wednesday said that it would be difficult to implement the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in the Union Territory. Narayanasamy said, "Puducherry will also toe the line of Punjab and Madhya Pradesh." The governments of three states namely West Bengal, Punjab and Madhya Pradesh have said that they would not implement the Citizenship Act.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Shreyas-Rishabh slam 31 runs in an over, break Sachin-Ajay Jadeja's record
text: India batsmen Rishabh Pant and Shreyas Iyer slammed 31 runs off West Indies spinner Roston Chase's over in the second ODI today to record the most runs off an over by India in an ODI. The duo broke the previous record (28 runs), set by Sachin Tendulkar and Ajay Jadeja against former New Zealand fast bowler Chris Drum in 1999.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Cash burn not sustainable, but we have to live with it in India: PhonePe CEO
text: PhonePe's Co-founder and CEO Sameer Nigam in an interview to YourStory said that cash burns are not sustainable but fintech is a tough sector and they have to live with it in India. "Every time you take a step back, somebody comes and ploughs a hundred billion dollars and it becomes hard," Nigam said. "There's no end," he added.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: 3,500-yr-old beehive-shaped Bronze Age graves lined with gold found
text: Cincinnati University archaeologists found two beehive-shaped Bronze Age graves in Pylos, Greece, last year while investigating area around the grave of an individual dubbed "Griffin Warrior". Announcing the discovery now, archaeologists said the tombs were littered with flakes of gold leaf that once lined the walls. A trove of engraved jewellery and artefacts was found in the tombs, they added.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: US organisation names NASA Best Place to Work in govt for 8th time
text: NASA was named the Best Place to Work in 2019 in the US Government by Washington-based nonprofit, nonpartisan organisation Partnership for Public Service. "[It] is a testament to the excellence of our workforce and their determination to maintain America's leadership in space exploration," said NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine. This was the 16th edition of the Best Places to Work rankings.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Noam Chomsky, Judith Butler among 10,000 who condemn police action in Jamia
text: Scholars Noam Chomsky, Judith Butler and Romila Thapar are among over 10,000 people who have signed a statement condemning "police brutality in Jamia University". The Citizenship (Amendment) Act bars Muslims in neighbouring countries from acquiring Indian citizenship and thus "contravenes the right to equality and secular citizenship enshrined in (India's) constitution", the statement read.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: BJD supports CAA, but not NRC: Naveen Patnaik
text: Biju Janata Dal (BJD) chief and Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik has said his party will not support the National Register of Citizens (NRC). "BJD MPs both in Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha have made it clear that we don't support NRC," he said. Patnaik, who supported Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), added that BJD backed it because it deals with foreigners.n
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: 210-kg ganja hidden in van carrying sweet potatoes seized in Chennai
text: The Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) has reported seizure of 210 kg of ganja in Chennai on Tuesday. The drug was packed alongside sweet potatoes and polythene covers in order to conceal it. The shipment was meant for supply in Chennai, according to anti-drug agency. The licence plate of the van, reportedly registered in Andhra Pradesh, turned out to be fake.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: 25-year-old man from Odisha sets himself on fire at India Gate
text: A 25-year-old man from Odisha set himself on fire at India Gate in Delhi on Wednesday. The man, who appeared to be mentally disturbed, has sustained 90% burns and has been rushed to Ram Manohar Lohia Hospital. The incident is not linked in any way to CAA protests, as per the police.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Drunk man in UK drives car unaware that it doesn't have a tyre; arrested
text: A man was arrested in South Yorkshire, UK for not carrying valid documents in his car. South Yorkshire Police said that the man was driving in a drunken state and had failed to realise that the car was missing a tyre. The drunk man had an expired driver's license and had no insurance.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: India continues to have British model of bureaucracy: Gopichand Hinduja
text: Hinduja Group Co-Chairman Gopichand Hinduja has said India continues to have a British model of bureaucracy, while Britain has already modified theirs. "The first step we have to take would be to see how bureaucracy can be modified," he said. Adding that initiatives taken by PM Narendra Modi were great, Hinduja further said that his team needs to be fast.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Not a personal victory: Mistry after reinstatement as Tata Sons Chairman
text: Cyrus Mistry has said the court ruling reinstating him as Tata Sons Chairman isn't a personal victory for him but a victory for the principle of good governance and minority shareholder rights. "I believe it's now time that all of us work together for sustainable growth and development of the Tata Group, an institution that we all cherish," Mistry added.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Tokyo 2020 Nippon festival to showcase Japanese calligraphy
text: Tokyo 2020 Nippon festival, which will promote Japanese culture around the Olympic and Paralympic Games set to be held next year, will showcase the work of 200 Japanese calligraphers. Further, the calligraphy by children and persons with impairments will also be on display. The Tokyo Olympics will begin on July 24 and culminate on August 9.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Harshal Patel picks 12 wickets as Haryana beat Tripura in Ranji
text: Haryana on Wednesday defeated Tripura by an innings and 125 runs within two days of the Ranji Trophy Elite Group C match. Haryana captain Harshal Patel picked his career-best first-class match figures of 12 for 53 as Tripura were bundled out for 49 in second innings. In their first match, Haryana had defeated Maharashtra by an innings and 68 runs.n
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Kolkata derby postponed due to anti-CAA protests
text: The Kolkata derby between Mohun Bagan and East Bengal set to be held on December 22 in the ongoing I-League has been postponed after the All India Football Federation (AIFF) failed to get "security assurances" from the police. A news agency report quoted sources as saying that it was due to the ongoing protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Samsung apologises after Chairman jailed for sabotaging union activities
text: Following the announcement of the 18-month long sentence to Samsung Electronics Chairman Lee Sang-hoon on Tuesday, the company has issued a public apology. "We humbly accept that the companies' understanding and view towards labour unions in the past fell short of society's expectations," they said. Lee Sang-hoon was sentenced by a South Korean court for sabotaging legitimate union activities.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Snapdeal founders lead funding round in wellness startup Azah
text: Snapdeal Co-founders Kunal Bahl and Rohit Bansal, through their investment firm Titan Capital, led a pre-Series A funding of Delhi-based female wellness startup Azah and invested an undisclosed amount in the startup. The round also saw participation from AngelList India along with other HNIs. Azah had earlier raised $200,000 from a group of angel investors in a seed funding round.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Swiggy accused of rigging delivery executives’ incentive system
text: Swiggy's delivery executives in Hyderabad have alleged that the company has been cheating them with its incentive and payment system. Executives need to earn ₹350 to get a ₹100-incentive but when they were close to achieving the target, orders would dry up, they said. Further, incentives were allegedly only given to executives hired six months ago and not new ones.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Fiat Chrysler and PSA sign agreement for $50 billion merger
text: PSA Group and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles have signed a binding agreement for a 50-50 merger worth about $50 billion to create the world's fourth-biggest auto manufacturer. The unit will be run by PSA CEO Carlos Tavares and Fiat Chairman John Elkann holding the same role. The company aims to post $189 billion revenue and cut costs by $4.1 billion yearly.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Elect government that listens to students: Priyanka Gandhi
text: Congress' Priyanka Gandhi Vadra urged voters to elect a government that will "listen to students, waive farm loans, provide security to women". While speaking at an election rally in Jharkhand, she said students have hit the roads in the country and are "facing police batons". The final phase of polling for Jharkhand Assembly election will be held on December 20.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Curfew relaxed in parts of Shillong, mobile internet to remain shut
text: Curfew was relaxed for 14 hours in Lumdiengjri police station and Sadar police station limits in Meghalaya's capital Shillong on Wednesday. "As precautionary measures, the curfew would be reimposed in these two police station areas from 8 pm on Wednesday till further orders," an official said. The ban on mobile internet services will remain in force.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Pak-lovers attempt to turn Bangladesh into failed state: PM Hasina
text: Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina said that lovers of Pakistan and those who collaborated with Pakistan forces during the country's liberation struggle were attempting to turn Bangladesh into a 'failed state'. Hasina urged her countrymen to foil plots by such people. "Our goal was that we will remain above Pakistan...on all sides including economic, social, and cultural fronts," she further said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: India must focus on fixing the financial sector: Gita Gopinath
text: IMF Chief Gita Gopinath said that ongoing issues of bad loans and problems across non-bank lenders have created disruptions in India's financial sector, causing slowdown. She urged policymakers for better governance and resolution of stressed assets. Gopinath added that IMF may "significantly" cut India's growth forecast and expressed doubt over it achieving a $5 trillion economy goal by 2025.n
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Class 2 student bitten by snake in Kerala school in 2nd incident within a month
text: A Class 2 student was bitten by a snake in a government school in Kerala's Wayanad district in second such incident within a month. The student was admitted to a private hospital and is out of danger now. Earlier, a Class 5 student of a government school in Wayanad died hours after she suffered a snake bite in her classroom.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: I will be impeached today: Donald Trump
text: Ahead of the vote in the US House of Representatives, US President Donald Trump tweeted, "Can you believe that I'll be impeached today by the...Do Nothing Democrats, AND I DID NOTHING WRONG!" "This shoild never happen to another President again. Say a prayer!" he wrote. Trump later deleted the tweet and wrote another tweet with the correct spelling of 'should'.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Ratan Tata's actions against Cyrus Mistry were oppressive: Tribunal
text: Tata Sons Chairman Emeritus Ratan Tata's actions against Cyrus Mistry were oppressive and the appointment of a new chairman was illegal, the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal said on Wednesday. It noted the manner in which Mistry was ousted was hasty. The NCLAT also directed Ratan Tata to maintain arms-length distance as far as Tata Sons board is concerned.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Can't the PM eat mangoes: Akshay on 'Do you like mangoes?' question to PM Modi
text: Akshay Kumar, while speaking at Agenda AajTak about his interview with PM Narendra Modi before the General Elections, said the questions weren't "researched upon" or "dictated". Talking about his 'Do you like mangoes?' question to the PM, Akshay added, "Can't the PM eat mangoes?... It's just a natural thing." "I simply asked him whatever came to my mind," said Akshay.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Trust Indians to lose their shit over law that doesn't affect them: Ranvir on CAA
text: Ranvir Shorey on Tuesday commented on the ongoing anti-CAA protests. "Trust Indian citizens to lose their shit over a law that doesn't affect Indian citizens. #CAAProtests," he tweeted. "The CAA doesn't affect students directly. Yet they're being made the face of these protests," he added. Ranvir further wrote even though he might not think it's "protest-worthy", he doesn't support CAA.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Kamal Haasan meets Madras University students protesting CAA
text: Actor-turned-politician Kamal Haasan on Wednesday met the students of Madras University in Chennai who are protesting against the Citizenship Act. Haasan said, "I'm not allowed to go inside. Till I die, I will call myself a student. I have come here in that capacity to be their defender." Haasan's party filed a plea against the Act in the Supreme Court.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: IAS Tina Dabi files FIR against her fake FB page criticising CAA
text: IAS officer Tina Dabi has said that she has filed an FIR to report a fake Facebook page in her name which had criticised the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. A message posted from the fake page criticising the citizenship law had gone viral on Tuesday. The Act gives Indian citizenship to non-muslim refugees fleeing religious persecution from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Rohit hits his 18th ODI hundred since start of 2017, overtakes Virat Kohli
text: Team India opener Rohit Sharma on Wednesday slammed his 18th ODI hundred since the start of 2017, overtaking Virat Kohli who has hit 17 ODI hundreds during the time period. Rohit and Virat are followed by England wicketkeeper-batsman Jonny Bairstow, who has hit nine ODI hundreds since the start of 2017. Overall, it was Rohit's 28th ODI hundred.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Rohit breaks his own world record for most international 6s in a calendar year
text: Team India opener Rohit Sharma on Wednesday broke his own world record for hitting most sixes across all formats in international cricket in a calendar year. The 32-year-old smashed five sixes in the second ODI against West Indies, taking his tally of sixes in 2019 to 77. He had set the previous record by slamming 74 sixes in 2018.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Rohit Sharma has hit India's highest ODI score each year since 2013
text: Rohit Sharma has hit highest yearly individual ODI score for India each time for last seven years. His 159(138) against West Indies today is the highest ODI score by an Indian this year, while his 162(137) was India's best in 2018. Rohit's 209(158), 264(173), 150(133), 171*(163) and 208*(153) were India's highest scores in 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016 and 2017, respectively.nn
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: How many times has Internet been shut down in India in 2019?
text: According to the Software Freedom Law Center, a global tracker for Internet shutdowns, there have been 93 Internet shutdowns in India so far in 2019. There were 14 shutdowns in 2015, 31 in 2016, 79 in 2017 and 134 in 2018, it said. As per another report, the shutdowns from 2012 to 2017 have cost the economy over $3 billion.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: NASA's experimental supersonic jet gets cleared for final assembly
text: NASA's supersonic X-59 jet, its first large-scale piloted X-plane (experimental aircraft) in over three decades, has been cleared for final assembly. The Lockheed Martin-designed aircraft could take its first flight as soon as 2021, reportedly travelling at a speed of over 1,500 kmph. The X-59 is shaped to reduce the loudness of the sonic boom reaching the ground, NASA said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Shashi Tharoor wins Sahitya Akademi Award for 'An Era of Darkness'
text: Congress MP Shashi Tharoor has won the Sahitya Akademi Award for his book 'An Era of Darkness: The British Empire in India'. He won the award in the creative non-fiction category in the English language. The book was published in 2016 and talks about the negative impact of the British rule in India.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Tribunal order on Mistry to take effect after 4 weeks, Tata can appeal in SC
text: The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) has said its order reinstating Cyrus Mistry as Chairman of Tata Sons will take effect after four weeks and Tata can challenge the ruling in Supreme Court. Mistry launched legal proceedings against Tata Sons after his ouster in 2016. The appeals court also declared that Mistry's removal from other Tata companies was illegal.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Left Bollywood to give 100% to my marriage, family: 'Swades' actress
text: Gayatri Oberoi has revealed she left Bollywood after her debut film 'Swades' starring Shah Rukh Khan because she had met her husband and wanted to commit 100% to her marriage and family. "I could have continued to work...But I consciously made that decision," she said. "When I met [my husband], I realised that this was something...I wanted more," she added.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: My pregnancy has been a roller-coaster: Kalki Koechlin
text: Actress Kalki Koechlin, who is expecting her first child in January with Israeli boyfriend Guy Hershberg, took to Instagram to share a photo showing her bare baby bump. "What a roller-coaster this pregnancy has been," Kalki wrote. Earlier, she had revealed that her "unexpected pregnancy" feels like an alien invasion wherein the baby is sucking out everything from her body.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: There was no case, police detained Payal intentionally: Fiancé Sangram
text: Actor Sangram Singh, while talking about his fiancée Payal Rohatgi's detention by Rajasthan Police, said, "There was no case and...this was done intentionally." He questioned how Payal's arrest was justified when she made a video on Nehru family using information given on the internet. "Why...nobody is taking any action against...Kanhaiya (Kumar)...who [talks] against the nation?" Sangram asked.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Best is yet to come: Kerala coach on Samson's 116-run knock vs Bengal
text: Sanju Samson on Tuesday slammed his 10th first-class century against Bengal in the ongoing Ranji Trophy after Kerala lost three wickets for 53 in the first session. Talking about his 116-run knock, Kerala coach Dav Whatmore said, "He is indeed in very good form...his best is yet to come." Kerala were bundled out for 239 in 84.2 overs.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Peter Thiel told Zuckerberg not to fact-check political ads on Facebook: WSJ
text: Billionaire investor and Facebook board member, Peter Thiel, had advised Mark Zuckerberg to keep a policy to not fact-check political ads, The Wall Street Journal reported. However, many executives from Facebook have called for a change in policy and ban on political ads. Notably, it was reported earlier that Thiel, Zuckerberg and Trump had shared a private dinner in October.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: 5G trials to start in January-March quarter this fiscal: DoT
text: Trials for 5G will commence in the January-March quarter of the current fiscal, however, the auction may be delayed to March-April, a senior telecom department official said on Tuesday. The official added that the department had received 12 applications for 5G trials. The proposals will be considered if they address the adoption of new technology and importance of national security.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: He doesn't represent Govt of India: BJP on Rahul Gandhi's S Korea visit
text: After Congress' Rahul Gandhi on Tuesday tweeted pictures of him meeting South Korea's PM Lee Nak-yon "as a part of an official delegation", Karnataka BJP said he doesn't represent the Government of India. "So, which country's official delegation is Rahul Jinnah part of? Pakistan?" they tweeted. Rahul said he discussed a wide range of issues with the South Korean PM.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: BYJU's reduces losses, announces profit of ₹20.16 crore in FY19
text: Edtech startup BYJU'S has reduced its consolidated loss to ₹8.82 crore in the fiscal ended March 2019 from a loss of ₹37.15 crore in FY18, according to regulatory documents. On a standalone basis, it registered a profit of ₹20.16 crore in FY19. Revenue from operations also increased to ₹1,305.92 crore in FY19 from ₹471.18 crore in FY18, it added.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Andhra farmers protest against CM Jagan's idea of three capitals
text: Farmers in different parts of Amaravati in Andhra Pradesh held a protest on Wednesday against CM YS Jagan Mohan Reddy's suggestion to have three capitals. Farmers said they gave land to the government under the land pooling scheme hoping that Amaravati will always remain the capital. Reddy mooted the idea of three capitals to give "decentralised development" a push.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: 2 policemen killed while on way to guard polio vaccinators in Pak
text: Two policemen were killed by gunmen in northwestern Pakistan while the latter were on their way to a health centre to provide security to polio vaccinators in the area. The gunmen managed to flee the scene after the incident, the police said. Reportedly, militants have alleged vaccination of children to be a Western plot to sterilise the population.
author: Shailesh

headlines: South Sudan Prez, ex-rebel leader agree to form unity govt by Feb
text: South Sudan President Salva Kiir and former rebel leader Riek Machar agreed to form a unity government by February or a "transitional" unity government even if they fail to resolve differences. The two leaders signed a peace deal in 2018 under pressure from the UN, the US and regional countries. The ceasefire will hold, no one wants war, Kiir said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: 5 dead, dozens injured in Hong Kong bus crash
text: At least five people were killed and dozens were injured after a double-decker bus slammed into a tree in Hong Kong on Wednesday, officials said. Hong Kong Police Force said that emergency rescue and investigation are underway. Victims were reportedly seen being removed in black body bags and placed next to a sign reading "Temporary Mortuary" at the roadside.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Poland could exit EU over proposed judicial reforms: Polish SC
text: Polish Supreme Court said that Poland's ruling Law and Justice party's (PiS) proposed judicial reforms may clash with European Union laws and lead to the country leaving the union. Reportedly, under the proposed reforms a judge could be removed by the government for questioning the legitimacy of government's judicial reforms. The PiS claims reforms are necessary to make judiciary efficient.
author: Shailesh

headlines: UK startup makes tilted toilet to help companies cut employees' toilet breaks
text: A UK-based startup named StandardToilet has made a toilet seat sloped forward by about 13 degrees to increase strain on the legs similar to a gentle squat. It is aimed at companies looking to cut down the time employees spend during their toilet breaks. The startup claims it gets uncomfortable to spend more than five minutes on the toilet.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Farhan Akhtar shares post depicting inaccurate map of India; apologises
text: Farhan Akhtar has apologised after he shared a post on Citizenship (Amendment) Act, depicting an inaccurate map of India. "Every inch and part of Kashmir is a part of India and I reject the inaccurate map. I regret not noticing this earlier," he wrote. Farhan had shared the post while announcing that he'll join a protest in Mumbai on Thursday.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Not ashamed to say my mom killed my alcoholic father when I was 15: Charlize
text: Actress Charlize Theron has said she's not ashamed to talk about her mother killing her alcoholic father when she was 15. The actress said her family was "incredibly unhealthy" due to her father's alcohol issues. Charlize's mother had shot her father dead after he fired three bullets which didn't hit them. The killing was ruled as an act of self-defence.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Your job is not to set fire to country but to douse it: Mamata to Shah
text: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee on the third straight day of her protest against the Citizenship Act and National Register of Citizens has said, "You (Amit Shah) are Home Minister of the country not only a BJP leader, please maintain peace in the country." She added, "Your job is not to set fire in the country, but to douse it."
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: What is the meaning of such challenges: Chidambaram on PM's remarks
text: Congress leader P Chidambaram has tweeted, "Why should we give citizenship to people who are already citizens of Pakistan? What is the meaning of such challenges to the Opposition?" This comes after PM Narendra Modi said, "If they (Congress and allies) have the guts, they should openly announce that they are ready to grant Indian citizenship to every Pakistani citizen."
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: KL Rahul smashes his third hundred in ODI cricket, first in India
text: Team India opener KL Rahul smashed his third hundred in ODI cricket, achieving the feat against West Indies in the second ODI on Wednesday. It is the 27-year-old's first ODI hundred in India. With this, he became the second Indian after Rohit Sharma to score an international hundred in each format on home soil.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Virat Kohli gets out on golden duck in ODI cricket after six years
text: Team India captain Virat Kohli was dismissed for a first-ball duck in the second ODI against West Indies on Wednesday, registering his first golden duck in ODI cricket after six years. Kohli, who is playing his 400th international match, was caught by Roston Chase at mid-wicket on the bowling of Kieron Pollard. Overall, it is Kohli's 13th duck in ODIs.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Rohit Sharma smashes 10 hundreds in a year for the first time in his career
text: India opener Rohit Sharma smashed his 28th ODI hundred in the second ODI against West Indies on Wednesday. The hundred is the 32-year-old batsman's tenth international hundred across formats this year. This is the first time that Rohit has slammed 10 international hundreds in a year. Rohit has jumped to the joint-fourth position in the list of most ODI hundreds.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Health records of 15 million Canadians compromised in cyberattack on lab
text: Law enforcement agencies have launched an investigation after Canadian laboratory services provider LifeLabs on Tuesday revealed that a cyberattack compromised data of up to 15 million Canadians or nearly half the population. The company admitted to a cyberattack that involved unauthorised access to its computer systems. The company also said it paid an undisclosed sum to hackers to retrieve data.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Australia experiences its hottest day in recorded history at 40.9℃
text: Australia on Tuesday experienced its hottest day on record with an average maximum temperature of 40.9℃ across the country, according to data released by the Bureau of Meteorology. The temperature beat the previous 40.3℃ record set on January 7, 2013. The soaring temperature was recorded as wildfires continue to burn across the country's New South Wales (NSW) state.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Man talks to Mumbai RJ via matrimonial site, threatens to post photoshopped pics
text: A 32-year-old cab driver has been arrested for allegedly stalking a Mumbai-based radio jockey and threatening to circulate photoshopped photos of her on social media. The 34-year-old RJ said she came in contact with the accused through a matrimonial website. She stopped talking to him after he asked for her bank account details, following which he started threatening her.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Millions of Muslims could flee India: Pakistan PM
text: Pakistan PM Imran Khan said that millions of Muslims could flee India due to the restrictions in Kashmir and the new Citizenship (Amendment) Act, creating a "refugee crisis". "We're worried there not only could be a refugee crisis, we're worried it could lead to a conflict between two nuclear-armed countries...Our country won't be able to accommodate more refugees," he added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: 8 students of Mumbai school suspended for WhatsApp chat on raping classmates
text: A Mumbai school has suspended eight students aged 13-14 years for making violent and sexually explicit comments on their female classmates on WhatsApp that included words like 'rape' and 'gangbang'. It came to light when the parents of two girls saw the conversation and reported it to school. Some of the girls had stopped attending school saying they were scared.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Is govt serious about court security: HC as man shot dead in Bijnor courtroom
text: The Allahabad High Court took suo motu cognizance of the shootout in a courtroom in Bijnor. "The most incompetent police professionals are deployed for security of court premises in state. Is government serious about court security?" the court said. We'll ask the central government to deploy central forces if the state government cannot provide adequate security, it added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Nagpur Mayor Sandip Joshi shot at days after receiving threat letter
text: Nagpur city mayor Sandip Joshi was attacked by two unidentified persons on Tuesday midnight, however, he escaped uninjured. "I was out with my family. While I was returning two people came in a vehicle and fired bullets on my vehicle thrice. I had received threats earlier. Police says this might be in connection with anti-encroachment in the city," he said.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: 5 booked for enactment of Babri mosque demolition at K'taka school
text: The police in Karnataka has booked five members of a school administration including RSS leader Kalladka Prabhakar Bhat for allegedly making students re-enact the 1992 demolition of Babri mosque during a school event. Puducherry Lieutenant Governor Kiran Bedi, Union Minister of Chemicals and Fertilizers DV Sadananda Gowda, and state ministers H Nagesh and Shashikala Jolle had attended the event.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: 21-yr-old who raped 4-yr-old girl gets life sentence within 16 days of arrest
text: A special POCSO court on Tuesday sentenced a 21-year-old man to life imprisonment for raping a four-year-old girl in Rajasthan's Churu. The accused committed the crime on November 30 and was arrested the next day. The police completed investigation and filed chargesheet in seven days, following which the court held trial on a day-to-day basis.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Trump writes 6-page letter to US House Speaker ahead of impeachment vote
text: US President Donald Trump wrote a six-page letter to US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi ahead of the impeachment vote against him. Accusing the Democrats of pursuing an "illegal, partisan attempted coup", Trump wrote that he had been "deprived of basic Constitutional Due Process from the beginning of this impeachment scam". "You view democracy as your enemy!" he further wrote.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Infosys pays California ₹5.7 cr, settles claims it got workers under wrong visas
text: Infosys has agreed to pay $800,000 (₹5.7 crore) to California to settle claims of misclassification of foreign workers and tax fraud. Infosys allegedly brought in workers using wrong visas to underpay them and avoid paying state taxes. About 500 employees were working in California on company-sponsored B-1 visas rather than H-1B visas between 2006 and 2017, the US state said.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: She is the most intuitive director I've worked with: Ranvir on Mira Nair
text: Actor Ranvir Shorey, who will be seen in Mira Nair's upcoming TV series 'A Suitable Boy', said that she is "possibly the most intuitive director" he has worked with. "Her attention to detail...really shows through her work," he added. "It's an absolute pleasure working with Mira...look forward to any opportunity I get to work with her," Ranvir further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Protest freely but show respect: Barca manager ahead of El Clasico
text: Ahead of the El Clasico against Real Madrid on Wednesday night, Barcelona manager Ernesto Valverde said that fans were free to protest "as long as they show respect to everyone". The encounter between the Spanish clubs is expected to witness political chanting with a pro-Catalan independence protest scheduled around Camp Nou stadium only hours before the match.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Serie A CEO apologises over monkey paintings in anti-racism campaign
text: Italian football league Serie A CEO Luigi De Siervo has apologised for the monkey paintings in its anti-racism campaign, which came under criticism. "We realised it was inappropriate," Siervo said. With several incidents of black players being subjected to monkey chants, the league had revealed the paintings of three differently coloured monkeys to show everyone is the same.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Google to resume Chrome 79 update as it fixes bug that 'deleted' data
text: The new Google Chrome update, Chrome 79, will start rolling out again after it was halted due to a bug that deleted data from third-party apps on Android devices. The tech company said that the data was not deleted but was made 'invisible' by the bug. Reportedly, Chrome was switching web data storage locations which led to the issue. nn
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: 2 missing bodies of NZ volcano victims may never be found: Police
text: The bodies of two missing people after a volcano erupted on New Zealand's White Island may never be found, police said on Wednesday. The police further added that they would be scaling down search operations. The two bodies are believed to be in the waters around the island and the official death toll from the eruption stands at 16.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Myanmar seizes boat carrying over 150 Rohingya Muslims
text: Myanmar Navy on Sunday seized a vessel carrying as many as 173 Rohingya Muslims, including 22 children, off the coast of Tanintharyi Division's Kawthaung township. "We will hand them over to immigration authorities and police to take action," an official said. The boat reportedly came from camps in Bangladesh and was bound for Malaysia.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Japanese journalist wins $30,000 in damages in alleged rape case
text: A Japanese court asked journalist Noriyuki Yamaguchi to pay around $30,000 in damages to journalist Shiori Ito in a civil lawsuit after she alleged that he raped her. Ito alleged she was raped by Yamaguchi in 2015 when she met him to discuss an offer to find her a job. The court rejected a counter-suit filed by Yamaguchi against Ito.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Daisy Ridley wears red Oscar de la Renta gown at 'Star Wars...' premiere
text: The 'Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker' world premiere took place on Monday in California. Actress Daisy Ridley, who plays Rey in the franchise, wore a red Oscar de la Renta one-shoulder gown and actor John Boyega, who plays Finn, attired in a blue suit. Kelly Marie Tran, who plays Rose Tico, opted for a blue Jason Wu gown.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Nirbhaya gangrape convict's review plea rejected; SC confirms death penalty
text: The Supreme Court has rejected the review petition filed by Nirbhaya gangrape convict Akshay Thakur, who was awarded death penalty. Seeking review of his conviction, Thakur had said that life in Delhi is already getting "short" due to air and water pollution. Earlier, Chief Justice of India SA Bobde recused himself from the case.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Cyrus Mistry restored as Executive Chairman of Tata Sons
text: The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) has restored Cyrus Mistry as Executive Chairman of Tata Sons and ruled that his ouster in 2016 was illegal. Mistry had taken over as Tata Sons' sixth chairman in 2012 after Ratan Tata announced his retirement. The Mistry family is the single largest shareholder in Tata Sons, with an 18.4% stake.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: OnePlus to announce 'something special' at CES 2020, says CEO Pete Lau
text: OnePlus has announced that it will hold its first major event at the upcoming Consumer Electronics Show, one of the largest technology trade shows in the US, which will be held next month in Las Vegas. OnePlus founder and CEO Pete Lau tweeted about the 'special event' at the CES and said that the company will showcase "something special".
author: Roshan Gupta

headlines: Nirbhaya gangrape convict can file mercy plea before Prez within 7 days: SC
text: The Supreme Court has said that the Nirbhaya gangrape convict Akshay Thakur can file mercy petition before President Ram Nath Kovind within seven days. Thakur's lawyer had sought three-week time to file the petition. This comes after the top court rejected his plea seeking review of his conviction and upheld his death penalty.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Academy announces list of 344 films eligible for Oscars 2020
text: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS) has announced a list of 344 feature films eligible for the Oscars 2020. For a film to be eligible for Oscars, it must run for seven consecutive days in commercial theatres in California's Los Angeles County by December 31. It must have a running time of more than 40 minutes.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Won National Award for 137th film, a girl won it for 1st film on same day: Akshay
text: Speaking at Agenda AajTak, Akshay Kumar shared an incident from 64th National Film Awards held in 2017 when he won his first National Award for Best Actor for 'Rustom'. He said a girl congratulated him and asked how many films he had done. "I said 137...it was her first film...she was winning National Award...kaise mera insult ho gaya," Akshay added.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Sikh group provides food to CAA protesters in Delhi, video surfaces
text: A video of NGO Khalsa Aid's volunteers providing refreshments to people protesting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in Delhi has surfaced online. Volunteers can be seen distributing tea and snacks to the protesters on the road. People in different parts of the national capital have been protesting for the past few days against the amended Citizenship Act.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: No BJP member in Ram Temple trust, govt won't spend on project: Shah
text: Home Minister Amit Shah said that no BJP member will be a part of the trust that'll oversee the construction of the Ram Temple in Ayodhya. The government won't spend anything on the project and the trust will have to collect donations, he added. Shah had earlier said that a sky-high Ram Temple would be constructed in next four months.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: I don't need permission in my own country to say what I feel: Irfan Pathan
text: Responding to criticism over his tweet supporting Jamia Millia Islamia students amid anti-CAA protests, all-rounder Irfan Pathan said, "I don't need anyone's permission in my own country to say what I feel." "I've represented my country. Some people should realise that. When I ran into bowl for India, I didn't think I'm a Muslim. I'm an Indian first," he added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: No internet, bookings; how will we pay EMIs: Ola, Uber drivers in Assam
text: All Assam Cab Operators' Union, with drivers from aggregators like Ola and Uber, threatened an aggressive campaign against the government after a week-long suspension of internet in some parts. Drivers took to streets demanding prompt resumption of mobile internet for bookings. "We're unable to feed our families. Many have to pay EMI...we may become bank defaulters," the union's president said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: 18 UP policemen suspended after 3 men kill murder accused in courtroom
text: Uttar Pradesh Police has said that it has suspended 18 policemen after a man accused of killing a Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) leader and his nephew was shot dead by three men inside a courtroom in Bijnor on Tuesday. The three men, including the BSP leader's son, were arrested. Three policemen and a court employee were injured in the attack.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Won't be satisfied till death warrant is issued against convicts: Nirbhaya's dad
text: After the Supreme Court upheld the death penalty of Nirbhaya gangrape convict Akshay Thakur, her father said, "We're still not fully satisfied." "Until a death warrant is issued (against the convicts) by Patiala House Court, we'll not be content," he added. Her parents' plea had sought issuance of death warrant and execution of all convicts by December 18.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Death warrant delayed for convicts in Nirbhaya case, next hearing on Jan 7
text: A Delhi court has adjourned the hearing on plea by Nirbhaya's parents for immediate death warrant to the accused in the gangrape and murder case to January 7. The court said fresh notice will be issued to the convicts after Supreme Court dismissed a convict's review petition. Addressing Nirbhaya's mother, the judge said, "I've my sympathies...but accused have rights too."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Staircase of UP's Atal Ghat where PM Modi slipped to be repaired
text: The staircase of the Atal Ghat in UP's Kanpur where PM Narendra Modi slipped last week will be repaired to prevent such incidents in the future. "Only one step of the staircase, which is uneven in height, will be...reconstructed to align it with other steps," Divisional Commissioner Sudhir Bobde said, adding that several visitors had tripped on the step.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Nirbhaya's mother breaks down in court after death warrant hearing delayed
text: Nirbhaya's mother broke down in Patiala House Court after the judge postponed the death warrant hearing in the case to January 7. Addressing Nirbhaya's mother, the judge said, "We have full sympathy with you. We know someone has died but there are their (convicts) rights too. We are here to listen to you but are also bound by the law."
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Kashmir economy suffered loss of ₹18,000 crore since Aug 5: Trade body
text: Kashmir's economy suffered a loss of nearly ₹18,000 crore because of restrictions since August 5 when its special status was revoked, the Kashmir Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KCCI) said. Sectors directly dependent on internet such as IT and e-commerce had been "ruined", it added. "We fear this crisis will further intensify in 2020," said KCCI President Sheikh Ashiq Ahmad.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: I'm happy: Nirbhaya's mother after SC rejects convict's review plea
text: After the Supreme Court rejected the review petition filed by Nirbhaya gangrape convict Akshay Thakur, Nirbhaya's mother said she is happy with the court's decision. "We have gone a step further," the mother added. Thakur, one of the four convicted for rape and murder of the 23-year-old Nirbhaya in Delhi in 2012, had sought review of his death penalty.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: 6 men in bus couldn't have raped her in just 21 min: Nirbhaya convict's lawyer
text: The lawyer appearing for Nirbhaya gangrape convict said in Supreme Court, "Dying declaration of Nirbhaya...cannot be relied upon. All 6 persons in the bus could not have raped her in just 21 minutes." "She didn't even name any of the accused...or mention the iron rod used by the accused," he added. The court was hearing convict Akshay Thakur's review plea.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 3-time Assam CM Tarun Gogoi in court as lawyer after 36 yrs to challenge CAA
text: Former three-time Assam CM Tarun Gogoi on Wednesday attended court proceedings as a lawyer at Supreme Court after 36 years. He assisted Congress' P Chidambaram and took up a batch of petitions challenging the constitutional validity of Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019. The apex court adjourned the matter till January 22 after issuing a notice to the Centre.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Thankful that I'm out of jail, was very scared: Payal Rohatgi
text: Payal Rohatgi, after getting bail on Tuesday, said she is "thankful" to the people, her lawyer and family for getting her out of jail. "I was very scared," Payal, who was sent to eight-day judicial custody on Monday, said. She added that her video on Nehru family got her "trapped in legality" when she was only exercising freedom of speech.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Anguished by actor Shreeram Lagoo's demise: PM Narendra Modi
text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Wednesday condoled the demise of veteran actor Shreeram Lagoo, who passed away on Tuesday at the age of 92 due to age-related complications. "Anguished by [Shreeram Lagoo's] demise...His work will be remembered for years to come," the PM tweeted. "[He] personified versatility and brilliance...[and] enthralled audiences with outstanding performances," he added.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Related myself to a python: Mardaani 2 villain on preparing for role
text: Actor Vishal Jethwa, while talking about how he prepared for the character of a serial rapist for his Bollywood debut film 'Mardaani 2', said, "I tried to relate myself to...a python." "I watched...videos of...how [a python] preys...to reach that darkness within me," he added. He also revealed that playing a rapist was disturbing and took a toll on him.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Today's stars are spoilt as too many people surround them: Rani Mukerji
text: Rani Mukerji on Neha Dhupia's show '#NoFilterNeha' said that today's stars "are bit too spoilt" because there are too many people surrounding them. "Today you're less prone to making mistakes...so many people around...tell you what to do and not do," she added. "Our moms would do all of that single-handedly," Rani further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Robots to greet, guide visitors during Tokyo Games 2020
text: Japan's Haneda airport has announced that robots would be greeting and guiding the visitors during the Tokyo Games 2020. The airport will employ four robots, divided into two groups. The first group will have digital signage guiding robots, while the second group will comprise security robots that can operate and move by themselves.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Can't see New Zealand winning a game: Ricky Ponting
text: Former Australian captain Ricky Ponting said, "Australia have played some really good cricket here in Perth and if they continue to play anywhere near that I can't see New Zealand winning a game." Ponting added that he was worried about the visiting New Zealand side and the 'lack of penetration with their bowling attack'.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Kerala's semi-high speed rail corridor project gets Centre's approval
text: The Centre has given in-principle approval to the Silver Line, a semi-high speed railway corridor project from Kerala's Thiruvananthapuram to Kasaragod. The rail corridor will reduce the travel time from Thiruvananthapuram to Kasaragod from 12 hours to 4 hours. Trains on this corridor will go through 11 districts and will run at a speed of 200 km per hour.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: I want him to wear pink suit but he won't: Shahid Kapoor's stylist
text: Actor Shahid Kapoor's stylist Anisha Jain said in an interview that the 38-year-old actor will "never do anything that he isn't comfortable with". She added that she wants Shahid to wear a pink suit but he keeps refraining. "It's just not his colour. He keeps making fun of me saying, 'Anisha you want me to wear pink'," she further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Section 144 imposed in North-East Delhi after protests over CAA
text: A day after protests over the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in North-East Delhi turned violent, police on Wednesday imposed Section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in the district. At least 21 people were injured, nearly 20 vehicles and other public properties were damaged in the protests in North-East Delhi's Seelampur area. Those injured in the clash included 15 policemen.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: SC refuses to stay implementation of Citizenship Act, sends notice to govt
text: The Supreme Court on Wednesday issued a notice to the Centre on a batch of petitions challenging the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, while refusing to put a stay on the implementation. The apex court bench headed by Chief Justice SA Bobde has posted the matter for hearing on January 22. Around 60 petitions have been filed against the Act.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: I sell my talent, not conscience: Sushant on contract ending with Savdhaan India
text: Sushant Singh, whose stint as 'Savdhaan India' host ended after he joined a protest against violence on Jamia Millia Islamia University students amid CAA protests, said, "I sell my talent, not my conscience." "It can be...coincidence that it happened on...same day as my presence at the protest," he added. "I don't want to link both these things," Sushant further said.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Viral pic of 'unrecognisable Dilip Kumar' is of his brother, clarifies actor
text: The Twitter handle of veteran actor Dilip Kumar on Tuesday clarified that a picture that's going viral on social media is not of the actor but of his brother Aslam Khan. "Dilip Kumar is not in the pic," the tweet added. The actor's handle had shared a post which said that 97-year-old Dilip Kumar looks "almost unrecognisable" in the picture.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Veteran actor Shreeram Lagoo passes away aged 92
text: Veteran actor and theatre personality Shreeram Lagoo passed away on Tuesday aged 92 in a private hospital in Pune. "I spoke to his son-in-law. He died due to age-related complications," actor and playwright Satish Alekar told media. Lagoo was known for his roles in films like 'Gharaonda', 'Gandhi', 'Pukar', among others and in various Hindi, Marathi and Gujarati plays.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Tried to meet Trump with 'beautiful' climate activists to convince him: Actress
text: Hollywood actress Jane Fonda said she attempted to meet US President Donald Trump after his election with a group of "beautiful, voluptuous, brilliant" climate activists, including Pamela Anderson, in order to convince him to tackle global warming. "I kind of know men like Trump, not as bad, but you know, I sort of know those inclinations," the 81-year-old added.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Alia Bhatt's pic shows wrong Preamble to Constitution of India, say Twitter users
text: Alia Bhatt was trolled after she shared the original Preamble to the Constitution of India on Instagram. "Wrong Preamble," a Twitter user's comment read. The Constitution (42nd Amendment) Act, 1976 changed description of India from a "Sovereign Democratic Republic" to "Sovereign Socialist Secular Democratic Republic" and also changed "unity of the Nation" to "unity and integrity of the Nation".
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Men's salon run by prison inmates opens up in Kerala
text: A men's salon run by inmates of Kerala's Central Prison in Poojappura was inaugurated on Monday by Director General of Prisons Rishi Raj Singh and Transport Commissioner R Sreelekha. An unused building located near the jail was renovated for the men's parlour. The initiative is part of the various rehabilitation programmes taken up by the Prison Department for the prisoners.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Delhi Police names 3 Jamia students, ex-Congress MLA in FIR
text: Delhi Police on Tuesday filed an FIR against seven persons in connection with the unrest in Jamia Millia Islamia University on Sunday. The police have named three Jamia students in the FIR along with former Congress MLA Asif Khan. The protest turned violent and protestors started pelting stones on policemen and also set DTC buses on fire, the FIR stated.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Citizenship Act has nothing to do with Muslims living in India: Shahi Imam
text: Shahi Imam of Delhi's Jama Masjid, Syed Ahmed Bukhari, made an appeal to the protesters to maintain peace and not to indulge in violence while opposing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. "Under [the] Act, Muslim refugees who come to India from Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Bangladesh won't get Indian citizenship. It has nothing to do with Muslims living in India," he said.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Urdu author Mujtaba Hussain to return Padma Shri over Citizenship Act, NRC
text: Urdu author Mujtaba Hussain has decided to return his Padma Shri award amid the protests against the Citizenship Act and NRC in the country. Hussain said he is pained over the current situation in the country with those in power targeting minorities, especially Muslims. "In these circumstances, I don't wish to keep any government award in my possession," he added.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Twitter founder Dorsey unfollows Facebook founder Zuckerberg on Twitter
text: Twitter Co-founder and CEO Jack Dorsey unfollowed Facebook Co-founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg's Twitter account, '@finkd'. Notably, Zuckerberg hasn't tweeted from the account since 2012 and has only 12 tweets in his account. Reports claimed that Dorsey made sure the world took note of the move by first following '@BigTechAlert', which updates on the following and unfollowing activities of CEOs.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Felt like time for new one: Facebook CEO changes display pic after 2 yrs
text: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg changed his display picture on Facebook, which he co-founded in 2004, after over two years. "It felt like time for a new one," Zuckerberg commented on his photo. His last profile picture from September 2017 was a display picture from 2015 with the "I support DACA" filter for American immigration policy 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals'.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: BJP MLAs sit on dharna inside UP Assembly against their own govt
text: Many BJP MLAs joined the dharna staged by ruling party MLA Nand Kishor Gurjar in the Uttar Pradesh Assembly after the Speaker didn't allow him to speak about alleged mistreatment by police. The MLAs said they were being ignored by their own BJP-led government. Several opposition leaders also supported Gurjar and joined the protest.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: WeWork arranges $1.75 billion in financing from Goldman Sachs
text: American office space provider WeWork has arranged a $1.75 billion letter of credit with Goldman Sachs. The credit line is part of SoftBank Group's $9.5-billion bailout that was announced in October when WeWork was on the brink of running out of cash. It had happened about a month after the startup withdrew its plans to go public.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Yahoo cancels Japan JV with OYO over rising complaints: Report
text: Yahoo has cancelled the joint venture with India's most-valuable hospitality startup OYO for its real estate rental brokerage business OYO Life in Japan over rising complaints from property owners over contracts, Nikkei reported. Yahoo reportedly sold its 30% stake in Japan-based OYO Technology and Hospitality to OYO in November. OYO confirmed the ownership buyback without confirming the reason.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Gurugram's Toffee Insurance gets ₹40 cr from IVM, Omidyar, Kalaari
text: Gurugram-based Toffee Insurance has raised $5.5 million (about ₹40 crore) in its Series A funding round led by IVM Intersurer. The round saw participation from Omidyar Network, Flourish Ventures, Accion Venture Lab and Kalaari Capital. Founded in 2017 by Nishant Jain and Rohan Kumar, the startup aims to make insurance accessible and affordable via relevant products in insurance value chain.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: IIT (BHU) scientist helps see new kind of magnetic explosion on Sun
text: Researchers, including IIT (BHU) solar scientist Abhishek Srivastava, using NASA's Solar Dynamics Observatory data observed a new type of magnetic explosion, called forced or controlled magnetic reconnection. The new type of the explosion is the first-ever seen to be triggered by a nearby eruption. "This was the first observation of an external driver of magnetic reconnection," Srivastava said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Entire genome of woman from 5,700-yr-old 'chewing gum' reconstructed
text: DNA recovered from a birch pitch piece, believably used as 'chewing gum' about 5,700 years back, helped Danish scientists reconstruct the entire genome of a woman dubbed "Lola". Likely a dark-haired, dark-skinned and blue-eyed woman, Lola's last diet may have been duck and hazelnuts, the DNA revealed. She may have also suffered from gum disease and mononucleosis, researchers said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: 38-yr-old woman gives birth to 17th child in 20th pregnancy; baby dies
text: A migrant labourer woman from Maharashtra recently gave birth to her 17th baby in a sugarcane field in Karnataka's Belgaum district, but the newborn girl did not survive, an official said. This was the woman's 20th pregnancy and she currently has 11 children. She had three abortions while her five children had died, the official said.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: 4 convicted in 2008 Jaipur blasts that killed 80; 1 acquitted
text: Four people have been found guilty of involvement in multiple bomb explosions in Rajasthan's Jaipur in 2008 that killed around 80 people and left more than 170 people injured. One person has been acquitted in the case. The four accused were held guilty on charges under different sections including Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: God would feel ashamed on creating such monster: Police on Nirbhaya convict
text: Solicitor General Tushar Mehta, who's appearing for Delhi Police in the Nirbhaya gangrape case, appealed in the Supreme Court that death-row convict Akshay Thakur doesn't deserve any leniency. "God would feel ashamed on creating such a monster," he stated. The top court was hearing the plea filed by Thakur, seeking review of his conviction.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Farhan to join anti-CAA protest, says 'time to protest on social media over'
text: Farhan Akhtar took to Twitter to announce that he is going to join the protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act on Thursday at Mumbai's August Kranti Maidan. "Time to protest on social media alone is over," he tweeted. Farhan also shared an image detailing out the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, National Register of Citizens (NRC) and how the two are related.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: We've crawled further into dark tunnel: Twinkle on Jamia violence
text: Amid anti-CAA protests in Jamia Millia Islamia university, Twinkle Khanna said that she "stands by a secular India where peaceful dissent is our constitutional right". Sharing a previous post, Twinkle wrote on Instagram that we've "crawled further into the dark tunnel" by oppressing students' voices. This comes after her husband Akshay Kumar clarified about liking a tweet cheering police action.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: I want to create a small jungle and a writer's hub: Pankaj Tripathi
text: Actor Pankaj Tripathi said in an interview that he would like to give back to Hindi cinema. He added that he would want to have a land where he could "create a small jungle to do farming and foster animals". "I also want to create a writers' hub where people could come, stay and write scripts," Pankaj further said.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: Kajal Aggarwal to unveil her wax statue at Madame Tussauds Singapore
text: Actress Kajal Aggarwal has revealed that she will unveil her wax statue at Madame Tussauds Singapore on February 5, 2020. "Me and my other half will see you in Singapore on 05/02/2020," she tweeted. "I remember going to @madametussauds as a child and being so fascinated with all the figures..overwhelmed to be amongst them myself," Kajal wrote in another tweet.
author: Atul Mishra

headlines: A couple from Jaipur help revive blue art pottery with aid from Amazon
text: Blue art pottery, a widely recognised craft form of Jaipur, was dying in 1950s and Rajmata Gayatri Devi undertook various programs to keep this art alive. Taking advantage of these programs, a couple from Jaipur, Girdhari and Sharada, the sellers of Blue Art Pottery at Amazon motivated each other to keep the art form alive.
author: Roshan Gupta

headlines: Say something, you're from Jamia too: RJ to SRK over silence on Jamia violence
