text: Radio jockey and actor Roshan Abbas has questioned Shah Rukh Khan's silence over the violence against students of Jamia Millia Islamia University. "Say something @iamsrk you are from Jamia too. Who has made you so quiet? #IStandWithJamiaMilliaStudents," Abbas tweeted. Shah Rukh was a master's student at Jamia, but dropped out to pursue a career in acting.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Filmmaker says B'wood celebs supplied protestors at CAA protests; Richa replies
text: Richa Chadha has responded to filmmaker Ashoke Pandit, who accused Bollywood celebrities of supplying 'dummy students' at CAA protests. She tweeted, "When you ran into me at a party and I promised ki aapki bakwas ko pyaar se counter karungi, you laughed! Now you levelling allegations?" "To behave in such...crass manner [at] your [age] is a travesty!" Richa added.
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Australian all-rounder Ellyse Perry named ICC Women's Cricketer of the Year
text: Australian all-rounder Ellyse Perry has been named ICC Women's Cricketer of the Year for the second time in three years. Perry also won the ICC Women's ODI Player of the Year award. Perry has scored 441 ODI runs and taken 21 wickets this year. Australia wicketkeeper Alyssa Healy won T20I Women's Cricketer of the Year award the second straight year.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Putin appears to use Windows XP which got last update in 2014
text: Pictures released by Russian President Vladimir Putin's press service appeared to show that he uses Windows XP operating system on his official computer. It is also installed on Putin's computer at his Novo-Ogaryovo residence near Moscow, reports said. Microsoft last provided security update for Windows XP in 2014 and warns computers running it might be more vulnerable to security risks.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: US student tweets 'I want my tweets on billboard', Twitter puts it on billboard
text: Microblogging site Twitter put a tweet by a female college student from the US on a billboard after she tweeted, "Wow I want my tweets to be on a billboard too." She originally posted the tweet on July 31, 2019. Reacting to Twitter's gesture, the student tweeted, "Twitter really put me on a billboard...look where sh*tposting can take you."
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: US startup unveils tech to turn normal helicopters self-driving
text: US-based autonomous helicopter startup Skyryse unveiled technology which could potentially turn normal helicopters into self-driving ones, through a modified FAA-approved helicopter 'Luna'. Called the "Skyryse Flight Stack", the system could enable future fleets of air taxis to fly themselves over cities, the startup claimed. It also includes sensor pads on the ground, called "smart helipads".
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Rabri Devi accuses daughter-in-law of harassing her, files complaint
text: Former Bihar CM Rabri Devi on Monday lodged a police complaint against her daughter-in-law Aishwarya Rai, accusing her of harassment. This came a day after Rai lodged a case against her in-laws under the Dowry Prohibition Act. Rai, the estranged wife of Tej Pratap Yadav, had also alleged that Rabri Devi had pulled her hair and slapped her.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Azam Khan's son Abdullah moves SC against disqualification from UP Assembly
text: SP leader Azam Khan's son Abdullah Azam Khan moved the Supreme Court against an Allahabad High Court ruling which disqualified him from the Uttar Pradesh Assembly. Khan was disqualified for producing fake age-related documents to contest the 2017 UP Assembly polls, when he was below the mandatory age of 25. Khan was an MLA from Suar constituency in Rampur district.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Family of 6 walking on railway track in Delhi hit by train; 3 die
text: At least three people were killed and two injured when they were run over by a train in Delhi on Tuesday. A family of six was walking on the tracks towards Shivaji Bridge Railway Station when the incident occurred. Of the six, a 36-year-old woman along with her two daughters aged 13 and 8 succumbed to their injuries.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Ex-Cong MLA Asif Khan named as accused in FIR for involvement in Jamia incident
text: Delhi Police has said that former Congress MLA Asif Khan has been named as an accused in the FIR for his involvement in Jamia Millia Islamia incident that took place on Sunday. Police had arrested 10 men in connection with the violence earlier in the day. Most of the accused have a criminal background and none are students, police said.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: CBSE Class 10, 12 exams to begin from February 15, 2020
text: The Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) today released the board examinations date sheet for the academic year 2019-20. Class 12 examinations will begin from February 15 and conclude on March 30, while Class 10 examinations will take place from February 15 to March 20. All the exams will be conducted in the morning session (10.30 am onwards).
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Will take back our citizens staying illegally in India if evidence provided: B'desh
text: Bangladesh will take back any of its citizens staying illegally in India if the evidence is provided, Gowher Rizvi, advisor to Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina said. The issue of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act is India's internal matter, he added. Bangladesh Foreign Minister AK Abdul Momen had earlier said Bangladesh has requested India to provide a list of Bangladeshis living illegally.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: I have lost sight in one eye after being beaten up by police: Jamia student
text: Mohammad Minhajuddin, a law student at Jamia Millia Islamia University, said he's lost sight in his left eye after being beaten up by police on Sunday. Minhajuddin said he was studying in the library when around 20-30 police personnel entered and beat up the students with sticks. He added he may lose sight in right eye after a few years.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: 2 Indian-origin lawmakers take oath holding Bhagwad Gita in UK
text: British Cabinet Minister Alok Sharma and Chief Secretary to the Treasury Rishi Sunak took oath as members of the parliament in the new House of Commons on Tuesday holding the Bhagwad Gita. Sunak, who's the son-in-law of Infosys co-founder Narayana Murthy, was re-elected the third time from Richmond, Yorkshire. Meanwhile, Sharma was elected for the fourth time from Reading West.
author: Arshiya Chopra

headlines: Man calls Mumbai woman via WhatsApp, shows his private parts; arrested
text: Mumbai Police has arrested a man for sexually harassing a woman through a video call. As per police, the man called the woman, who runs a beauty parlour in Kandivali, via WhatsApp and showed his private parts. The police added the accused is a serial offender and recently came out of jail after serving three years' sentence in POCSO case.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Nigerian prince sentenced to death for killing his boss
text: A 50-year-old Nigerian prince has been sentenced to death by hanging for killing his boss and dumping her body in a well. Prince Adewale Oyekan used to manage the deceased's restaurant and had conspired with her former servant to kill her. After her murder in 2012, they took over her businesses and property.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Our contract with Adani is under review: Siemens after criticism from activists
text: Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser has said the German engineering company's contract to deliver rail signalling system to Adani Group's controversial Carmichael coal mine in Australia is under review. Siemens has been targeted by environmental groups and anti-coal activists over the contract.  "I was not aware of and take your concerns seriously. I will diligently look into the matter," Kaeser said.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Uday Kotak is the best candidate to acquire Yes Bank: SBI Chairman
text: SBI Chairman Rajnish Kumar has said Kotak Mahindra Bank is best suited to acquire Yes Bank, which is looking to raise fresh capital. "I think Uday (Kotak) is the best candidate...You need deep pockets, Uday has that," Kumar said. Agreeing with Kumar, Axis Bank CEO Amitabh Chaudhry said, "We're a smaller bank...Mr Kotak, they are best suited rather than us."
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Pak pacer Usman Shinwari hospitalised, might miss 2nd Test vs SL
text: Pakistan pacer Usman Shinwari was reportedly hospitalised on Tuesday following fever and infection. On being asked if he'll play the second Test against Sri Lanka in Karachi, head coach and chief selector Misbah-ul-Haq said it's highly unlikely that he would be available. Leg-spinner Yasir Shah, who was dropped to train with Mushtaq Ahmed is likely to replace Shinwari, reports claimed.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: YouTuber flirts with Taiwan leader, Chinese agency asks to remove video
text: A Taiwanese YouTuber was asked by his Chinese agency to remove a video which featured Taiwan leader Tsai Ing-wen and was titled "First person in the world to flirt with a President". Chen Chia-chin, better known as Potter King, had used his signature humorous pickup lines in his video. The agency condemned the YouTuber for his "inappropriate language and actions".
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Google fires 5th employee over alleged workplace activism
text: Google has fired a fifth employee in less than a month over 'retaliation to protected workplace activism'. Kathryn Spiers was fired for creating a pop-up that directed employees to a list of worker rights when they visited the website of an anti-union firm that Google had hired. The notification read, "Googlers have the right to participate in protected concerted activities."
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: CM Thackeray's Jallianwala Bagh remark insult to martyrs: Fadnavis
text: BJP leader Devendra Fadnavis tweeted that comparing the Jallianwala Bagh massacre to police action in Jamia Millia Islamia University by Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray was an "insult to all the martyrs". Thackeray earlier said, "What happened at Jamia Millia Islamia is like Jallianwala Bagh massacre." Fadnavis accused Thackeray's party Shiv Sena of promoting and encouraging students' protests.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Andhra may have Amaravati, Kurnool & Vizag as 3 capitals: CM Jagan
text: Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy on Tuesday said that the state's capital may be spread across three cities. This may be done in a bid to develop all the regions in the state, he added. The existing capital Amaravati could become the legislative capital, port city Visakhapatnam the executive capital and Kurnool the judiciary capital, he added.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Posters mocking Nitish Kumar's silence on CAA, NRC seen in Patna
text: Posters mocking Bihar CM Nitish Kumar's silence on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) were seen across Patna on Tuesday morning. "Watch this face with attention, he has neither been seen nor heard...Bihar will forever be indebted to the person who finds him," said one of the posters.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Pope Francis abolishes 'pontifical secrecy' in sex abuse cases
text: Pope Francis abolished the 'pontifical secrecy' in sexual abuse cases of minors. Reportedly, such cases were previously shrouded in secrecy which the church claimed were efforts to protect the identities of victims and reputations of the accused. The Pope changed the age from 14 to 18 or under for pictures of an individual to be considered as child pornography.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Confident of recovering over 50% of IL&FS' dues: Uday Kotak
text: Chairman of IL&FS board Uday Kotak said that the company will be able to recover over 50% of its over ₹94,600-crore debt, adding that distribution mechanism was the most challenging part of the resolution process. IL&FS has developed resolution plan for all 302 entities. Kotak added that only the fittest lenders are able to survive in the current financial system.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Alia posts Preamble to Constitution on social media, says 'Learn from students'
text: Actress Alia Bhatt on Tuesday took to Instagram to post a picture of the Preamble to the Constitution of India amid several student protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 in the country. In another Instagram story, she posted the message, "Learn from the students". The actress also retweeted a tweet by comedian Vir Das that read, "Hey.....uh.....how's the economy?"
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Fan proposes to SL player with 'Marry me' poster, he gestures he's already married
text: A female fan proposed to Sri Lankan all-rounder Isuru Udana with a 'Marry Me' poster during the Mzansi Super League final match between Paarl Rocks and Tshwane Spartans. The Paarl Rocks all-rounder responded to the fan by showing his ring finger, gesturing that he is already married. "I am married so I am sorry," Udana later said about the proposal.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Planning was completely wrong: Yuvraj criticises management for India's WC exit
text: Former India all-rounder Yuvraj Singh has criticised team management for India's defeat in the semi-final of the 2019 World Cup. "I thought the planning was completely wrong...because they were thinking that Rohit and Virat are in good form but teams don't win like that. If you look at Australia (2003, 2007, 2015), they had set batsmen," he added.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: 84-yr-old Canadian man oldest ever to complete Antarctic Ice Marathon
text: Roy Jorgen Svenningsen, an 84-year-old Canadian national, has become the oldest person ever to complete the Antarctic Ice Marathon. Svenningsen, who started the race on December 13, took 11 hours, 41 minutes and 58 seconds to finish the race. Antarctic Ice Marathon is the southernmost marathon in the world where participants cover 42.195 km in temperatures as low as -20°C.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Jasprit Bumrah, Prithvi Shaw train with Team India, BCCI shares pic
text: Fast bowler Jasprit Bumrah and opener Prithvi Shaw trained with Team India on Tuesday. The BCCI took to social media to share a picture of the duo from the training ground with the caption, "Look who's here." Bumrah last featured for India in September before sustaining a stress fracture, while Shaw last featured for India in October 2018.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: Samsung Chairman jailed for disrupting union activities
text: Samsung Electronics Chairman Lee Sang-hoon has been sentenced to 18 months in jail by a South Korean court for sabotaging legitimate union activities. About 25 other current and former employees of various Samsung units were also convicted. Prosecutors said Samsung executives used several tactics to target union activities, including withdrawing business from subcontractors with active unions.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Tesla may not be allowed to launch Cybertruck in Europe: Report
text: Several media outlets, including Forbes, have reported that Tesla's Cybertruck launch is going to be road blocked in European countries where the safety norms that a vehicle must meet are extremely stringent. Experts pointed out that the exterior stainless steel shell of the Cybertruck could be red-flagged in Europe considering it may not be safe for pedestrians and cyclists.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: If anybody destroys public property, shoot them at sight: MoS Railways
text: Amid the ongoing anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protests, Minister of State for Railways Suresh C Angadi said, "If anybody destroys public property, including railway, I direct as a Minister, shoot them at sight." "My 13 lakh employees are working day and night for Railways...Some anti-social elements, supported by the Opposition, are creating problem in the country," he added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: France vetoes China's move to hold UNSC meeting on Kashmir: Reports
text: France has vetoed China's move to convene a UN Security Council (UNSC) meeting on Kashmir, reports quoting French diplomatic sources said. "Kashmir will not be discussed in UNSC. Our position has been clear. Kashmir issue has to be treated bilaterally," French diplomatic sources said. In August, the UNSC had met on Kashmir at China's request after India abrogated Article 370.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: India rejects Pakistan Assembly's resolution against Citizenship Act
text: India rejected a resolution passed by Pakistan's National Assembly condemning the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. "The resolution is a thinly-veiled attempt by Pakistan to further its false narrative on...J&K and Ladakh. It seeks to provide justification for Pakistan's support for cross-border terrorist activities in India. We're confident such attempts will fail," Ministry of External Affairs said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: 12 Delhi Police personnel injured in anti-CAA protests in Seelampur
text: A total of 21 people, including 12 Delhi Police personnel, were injured in protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in the Seelampur area on Tuesday, Alok Kumar, Joint Commissioner of Delhi Police, said. Five people were detained during the protests, he added. No bullets were fired on protesters, only tear gas shells were used by police, he further said.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Police enter Madras University campus as students protest against CAA
text: The Chennai Police on Tuesday entered the campus of Madras University as students protested against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The students have also been protesting against the police action in Jamia Millia Islamia University. Students of IIT-Madras, Loyola College and New College, among others had staged protests against the Act on Monday.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: 6p/minute call connect charge extended by one year in setback for Jio
text: Telecom regulator TRAI on Tuesday said Interconnection Usage Charges (IUC) of 6 paise per minute will continue till December 31, 2020, in a setback for Jio which wanted the charge scrapped. An operator pays the charges to rivals for connecting calls of its subscribers. Airtel and Vodafone Idea, which have higher incoming than outgoing traffic, will benefit from the move.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Anti-CAA protesters seen chasing police, pelting stones in Delhi
text: A video has surfaced online which shows people protesting against the Citizenship Act chasing and pelting stones on policemen in Delhi's Seelampur area on Tuesday. Joint Commissioner of Delhi Police Alok Kumar said that 21 people were injured including 12 policemen and three Rapid Action Force personnel. He added that two public buses and some bikes were also damaged.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Pained and anguished by death sentence given to Musharraf: Pakistan Army
text: Pakistan's Army on Tuesday expressed "pain and anguish" over the death sentence given to former Pakistan President Pervez Musharraf. "An ex-Army Chief...and President of Pakistan, who has served the country for over 40 years, fought wars for the defence of the country can surely never be a traitor," it said. Musharraf has been sentenced to death on treason charges.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Whirlpool recalls over 5 lakh washing machines over fire risk in UK
text: American multinational manufacturer of home appliances Whirlpool on Tuesday announced that it is recalling more than 5 lakh washing machines in the UK. The washing machines that are being recalled are branded as Hotpoint or Indesit that were made between 2014 and 2018. The door locking system of the affected washing machines can overheat and create the risk of fire.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: India men's hockey team to start Olympics vs NZ, women to face Dutch
text: India men's hockey team will open their 2020 Olympics campaign against New Zealand and the women's team against the Netherlands on July 25, as per the International Hockey Federation. India, ranked fifth in the world, will face the world number one Australia on July 26 in their second game. The women's team will face Germany on July 27.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Lakshya jumps 9 places to career-best 32nd in latest BWF rankings
text: Shuttler Lakshya Sen has jumped nine places to achieve his career-best ranking of world number 32 in the latest BWF rankings. 18-year-old Sen on Sunday won the Bangladesh International Challenge title in men's singles after defeating Malaysia's Leong Jun Hao 22-20, 21-18. Notably, Sen has won five titles in the last seven tournaments he has participated in this year.
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: New Android phones in Turkey not to have Google apps
text: Following Turkish competition board's ruling, Google has said that it won't be able to work with its Turkish partners on Android phones to be released in Turkey. As a result, while the existing phones would function normally, newer ones will not be having Google apps. The board in its ruling had called Google's changes to its contracts with partners unacceptable.n
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Bug in WeChat translated Canadian flag into ‘He’s in prison’
text: A translation bug on China's WeChat put random texts when a national or regional flag was added to a sentence in text conversations. The auto-translation system had translated the Canadian national flag as "He's in prison" while the European Union flag was translated to "Hey, it's hot". WeChat's developer Tencent Holdings has since apologised and will fix the translation bug.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Website that generates poetry based on people's location created
text: Data visualisation firm Satellite Studio has developed a website 'OpenStreetMap Haiku', which generates a poem based on a person's location or for any place in the world. It generates poems having elements from the location using information from around it and what users add to OpenStreetMap. Lines like "smells of chlorine" could pop up if a swimming pool is around.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Brothers cheat 64-yr-old woman of $150,000 in Bitcoin in Twitter scam
text: Two Canadian brothers have admitted to defrauding a 64-year-old woman out of over $150,000 worth of Bitcoin. The brothers had created a fake Twitter account of a Hong-Kong based cryptocurrency exchange platform and tricked her to share her account details. They are likely to be sentenced to two years in prison, as per the government's recommendation, reports said.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Fashion tech startup Zilingo buys Sri Lankan startup nCinga for $15.5 mn
text: Singapore-based fashion technology platform Zilingo has acquired Sri Lanka’s SaaS startup nCinga for $15.5 million. The companies claim this acquisition to be one of Sri Lanka’s largest tech exits in recent times. Founded in 2015, Zilingo plans to use nCinga's Manufacturing Execution System (MES) software in its network of 6,000 factories and 75,000 businesses.
author: Aishwarya

headlines: Government shutting down people's voices: Sonia Gandhi
text: Congress President Sonia Gandhi on Tuesday said that the government is "shutting down" the voices of the people and bringing legislations which are not acceptable to them. The statement was made after a delegation of opposition parties on Tuesday met President Ram Nath Kovind to discuss the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and the police action in Jamia Millia Islamia.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: Tehseen files complaint against PM Modi for 'clothes' remark
text: Tehseen Poonawalla has filed a complaint against Prime Minister Narendra Modi for saying those who are creating violence against Citizenship (Amendment) Act "can be identified by their clothes". "This is an attempt at demonizing Assam & Muslims citizens. Election Commission must act against PM," he tweeted. PM Modi had made the statement while addressing an election rally in Jharkhand's Dumka.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: RTI abuse causing fear, need to evolve some guidelines: CJI
text: Chief Justice of India SA Bobde on Monday observed that 'abuse' of the RTI Act was causing fear and paralysis in government. While hearing a PIL in Supreme Court for the appointment of Information Commissioners, Bobde said, "We're not against information and right to information." He further added there was "need to evolve some kind of guidelines" to regulate this.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: We'll take care of it: Trump on threats from North Korea
text: US President Donald Trump said, "I'd be disappointed if something would be in the works (in North Korea), and if it is, we'll take care of it". Recently, North Korea conducted tests that it claimed were important and crucial at a rocket launch site. It's up to the US to choose what "Christmas gift" it wants, North Korea recently said.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Big B gave 3 pieces of advice, couldn't follow 3rd one: Rajinikanth
text: Rajinikanth, while speaking about his friendship with Amitabh Bachchan, said, "[He] gave me three [pieces of] advice. That I should work out daily, keep myself occupied all the time and never enter politics." "I have followed the first two, but couldn't follow the last one due to circumstances," he added. Rajinikanth further said he looks up to Amitabh off-camera too.n
author: Daisy Mowke

headlines: Kolkata man who attended 10 FIFA World Cups passes away at the age of 86
text: Kolkata-based Pannalal Chatterjee, who attended 10 FIFA World Cups with his wife Chaitali, has passed away at the age of 86. The couple watched their first World Cup in 1982 when they were spending a summer with a friend in London. Pannalal was a former employee of the Kolkata Port Trust. "Football is our only child," Pannalal had earlier said.
author: Anmol Sharma

headlines: PewDiePie deletes his Twitter account with 19 million followers
text: YouTube creator PewDiePie, whose real name is Felix Kjellberg, deleted his Twitter account which had over 19 million followers on Monday after uploading a video on YouTube titled "I hate twitter". He said the platform rewards virtue-signalling and "constant posturing". PewDiePie had announced that he will be taking a break from YouTube early next year, saying he is "very tired".
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: WhatsApp bug let one message crash group chats, delete chat history forever
text: Cybersecurity firm Check Point's researchers have said they detected a vulnerability in WhatsApp that led to group chat crash the moment a 'destructive message' was introduced by the hackers in the chat. It led the entire group chat history being deleted forever. The bug was discovered in August 2019. WhatsApp fixed it in the update for version 2.19.246 and onwards.
author: Pragya Swastik

headlines: Opposition meets President Kovind over Citizenship Act, Jamia row
text: Opposition leaders led by Congress President Sonia Gandhi met President Ram Nath Kovind on Tuesday to discuss the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the police action in Jamia Millia Islamia on Sunday. Congress leaders Ghulam Nabi Azad, Kapil Sibal, DMK leader TR Baalu, TMC leader Derek O'Brien and CPI(M) leader Sitaram Yechury accompanied Sonia Gandhi to the Rashtrapati Bhavan.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: Very Large Telescope image reveals ancient starburst in Milky Way
text: Astronomers created a high-resolution image of Milky Way galaxy's central region using the European Southern Observatory's Very Large Telescope array. The observations revealed evidence of a burst of new star formation around one billion years back which was so intense, it led to over 1,00,000 exploding stars or 'supernovae'. The starburst happened for nearly 100 million years, researchers said.
author: Kanishka Pandey

headlines: Plane's nose landing gear doesn't deploy, accident averted as Navy officer notices
text: An accident involving a SpiceJet plane was averted at the Goa Airport on Tuesday after the runway controller at Naval Air Station INS Hansa noticed its nose landing gear wasn't deployed. He alerted the ATC tower which informed the incoming aircraft to abort the landing. The flight landed safely on the third attempt after the landing gear was partially deployed.
author: Krishna Veera Vanamali

headlines: Nothing can be gained by violence: Kejriwal appeals for peace in Delhi
text: Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal has appealed to the citizens of the national capital to maintain peace as violent protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act broke out in Seelampur area on Tuesday. Kejriwal said, "No form of violence is acceptable in a civilised society. Nothing can be gained by violence. We should put forth our opinion peacefully."
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: JNU to conduct exams via WhatsApp, email amid boycott by students
text: JNU will conduct exams through WhatsApp and email amid a boycott of exams by students protesting a fee hike by the university. "The alternate mode of test for the end semester of MPhil/PhD and MA Programme will be conducted keeping in mind the academic interest of JNU students," Dean of School of International Studies, Aswini K Mohapatra said.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: 2 Pak commandos killed as Indian Army foils BAT action along LoC: Reports
text: Two Pakistani Special Services Group (SSG) commandos were killed by the Indian Army as it foiled BAT (Border Action Team) action by the Pakistan Army along the LoC in Jammu and Kashmir's Poonch district, reports said. The incident took place after the SSG commandos and Pakistan Army personnel launched an attack in Nathua Ka Tibba in Sunderbani sector, reports added.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: IIT Madras students protest over Jamia violence, tear copy of CAA
text: IIT Madras students on Monday staged protests condemning the attack on the students of Delhi's Jamia Millia Islamia University. The students tore and burnt a copy of the amended Citizenship Act's gazette notification. "This is a warning to all of us that even the smallest dissent will be quelled. We must all stand up and demand justice," a student said.
author: Jigyasu

headlines: Banaras Hindu University students march in support of Citizenship Act
text: Students of Banaras Hindu University (BHU) in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh held a rally in support of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act on Tuesday. One of the participants said, "We are in support of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the Centre." This comes amid protests against the citizenship law that allows non-muslim refugees from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan to become Indian citizens.
author: Apaar Sharma

headlines: School bus attacked during anti-CAA protests in Delhi's Seelampur
text: A school bus was attacked during protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) in Delhi's Seelampur on Tuesday. The Delhi Police fired tear gas and lathicharged demonstrators as they threw stones and glass bottles at the police. Delhi Police PRO, MS Randhawa said that the situation in Seelampur is now under control.
author: Nandini Sinha

headlines: Marijuana laws have reduced prescription opioid use: Study
text: A new study from the US analysed 1.5 billion individual opioid prescriptions between 2011 and 2018 and found that recreational and medical cannabis access laws reduce the number of morphine milligram equivalents prescribed each year by 11.8% and 4.2%, respectively. These laws also reduce the total days supply of opioids prescribed and the total number of patients receiving opioids.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: I want to do the role of transgender in film: Rajinikanth
text: Actor Rajinikanth has revealed that after exploring "almost all genres" of films in his career spanning over 45 years, he wants to do a transgender's role next. He said this when he was asked about the genre or role he would like to explore. When asked if he has been approached for such a role, he said, "No, not yet."
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Ajay Devgn turns down Sanjay Leela Bhansali's 'Baiju Bawra': Report
text: Actor Ajay Devgn has reportedly turned down the role of Tansen, a classical musician at Emperor Akbar's court, in director Sanjay Leela Bhansali's upcoming film 'Baiju Bawra'. The film's story is about how a singer from peasant class scores over Tansen, a report said. Ajay reportedly declined the offer because he thinks that Baiju's role is more pivotal than Tansen's.
author: Vidushi Mishra

headlines: Hope all cards fall our way: KKR coach McCullum ahead of IPL auction
text: Ahead of the Indian Premier League (IPL) 2020 auction, Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR) coach Brendon McCullum said that they need some "luck" on the auction night to pick up the players they want. "Here's hoping the cards fall our way," he added. KKR released 11 players and retained 13 players with one new signing and are left with ₹35.65 crore.n
author: Ankur Taliyan

headlines: Indian Railways deploys 2,600 Mobile satellite terminals for punctuality
text: Indian Railways has installed over 2,600 Mobile Satellite Service (MSS) terminals on locomotives under Phase-1 of its train tracking system Real Time Train Information System (RTIS) for punctuality. Indian Railways launched the first 10 locomotives equipped with RTIS devices in January. RTIS will reportedly be fitted on about 2,700 engines out of 11,000 in total by end of this fiscal.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: App that turned iPhone into a virtual iPod removed by Apple
text: Rewound, an app that made iPhones look and feel like iPod Classics through its downloadable skins has been removed from the App Store. The company said it was pulled over copied designs and for charging users for Apple Music features. The developers plan to make a Rewound web app "without Apple's approval" and are looking for funding for the project.
author: Anushka Dixit

headlines: Students, teachers protest against closure of unrecognised Delhi schools
text: School students and teachers protested near Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal's house on Tuesday against his government's decision to close unrecognised schools in the capital. Delhi Directorate of Education had identified 700 unrecognised schools in October 2019. Protesters claimed that future of 10 lakh students was at risk because of the move.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Continue your political opposition to CAA but govt firm on it: Shah
text: Union Home Minister Amit Shah said that the Opposition can continue their political opposition to the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 (CAA) but PM Narendra Modi-led government is firm on implementing it. It grants Indian Citizenship to refugees from minority communities from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan facing persecution. Shah added that all refugees will live as Indians with honour.
author: Shailesh

headlines: Scientists develop sponge that soaks 90% oil from wastewater
text: Scientists have developed a kind of sponge capable of absorbing over 90% of oil microdroplets from wastewater within ten minutes. Drilling and fracking under the seabed produces 100 billion barrels of wastewater each year by releasing tiny oil droplets into surrounding water. On using the sponge, the oil coats its surfaces like a thin film through a process called adsorption.
author: Dishant Sharma

headlines: Fergusson College students protest against CAA, NRC in Pune
text: Students of Fergusson College in Maharashtra's Pune on Tuesday took out a rally in campus to protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), 2019 and National Register of Citizens (NRC). The students also conducted a signature campaign against the law that has triggered protests across the country. The police had earlier denied permission to students to stage protests.
author: Sakshita Khosla

headlines: Family of 10, including 2 children, killed in Afghanistan blast
text: As many as 10 people, including two children, of a family were killed in an explosion that took place in southeastern Afghanistan on Tuesday, officials said. The family was on their way to a neighbouring province when their vehicle struck the device planted on the main road, an official said. No group has so far taken responsibility for the blast.
author: Kirti Joshi

headlines: 49 journalists killed in 2019: Reporters Without Borders
text: Paris-based watchdog, Reporters Without Borders (RSF), said that 49 journalists were killed in 2019, the lowest figure in 16 years. Most of the journalists had died covering conflicts in Afghanistan, Syria and Yemen. However, the organisation said that the number of reporters being detained has increased to 389 in 2019, a 12% rise over the previous year.
author: Shailesh

headlines: US asks Turkey to explain threats to close military bases
text: US Defence Secretary Mark Esper said that he will ask his Turkish counterpart to explain President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan's threats to close two bases used by the US military in Turkey. Erdoğan's threats were in response to US' sanctions threat and US Senate's passing of a resolution recognising the killing of Armenians in the Ottoman Empire as a genocide.nn
author: Shailesh

headlines: Equitas Small Finance Bank files IPO papers to reportedly raise ₹1,000 cr
text: Equitas Small Finance Bank on December 16 filed draft red herring prospectus for its IPO with SEBI, aiming to reportedly raise about ₹1,000 crore. The bank said it would offer a fresh issue aggregating to ₹550 crore and will offer up to eight crore equity shares. The bank started operations in 2007 as a non-banking financial company.n
author: Anushka Dixit
